name: Orange Cream Dream
description: Scotch, orange soda and ice cream don't seem like the most obvious combination. But that's only until you give the Orange Cream Dream a whirl. It's an unexpected merger that starts with Monkey Shoulder Blended Scotch and ends with you requesting seconds. Mix this up during the summer, on a random weekend, or whenever you'd benefit from a tall, refreshing glass of scotch, orange soda, and ice cream. Hey, it's probably more often than you think.

ingredients.name: Dublin Orange Dream Soda (Or Other Orange Soda)

instructions.description: In a long glass, add a generous scoop or swirl of creamy vanilla soft-serve.
Fill glass 3/4 of the way with orange soda.
Top with Monkey Shoulder, and garnish with an orange peel.

ingredients.name: Part (8 Oz) Sugar Island Coconut Rum

instructions.description: Multiply first four parts by desired servings if you're making a large batch (we've included suggested measurements above for 8 servings).
Combine and stir all ingredients over ice.
Serve by pouring into an old-fashioned or similar glass.
Top individual glass with rosé, and garnish with pineapple chunks on a skewer.

name: The Garibaldi
description: The Garibaldi is an exceedingly simple two-ingredient cocktail, but one that tastes more intricate than it is. Traditionally composed of equal parts Campari and Orange juice, more recent iterations of the Garibaldi have upped the orange juice for a longer, more refreshing drink.Here, we're doing just that, with 1.5 ounces of Campari and 4 ounces of orange juice. That said, feel free to experiment to suit your own tastes. Whatever you do, be sure to use fresh-squeezed orange juice in your Garibaldi, which is needed to add that rich, orange-y sweetness to the bitter Campari.If you've got a juicer or blender, or a milk frother, or don't mind shaking up some OJ for awhile, you can attempt the "fluffy" orange juice that was popularized by Naren Young's NYC bar, Dante. For their Garibaldi, the juice is blended on a high speed, which aerates it and leaves it with a thick and fluffy texture. It's delightful.

instructions.description: Add Campari to a Collins glass with ice cubes.
Top with fresh orange juice.
Garnish with an orange wedge.

name: El Anticuado
description: The Old-Fashioned is best known for its whiskey-spiked sensibilities, but the tried-and-true template of spirit, sugar, and bitters can work across a variety of spirits. Proving that point is El Anticuado, which opts for añejo tequila as its base, plus Bolivar Bitters, which are light, floral, and aromatic.With its oak accents, the strong and simple drink should appeal to tequila and bourbon fans alike.

instructions.description: Muddle sugar cube with bitters in a mixing glass.
Add tequila and stir until cold.
Strain over a large rock, and garnish with an orange peel.

name: Rye Whiskey Thyme Julep
description: The Rye Whiskey Thyme Julep is a Mint Julep variation by Basil Hayden's, made with rye instead of bourbon, a dash of Angostura bitters for some complexity, and muddled thyme instead of mint. It's an extraordinarily simple cocktail, and doesn't require all the usual pomp and circumstance of crushing ice and finding a julep cup.

ingredients.name: Fresh Thyme Sprigs (Save One For Garnish)

instructions.description: Muddle 5 thyme sprigs in an Old-Fashioned glass.
Add rye whiskey, simple syrup, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into the Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with remaining thyme sprig and serve.

name: Bay Breeze
description: The Bay Breeze cocktail is a simple, fruity mixed drink that's great for summertime refreshment at the beach or barbecue. It's a snap to make, using only vodka, cranberry juice, and pineapple juice, and is a pretty universal crowd-pleaser when the weather is nice.The Bay Breeze is a variation of the Sea Breeze, a similar cocktail made with grapefruit juice instead of pineapple. As a result, it is also sometimes called a Hawaiian Sea Breeze in reference to the pineapple juice—but pretty much every bartender in the world is going to know what you mean if you order a Bay Breeze.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a Highball or Collins glass filled with ice.
Stir gently and serve.

name: Flaming B-52
description: The Flaming B-52 cocktail is a riff on the popular B-52 shooter, where the top layer is ignited to produce a flame, before being drank. As with the B-52, the Flaming B-52 recipe consists of a coffee liqueur (commonly Kahlúa Coffee Liqueur), an Irish cream (commonly Baileys Irish Cream), and an orange liqueur (commonly Grand Marnier Cordon Rouge)—layered—in that order, but an extra layer of overproof rum (commonly Bacardi 151) is added on top to help facilitate the flame being lit. Once lit, the Flaming B-52 should be drank quickly by placing a heat-resistant straw to the bottom of the shot glass before the glass heats up too much. The Flaming B-52 shooter became popular due to the crowd-pleasing spectacle it creates with the flame and being lit. These days, it has thankfully waned in popularity, as it is more of a gimmick than a great drink.

instructions.description: Pour the coffee liqueur into a chilled shot glass.
Layer or float the Irish cream next on top of the coffee liqueur (use an upside down spoon to help if necessary).
Layer or float the orange liqueur on top.
Layer or float the overproof rum on top, and light it to produce the flame.
With the shot glass still on the bar top, quickly place a straw to the bottom of the glass and drink quickly.

name: Vegas Bomb
description: The Vegas Bomb cocktail is a potent shot that's a popular order at bars. It's not the craftiest or most nuanced beverage—but you can't deny that it's fun. The Vegas Bomb recipe consists of three liquors—Crown Royal Canadian whisky, peach schnapps, and Malibu rum (or other coconut rum)—plus Red Bull energy drink. That's what you'll find being served in the vast majority of cases, however, occasionally recipes throw in a splash of cranberry juice or some butterscotch schnapps, or they employ other brands of energy drinks besides Red Bull.How to Drink a Vegas BombDrinking a Vegas Bomb involves dropping a shot glass into a larger glass (similar to other "bomb drinks," including the Jäger Bomb and Sake Bomb) and chugging the contents in one go. In this case, the three liquors are combined together in the shot glass, then dropped into a glass of Red Bull.The Vegas Bomb drink isn't what you would call a nuanced cocktail, but if a party drink is what you're looking for, the Vegas Bomb shot is a fun and popular one—particularly among college students, bachelorette parties, and bachelor parties—who desire a dose of caffeine with their alcohol. And most party-centric bars, especially those that serve a college crowd, will have the ingredients on hand to make one.Alternatively, if you don't want to go the two-glass-chug route, you can simply shake all four ingredients together with ice in a cocktail shaker, strain the contents into a glass and drink at your leisure. It doesn't have quite the communal, glass-slamming effect as your typical Vegas Bomb experience, but it tastes the same and still gets the job done.Vegas Bomb OriginsSo, where does the name "Vegas Bomb" come from? There are some who believe the Crown Royal symbolizes a Royal Flush—the highest ranking poker hand—which makes the name fitting in true Las Vegas fashion. There is also a Royal Flush Shot, a mixture of Crown, cranberry, peach schnapps, and raspberry liqueur, so the Vegas Bomb shot recipe is an easy departure from that, losing the raspberry while adding the Red Bull and glass-within-a-glass drinking method.Those are both very plausible reasons for the name. But one thing we can absolutely confirm we've heard is this: What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas. But what happens after Vegas Bombs, well, that's less certain.

instructions.description: Pour Crown Royal, Peach Schnapps, and Malibu Rum into a large shot class.
Pour chilled Red Bull into a pint glass with no ice.
When ready, carefully drop the shot into the glass of Red Bull, and chug it.
Alternatively, skip the above steps, and just mix all the ingredients over ice.

name: Dalmatian
description: The Dalmation is a peppery variation on the popular Vodka Greyhound cocktail. Using homemade black pepper syrup, the Dalmation recipe gives the tangy grapefruit classic a bit of a kick, with the heat of the pepper syrup providing for a bold, lingering finish against the backdrop of the citrus.

instructions.description: To make black pepper syrup: mix 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, 1 tsp cracked black pepper over low heat, until sugar is completely dissolved. Leave the pepper bits in syrup for a bolder flavor, or remove sooner for something milder. When syrup has cooled, strain into a container for storage.
Add black pepper syrup, vodka, and grapefruit juice to a shaker with ice, and shake well.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass or Highball glass over ice.
Garnish with a grapefruit twist (optional) and serve.

name: Margarita
description: The classic Margarita is a simple, citrusy cocktail, and for more than 40 years it’s been the unmistakable face of summertime and south-of-the-border beach hangouts (and, really, of tequila drinks in general). Unfortunately, thanks to the popularity of syrupy pre-made mix, most people’s homemade Margaritas leave a bit to be desired. But with a little elbow grease and an extra minute or two of prep time, it’s easy to whip up a Margarita that’s fresh, well-balanced, and delicious—and should prove a spectacular companion to some chips and salsa.What's in a Margarita?Over the years, we've seen the rise of blender Margaritas, Frozen Margaritas, and Skinny Margaritas, but for today's purposes we'll be sticking to the original (and please, no Margarita mix). This classic Margarita recipe calls for an ounce of fresh lime juice (if you don't feel like measuring, it's roughly the juice of one medium lime), a triple sec or orange liqueur such as Cointreau or Grand Marnier, and, of course, tequila. The drink is often garnished by a lime wedge or a salted rim, based on the preferences of those ordering it. The history of the Margarita Like many classic cocktails, the origins of the Margarita are shrouded in mystery. What's clear is that it belongs the the "daisy" category of cocktails, which are broadly defined as drinks made with a base spirit, liqueur, and citrus. Historically, the Sidecar serves as a popular example of the daisy template, and it's thought that this was adapted for the tastes of drinkers in Mexico with tequila in place of brandy.As per who mixed the first margarita and where, there are many competing versions that have either been debunked or cannot be verified. But it is known that the first printed recipe for a Margarita appeared in a 1953 issue of Esquire, which entailed tequila, triple sec and either lime or lemon juice. How to make a MargaritaMaking a Margarita is straightforward. After gathering your ingredients, you will add them to a a cocktail shaker and shake until chilled. Afterwards, pour the contents into a a Margarita glass and enjoy (ideally, some tacos will be nearby).Popular tequilas for a MargaritaBlanco tequila is the standard choice, as it's straightforward and mixes well, but you're welcome to use a reposado tequila if you want something a little different. That said, the oaky subtleties of a reposado or añejo tequila tend to be lost in a Margarita cocktail, so we don't recommend using anything too aged—or too expensive.

instructions.description: Rub rim of cocktail glass with lime juice, dip rim in salt.
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into the salt-rimmed glass and serve.

name: Painkiller
description: The Painkiller is a twist on the classic Piña Colada. While the latter contains rum, coconut, and pineapple, the Painkiller adds orange juice to the equation. It's creamy, fruit, and delicious—befitting a tropical locale, an umbrella, and having nowhere to be.Also noteworthy: the Painkiller specifically calls for Pusser's Rum. Whether you use said rum or not is up to you, but... the more you know.

instructions.description: Shake ingredients vigorously with ice, then pour into a tall glass over crushed ice.
Sprinkle nutmeg on top, and serve.
Mix all ingredients into an ice-filled shaker.
Shake, and strain into a chilled, sugar and cinnamon rimmed cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange spiral twist.
Combine gin, Campari and vermouth in a mixing glass and add ice. Stir and strain over fresh ice. Garnish with an orange peel.
* To make Cocoa Puff-Infused Vermouth: Add Cocoa Puffs to Martini Gran Lusso Vermouth for one hour, then strain through a tea strainer to remove cereal from vermouth.

name: Bee's Knees
description: The Bee’s Knees cocktail is a Prohibition-era classic made up of gin, honey and lemon. It is a delicious, spirit-forward cocktail that is a nice balance of sweet, tart, and strong.The phrase "bee's knees" was often used to call something "the best," and was a popular saying during the Roaring Twenties, a decade of opulence, decadence, and despite Prohibition, craft cocktails.Back then, ingredients like honey, citrus, and other sweeteners or fruits were often mixed with the era's harsh spirits to "soften" them up, mask the bad flavors, and make the drinks more palatable. In the case of the Bee's Knees cocktail, the strong flavor of the lemon with the sweetness of the honey helped turn the notorious bathtub gin of the time into a tasty and popular tipple.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients (except garnish) to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Singapore Sling
description: The Singapore Sling was invented at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore by bartender Ngiam Tong Boon, sometime in the 1900s or early 1910s. The recipe for the Singapore Sling changed drastically over time, due to being codified on handwritten notes, getting lost in translation as it traveled the globe, and the gradual decline in availability of some of its ingredients, like Cherry Heering and Bénédictine. Today, though, it's possible to make a Singapore Sling that's pretty close to the original, which is the recipe provided below. It doesn't traditionally have a garnish of any kind, but you can use a lime twist (added later at the Raffles Hotel) or a maraschino cherry if you're so inclined.

ingredients.name: Lime Twist Or Cherry For Garnish (Optional)

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except soda to a Highball or Collins glass over ice and stir gently.
Top with soda, stir once, and serve.
Optionally, garnish with a twist of lime or a cherry.
Shake all ingredients together with cube ice and double strain into a coup glass.
Garnish with a sprig of lavender, and serve.

name: Pisco Sour
description: The Pisco Sour is a classic South American cocktail made with pisco, a brandy (or aguardiente) distilled from Peruvian or Chilean wine. It was invented sometime between 1915 and 1922 by Victor Morris, an American expat bartender in Lima, Peru, and gradually became an international hit. It's a variation on the Whiskey Sour (and other sour cocktails), though it uses lime juice where that recipe typically uses lemon. The Peruvian Pisco Sour uses egg whites and bitters, but the Chilean recipe does not. It's the national drink of both countries, though, and there's a pretty fierce rivalry over who gets credit for the original.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients, except bitters, to a cocktail shaker WITHOUT ice and shake hard for about 30 seconds.
Add ice to shaker and shake again, hard, until chilled.
Double strain into a sour glass or Old-Fashioned glass, so that a layer of frothy egg white forms on top.
Add 2-3 drops of Angostura bitters to the top of the foam and serve.

ingredients.name: Dried Rose Tea Infused-Siembra Valles Tequila Blanco

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients together with ice and double strain into a coup glass.
Garnish with dried roses.
Mix and shake well and serve in a Highball glass. Served up

name: Cadillac Margarita
description: The Cadillac Margarita is more or less a standard Margarita, but it has an extra little float of Grand Marnier on top to class it up. The orange-flavored cognac liqueur blends beautifully with the other flavors, and complements the standard triple sec.To make a Cadillac Margarita, you start out by making a classic Margarita: add tequila (blanco or reposado, typically), triple sec (Cointreau if you want to be fancy, which you probably do if you're making this in the first place), and fresh-squeezed lime juice to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled, then strain into a Margarita glass or cocktail glass.For the float, gently pour a bit of Grand Marnier into the drink over a barspoon. This will keep it on the surface of the cocktail, and give it that classic Cadillac Margarita taste on the first sip.

instructions.description: Shake tequila, Cointreau, and lime juice in a cocktail shaker with ice.
Strain into salt-rimmed Margarita glass.
Float Grand Marnier on top.
Garnish with lime wedge (optional).
Alternatively, can serve over ice in an old-fashioned glass.

name: Mary Pickford Cocktail
description: Named for the famous silent film actress, the Mary Pickford cocktail is a Prohibition-era drink that has certainly aged well. It's fairly fruity and sweet, but not overpoweringly so. The result is a smooth, inoffensive cocktail that goes down almost dangerously easy, and looks gorgeous in the glass to boot (almost as gorgeous as its namesake herself).The Mary Pickford cocktail is rumored—and generally accepted—to have been created for her at the Hotel Nacional de Cuba by Eddie Woelke, the inventor of the El Presidente cocktail.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except garnish to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail or coupe glass.
Garnish with the maraschino cherries and serve.

name: Perfect Manhattan
description: The Perfect Manhattan is one of the simplest Manhattan variations out there, and differs only in its use of both dry and sweet vermouth (this is what "perfect" typically means in the cocktail world). It's often garnished with a lemon or orange twist, and sometimes a maraschino cherry as well—but one of the good ones, not those godawful neon-red things.This makes for a slightly drier drink, but blending the two vermouths does so without sacrificing the fundamental character of the Manhattan. The Perfect Manhattan is certainly worth a try if you've grown tired of the original, but aren't looking for anything too fancy.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except garnish(es) to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, garnish, and serve.

name: Black Tooth Grin
description: The Blacktooth Grin is a simple cocktail popularized by the band Pantera and its late frontman, "Dimebag" Darrell Abbott. Known best as a talented guitarist, Dimebag was also quite the drinker, and had a tendency to throw back a lot of whiskey. The Black Tooth Grin, a simple combination of Crown Royal, Seagram's 7, and Coca-Cola, made that whiskey go down easier. The name comes from a lyric in a Megadeth song called "Sweating Bullets."The cocktail (if you can call it that) is made by combining equal parts Crown and Seagram's 7 in a glass with ice, and then adding ice a splash of Coke—just enough to darken the color and provide some sweetness to the whiskey. Knock it back in one go, if you want to stay true to tradition, or just sip it slowly because you're an adult and can do whatever you want.

instructions.description: Add the Crown Royal and Seagram's 7 to a rocks glass with ice.
Add a splash of Coca-Cola.

name: Penicillin
description: The Penicillin cocktail was devised by Australian bartender Sam Ross, a veteran of famed New York bars Milk & Honey, Little Branch, Pegu Club, and Attaboy. The Penicillin recipe features a combination of blended scotch, Islay single malt, fresh lemon juice, honey syrup, and ginger to make a smoky, spicy, sweet cocktail that'll warm you right up.As Ross relocated and brought the Penicillin with him to the West Coast, the drink rose in popularity and spread to new bar programs, spawning off numerous variations and becoming one of "the most riffed-on modern classics" of the modern cocktail renaissance.

instructions.description: Muddle fresh ginger in a shaker and add the remaining ingredients, except for the Islay whiskey.
Add ice and shake until chilled, then double-strain into an ice-filled Old-Fashioned glass.
Float the whiskey on top and garnish with candied ginger (usually on a cocktail pick of some sort).
Shake all ingredients well with ice.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish, and serve.
Mix and Stir and serve up

name: Hell-Fire Punch
description: Named for the infamous Hellfire Club of 18th-century England, this complex punch packs some heat. The recipe is a speculative recreation devised by renowned cocktail historian David Wondrich, using ingredients that would have been available at the time (based partially on Benjamin Franklin's description of the drink as a "divine milk punch")—that said, there is a certain amount of artistic license taken here, and there's no way to know for sure what the Hellfire Punch referenced in the club's primary sources really would have entailed.

ingredients.name: 750-Ml Bottle Luxardo Sangue Moriacco Cherry Brandy
L Milk, Heated To A Simmer

instructions.description: Infuse cognac, rum, cherry brandy, and lemon zest for 24 hours.
Dissolve Demerara sugar in warm water, then let cool and add to spirits.
Add remaining ingredients.
The milk will curdle; let sit for 1 hour, then strain through a fine cloth.
Strain again, pouring liquid over retained curds.
Bottle and refrigerate until residues have settled, then siphon, rebottle, and store at cellar temperatures for future use.

name: Piña Colada
description: The Piña Colada is one of the most popular tropical rum cocktails, and sadly one that has been bastardized by poolside bars the world over. This is a classic Piña Colada recipe that doesn't use any kind of pre-made mix, instead opting for coconut cream and fresh pineapple juice. Be sure to use a proper coconut cream, as the alternative, coconut milk, is usually too thin. However, it will do in a pinch, and you can add a bit of condensed milk if you want to thicken it up a bit.While most recipes call for white rum, a gold or dark rum can make things a little more interesting—just don't bother using anything expensive, as its subtleties will be lost in the rest of the ingredients. This Piña Colada is blended, but you can also make a shaken version. Simply add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice, shake until chilled, and strain into a Hurricane glass with fresh ice.

instructions.description: Put all ingredients into an electric blender with 2 cups of crushed ice.
Blend at a high speed for a short length of time.
Strain into a Hurricane glass (or Collins glass) and serve with a straw.

name: Suffering Bastard
description:
The Suffering Bastard is a cocktail developed by legendary barkeep Joe Scialom—best known for his time as head bartender at Shepheard's Long Bar in Cairo—as a hangover cure for those particularly bad mornings after. The drink was made famous by its (potentially apocryphal) role in the Second Battle of El Alamein in World War Two.
The story goes that, the morning of the battle, the Hussar soldiers in Cairo were caught off guard by Rommel's forces after a night of particularly heavy drinking. The army sent a cable to Scialom requesting an urgent delivery of several gallons of his famous hangover cure, the Suffering Bastard. He delivered, the soldiers recovered, and the Germans were kept at bay.

ingredients.name: Orange Slice And Mint Sprig For Garnish

instructions.description: Add gin, cognac, Rose's lime juice, and bitters to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Stir ginger beer into shaker.
Pour unstrained into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
Garnish with an orange slice and sprig of clapped mint.

name: Gibson
description: The Gibson is a Martini variation that combines gin and dry vermouth. The garnish is where things take a turn. Rather than employing a lemon twist or olive, like a traditional Martini, the Gibson opts for a cocktail onion. This gives a pickled, briny quality to the drink that differs from olive brine. So while the change is subtle, it's noticeable.The Gibson's origin is unclear, but the oldest published recipe for the cocktail is believed to appear in William Boothby's 1908 book, The World's Drinks And How To Mix Them.

instructions.description: Stir gin and vermouth with ice in a mixing glass.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with cocktail onions and serve.
Muddle sugar cube, maraschino liqueur, bitters, and absinthe in the bottom of a mixing glass (the sugar cube is true to original form, but can also substitute 0.25 oz of simple syrup instead).
Add ice, and the whiskey, and stir well.
Strain into a chilled Old-fashioned glass over a big ice cube (can optionally build directly in the Old-Fashioned glass).
Garnish with an orange or lemon peel.

name: Charred Lemon
description: There's a bar in New York called Sugar East. At said bar, drink names are easy to remember, because they're simply ingredients. For example: Charred Lemon, Beet, and Grapefruit. Those are not just three separate components of a cocktail—those are the cocktails.One such cocktail that's easy to make at home is the aforementioned Charred Lemon, which is a simple take on the classic Gold Rush that combines bourbon with honey and lemon. But those lemons are charred for a smoky accent that really makes this drink sing. Try it for yourself. At the very least, it's a great opportunity to set fire to some citrus fruit.

instructions.description: Muddle charred lemons in a shaker tin.
Add bourbon, lemon juice and honey, then shake with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, and garnish with a charred lemon wheel.

name: Decadent Piña Colada
description: Next time you're feeling the heat, whether it's from sailing  or just from the sweltering city sun - blend up these Fat and Happy Pina Colada's and feel the heat just melt away. - Fat and Happy Blog

ingredients.name: Tips And Techniques: It Is Absolutely Imperative To Use Coco Lopez Coconut Creme In The Recipe And On The Rim Of The Glass, Don't Skimp.

instructions.description: Per drink, blend the rum, coconut creme and pineapple juice with 1-2 cups of ice.
Add more or less ice to achieve desired consistency.
Place the toasted coconut on a shallow plate.
Scoop the coconut creme from the 2nd can onto a another shallow plate. Roll the rim of the glass in the coconut creme and then lightly roll in toasted coconut.
Fill each glass with the blended Pina Colada, sit back and sip away the heat.

name: Ann Sheridan
description: Taken from the Stork Club Bar Book, the Ann Sheridan cocktail is named for the famous mid-20th century actress. It's mostly just a Daiquiri variation, but it also resembles the classic Daisy (the drink that birthed the Margarita) with its use of curaçao. According to Jeff "Beachbum" Berry, an even better rendition can be made with two ounces of rum, one ounce of curaçao, and one ounce of lime (pictured).

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a small, chilled cocktail glass and serve.

name: Paloma
description: Spanish for "dove," the Paloma is a Mexican favorite that is wonderful for the summer patio. Its refreshing taste is a wonderful example of sweet and tart flavors being combined with salt and powerful tequila. If unavailable, the grapefruit soda can be substituted with a combination of grapefruit juice and either club soda or sparkling water.

ingredients.name: Lime Wedge Or Wheel For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a Collins glass with ice and stir gently.
Garnish with a lime wedge or wheel and serve.

name: Mini Wapatui
description: Anyone that went to school in the midwest probably had a few of these at some point. They were a communal drink, each person brought a bottle of something to add to the mix. At frat parties they were made in garbage cans, and served in red Solo cups, but this is a mini version that serves two. The perfect drink for your next reunion.

ingredients.name: Bottles Juice, Something Fruity Works Best
Mixed Tropical Fruit, But Always Include Watermelon Balls
½ Bottle Of Any Dark Beer

instructions.description: Use the empty watermelon half as a punch bowl, mix everything together and let it sit for an hour or so before serving.

name: Greyhound
description: The Greyhound is a simple, two-ingredient cocktail with a tangy, citrusy flavor that is both refreshing and delicious. The origin of this tasty cocktail is rumored to date back to the 1930s at the Savoy Hotel, and the Greyhound recipe is included in Harry Craddock's Savoy Cocktail Book.

instructions.description: Pour ingredients into a highball glass over ice cubes.
Stir well, and serve.

name: Planter's Punch
description: The Planter's Punch recipe, like so many tiki drinks, depends a lot on the tastes of the bartender making it. The original can be traced back to the early 1900s (sometimes under the name Jamaican Rum Punch or Creole Punch), and has at times been as simple as rum, lime, sugar, and water, or as complicated as a mixture of dozens of tropical fruit juices—for better or worse.To differentiate it from other classic rum cocktails like the Daiquiri, though, we've gone with a more modern interpretation that falls somewhere in between the two extremes. This Planter's Punch recipe uses dark rum, pineapple, lime, and orange juices, and a splash of grenadine to make for a fantastic tropical drink. Be sure to use fresh juices if possible (at least for the lime and orange, since pineapple can be a pain unless you have a juicer), and a good, classic grenadine like Liber & Co. or Small Hand Foods, not the overly-syrupy Rose's.Planter's Punch, as its name implies, can also easily be made as a punch for a large group by multiplying this recipe by the number of servings you need.

ingredients.name: Lime Wheel, Pineapple Wedge, And/Or Mint Sprig For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a Highball glass over fresh ice.
Garnish as desired and serve.

name: Champagne Strawberry Jello Shots
description: Jello shots are a staple at college parties, but you can class things up with the addition of Champagne. These Champagne Strawberry Jello Shots are pretty enough to display at your New Year's Eve party or even a hangover brunch.Rather than using strawberry Jello, this recipe goes the fresh fruit route and begins with unflavored, powdered gelatin. From there, the recipe incorporates Champagne, ginger ale, water, sugar, and strawberries. Despite the extra ingredients, the recipe is very easy to follow, and doesn't stray far from the typical Jello-making process.So give it a whirl, and you can be drinking (well, eating) Champagne Strawberry Jello Shots at your next party.

ingredients.name: Tablespoons Or 3 Envelopes Of Unflavored Gelatin Powder

instructions.description: In a saucepan, sprinkle the gelatin evenly over the cold water and allow the gelatin to absorb the water for 2 minutes.
Bring the water with the gelatin powder to a boil over high heat while stirring until the gelatin is fully dissolved.
Remove from the heat, and transfer the gelatin mixture to a bowl, add the sugar, and stir until dissolved.
Stir in the champagne and ginger ale.
Refrigerate until thickened, but still partially liquid.
Fold in the strawberries.
Spoon into 7 to 10 individual molds.
The smaller the mold the firmer the jello will be, metal molds make firmer jello than glass molds.
Refrigerate until firm. To loosen from the mold, run a knife around the top of the jello and put it in a bath of warm water for 10–20 seconds.
Flip it over and shake it or give it a light pat to release.

name: White Dragon
description: The White Dragon is an easygoing riff on both the Margarita and the Tequila Sour. Starting with a base of Casa Dragones Blanco, this cocktail adds a healthy dose of Cointreau alongside fresh lemon juice and an egg white. The Cointreau and lemon lend that characteristic Margarita flair, while the egg white emulsifies the entire package, creating a smooth and silky drink. With its quaffable nature and dash of protein, the White Dragon is a welcome addition to your next brunch.

instructions.description: Add all the ingredients to a shaker, and shake without ice.
Fill with ice, then shake again until cold.
Strain into a coupe, twist an orange peel over the drink and serve.

name: Caipirinha
description: The Caipirinha is generally known as the national cocktail of Brazil, and it's certainly the most famous drink made with cachaça, a Brazilian sugar cane-based spirit that resembles rhum agricole. It's a fairly simple cocktail, sort of a South American analog of the Mint Julep. All that's involved is muddled lime, sugar, and cachaça, so it's a pretty powerful, spirit-forward drink even with the refreshing dose of citrusy sweetness. If you want to take the edge off (or if you're simply using a cheap cachaça), we recommend using crushed ice, as it melts faster.

instructions.description: Add the lime wedges and sugar or simple syrup to an Old-Fashioned glass and muddle.
Fill the glass with ice.
Add cachaça, stir gently, and serve.

name: Scorpion Bowl
description: The Scorpion is a classic tiki cocktail that uses plenty of fresh-squeezed citrus to make for a seriously refreshing sip any time of year. All you'll need is some white rum, brandy, orgeat syrup, orange juice, lemon juice, ice, and a blender to mix it all up. To garnish the Scorpion cocktail, you can use a slice or two of any citrus you'd like (orange or lemon are typical), a couple of good maraschino cherries, and a sprig of mint (clapped between your hands to release the essential oils) to really round out the aromas.This Scorpion recipe makes one serving, but it can easily be multiplied to serve in the classic Scorpion Bowl, which is a favorite at tiki bars around the world. The Scorpion Bowl typically has a smaller bowl in the center, into which you can pour some overproof rum and light it on fire for an extra-exotic presentation.

ingredients.name: Orange Slice, Maraschino Cherries, And Mint Sprig For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a blender with ice and blend for about 10 seconds.
Pour into a wine glass, Hurricane glass, tiki mug, or highball glass.
Garnish with orange wedge, maraschino cherries, and a sprig of clapped mint and serve.

name: Moscow Mule Popsicles
description: Moscow Mules are a perennial summertime favorite, but we figured they could cool you off even more efficiently in popsicle form. This recipe from Shutterbean makes 8 popsicles, and is sure to be a crowd-pleaser at your next barbecue or 4th of July shindig.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a pitcher or mixing glass.
Pour into popsicle molds and place in the freezer for 1 hour.
Add popsicle sticks to partially-frozen popsicles and return to the freezer for 12 hours.
Remove from the freezer and serve.

name: Fitzgerald
description: The Fitzgerald cocktail is a simple, refreshing gin cocktail that's a great way to ease people into gin drinks. The recipe comes from legendary bartender Dale DeGroff, back when he was working at the Rainbow Room in New York in the early 1990s.The Fitzgerald is basically a Gin Sour with a few dashes of bitters added, which make a surprisingly big difference. The bitters balance out the sour and sweet notes from the lemon and simple syrup, respectively, and give this drink a bit more complexity.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Strawberry Moscow Mule
description: The Strawberry Moscow Mule is a fun way to spruce up everyone's favorite ginger beer and vodka cocktail with some fresh summer fruit. This recipe from our friends at Beautiful Booze is a snap to make, and is guaranteed to be a new warm-weather favorite.

instructions.description: Muddle strawberries in the bottom of a Moscow Mule mug or other serving glass.
Add vodka and lime juice.
Add crushed ice.
Add ginger beer and stir gently.
Garnish with a fresh strawberry and serve.

name: Tequila Sunrise
description: The Tequila Sunrise is a 1970s-era cocktail comprised of tequila, grenadine, and orange juice. When served, the grenadine sinks to the bottom, creating a layered effect, which gives the drink its name.The Tequila Sunrise's origin story is attributed to Bobby Lozoff and Billy Rice, bartenders at the Trident in Sausalito, CA. The drink gained notoriety in 1972, when Mick Jagger and the Rolling Stones visited the bar and drank the cocktail. They enjoyed it so much, that they kept on drinking them, and their 1972 tour was affectionately dubbed the "Cocaine and Tequila Sunrise Tour." This helped to catapult the drink's status, with it soon becoming part of the marketing effort for Jose Cuervo, and even resulting in the Tequila Sunrise song on the Eagles' Desperado album, which debuted the following year.For decades, the Tequila Sunrise has been concocted with cheap orange juice and sickly sweet grenadine, and it eventually began to fall out of favor, as drinkers turned toward craft cocktails. But today, it can still be found on menus across the world. Fortunately, some enterprising bartenders have begun to make the drink with 100% agave tequila, fresh-squeezed orange juice, and real pomegranate grenadine. The difference is notable, and bridges the gap between the generally dark days of 1970s cocktailing and that of our modern era.So if you're making a Tequila Sunrise at home—which is a very easy thing to do—we suggest you follow suit. Because a well-made Tequila Sunrise featuring fresh ingredients is a respectable and Vitamin C-spiked addition to your next breakfast.

instructions.description: Pour tequila in a highball glass with ice, and top with orange juice.
Slowly add grenadine, which will sink to the bottom.
Garnish with an orange slice and cherry.

name: New Amsterdam Electrolyte
description: Just a simple, refreshing drink that would go nicely with a hot dog at your backyard barbecue.

instructions.description: Muddle the watermelon slices and combine all ingredients into a cocktail shaker. Add plenty of ice.
Shake vigorously for eight seconds.
Pour contents into a highball glass and garnish with a watermelon slice.

name: Corpse Reviver #2
description: The Corpse Reviver #2 is a fun name for a serious cocktail. It first appeared in Harry Craddock's "Savoy Cocktail Book" and features five ingredients: gin, Cointreau, Lillet Blanc, fresh lemon juice and absinthe. The first four ingredients are shaken with ice, while the absinthe is used to rinse the serving glass and is discarded before you strain the cocktail, so just a hint of absinthe is present in the finished drink.The recipe calls for a couple specifics here: namely Lillet Blanc and Cointreau. You can substitute Cocchi Americano for the Lillet to good effect, but Cointreau tends to fare better than other orange liqueurs, so we suggest sticking with it. If you can't find absinthe, a pastis (an anise-flavored spirit) like Herbsaint works nicely.Why's It Called a Corpse Reviver?The Corpse Reviver #2 is one of a whole cadre of variations, and it follows the Corpse Reviver #1, which features cognac, calvados, and sweet vermouth. These revivers were initially devised as hangover cures, hence the name. While the drinks probably won't make you feel any less like a corpse after a long night out, they may help to raise you from the dead. And the Corpse Reviver #2 certainly tastes better in the morning than a lot of other classic cocktails. Soft and a little sour, it goes great with brunch.

ingredients.name: Dash Of Absinthe Or Pastis, To Rinse

instructions.description: Add the absinthe to a chilled cocktail glass or coupe glass, swirl it around, and discard it.
Add the gin, Cointreau, Lillet Blanc, and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and
shake until well-chilled.
Strain into your absinthe-rinsed cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cherry, or nothing at all.

name: Gin and Tonic
description: The Gin and Tonic was originally conceived by the British East India Company as a way of getting its soldiers and merchants to consume quinine, the main ingredient in tonic water that is used to prevent and treat malaria. Gin, obviously, made that a little more appealing for the sailors of the day.The British Navy was always concerned about scurvy as well, so they needed a way to make sure their sailors consumed enough citrus. Their lime rations gave rise to a number of rum- and gin-based cocktails, eventually making their way into the Gin and Tonic. So, really, this started out as preventative medicine—kale smoothies be damned.

ingredients.name: Lime Wedge Or Wheel For Garnish

instructions.description: Add the gin and tonic water to a Highball glass or Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
Garnish with a lime wedge or wheel and serve.

name: Coconut Mojito
description: "This coconut mojito is made with fresh mint, lime and coconut rum. It's the type of drink that makes you feel like you are on the beach while sipping away." - Nutmeg Nanny

instructions.description: In a tall (12 ounce) glass add mint leaves, juice of half a lime and Truvia.
Using a wooden muddle muddle the mint into the bottom of the glass. This will release the mint flavor and help dissolve the Truvia. The mint will tear, this is totally normal.
Pour in coconut rum and stir to combine. Your Truvia should be dissolved at this point.
Fill the glass to the top with ice and pour in seltzer water. Serve with an extra wedge of lime and enjoy!

name: Maharaja
description: This cocktail is an ode to my love for the flavors and aromas of India, and to my deep adoration for cocktails that balance spice with sweet so both can sing. --Karen Hoskin

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake vigorously, and strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with a floating lime wheel and 3 Cardamom pods. Rim the glass with a combination of turbinado sugar, powdered cinnamon and nutmeg (or other favorite spices).

name: Strawberry Rose Gin Fizz
description: The Gin Fizz is a classic, and we'd be terrible bartenders if we weren't constantly trying to mess with classics. Rose water and strawberries make this Gin Fizz variation pink, fruity, and beautiful (as well as absolutely delicious).

ingredients.name: ½ Cup Club Soda (Or, To Taste)

instructions.description: First, wash and de-stem the strawberries. Next, dice the strawberries into small pieces, like 12 pieces from one berry. Tiny.
Sprinkle the sugar over the top of the strawberries. Let sit for 5 minutes. Then, mash the strawberries with a fork to release their juices.
Fill a cocktail shaker with ice, and then add the strawberry mixture, gin, rose water and a pinch of salt (just trust me). Shake, then divide between two glasses.
Top each glass off with club soda and squeeze a lime wedge into each glass.

name: Lambretta
description: A surprising cocktail with great balance and style. It hails from a restaurant called Aperitivo in Calabria Italy. Never visited the place but a friend introduced the drink to me.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients and strain over fresh ice into a stemmed glass, I used a white wine glass.
Cut a strip of lemon zest and break over the drink then rub the zest around the glass to spread the lemon oils.

name: Absolut Juice Shandy
description: Absolut Juice Pear & Elderflower was released in April 2020 as the latest addition to the Absolut Juice lineup. It's made with Absolut Vodka and 5 percent real fruit juice, offering the sweet and juicy taste of ripe pears and elderflower in every sip. So it's the perfect addition to springtime drinks like this shandy.The Absolut Juice Shandy combines the fruit-forward vodka with lemonade and hard sparkling cider. For the latter, choose your favorite brand—ideally something light and refreshing—and you'll have a drink perfect for sipping as the weather warms up.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a wine glass with ice.
Garnish with sliced fruit.

name: Bellini
description: The Bellini is a classic champagne cocktail made with sparkling wine (often Prosecco, since it's an Italian drink), peach puree, and optionally peach liqueur. It has long been a favorite at brunch, as it introduces some fresh, fruity flavors that pair fantastically with breakfast foods. While the Bellini has a reputation for being a bit of a girly drink, we think that's an old-fashioned idea—this is a cocktail that anyone can enjoy.Invented in 1945 at Harry's Bar in Venice, Italy, the Bellini was originally created to get rid of an excess of peaches bartender Giuseppe Cipriani had on hand. It gets its name from the Renaissance painter Giovanni Bellini, who is known for having brought rich, vivacious colors to the otherwise fairly muted style of the day—just like what this drink will bring to your brunch table.

instructions.description: Add peach puree to a mixing glass with no ice.
Add sparkling wine slowly, stirring gently so as not to lose the effervescence.
Strain into a champagne flute and serve.
Optionally, float the peach or raspberry liqueur on top.

name: Whiskey and Coke
description: A Whiskey and Coke is exactly what it sounds like: a simple two-ingredient cocktail comprised of whiskey and Coke. It's typically served in a rocks glass or Collins glass with ice.The drink is a popular call at bars, since you can get a Whiskey and Coke just about anywhere. It's also an easy cocktail to make at home. However, there's not one correct way to make the recipe, so that's where things can get interesting.Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey is a popular choice when making a Whiskey and Coke. The same goes for American bourbons and Canadian whiskies—a Bourbon and Coke or a specific call for Crown and Coke (featuring Crown Royal) are both mainstays at bars. Depending on the type of whiskey you use, the flavor of your cocktail will change slightly. Some whiskeys are sweeter, spicier or drier than other varieties, which means you can experiment to find exactly what you're looking for.Some people like their Whiskey and Cokes stronger than others, so playing with the ratios is another easy way to accommodate your preference. One part whiskey to three parts Coke is a pretty standard ratio, but feel free to dial the mixer up or down to adjust the strength and flavor.The Whiskey and Coke isn't a complicated drink, but with its mixture of spirit, soda, and a caffeine kick, it's got staying power and remains one of the most popular mixed drinks in the world.

instructions.description: Build over ice in a Collins glass or an Old-fashioned glass.
Serve.

name: Casino Royale
description: More than just a James Bond novel and movie, the Casino Royale is a vodka-spiked cocktail that's perfect for warm weather. Featuring elit Vodka, bittersweet Aperol and fresh grapefruit, it's an easy-drinking beverage that pairs nicely with sunny patios. And if you're entertaining a crowd, the below measurements can be multiplied to make a large batch. Just throw it all into a punch bowl, and you've got more time to interact with your guests.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice, and strain into a collins glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with an orange slice.

name: Orange Crush
description: The Orange Crush is a simple cocktail consisting of Reyka Vodka, fresh orange juice, and a sparkling topper. We prefer regular soda water, but a lemon-lime soda like Sprite also works nicely, if you prefer.Mix one up to start your day, when you're hosting brunch, or anytime you want a Vitamin C infusion. Plus vodka.

instructions.description: Build all ingredients in a highball glass.
Garnish with an orange slice.
Combine all ingredients In a cocktail shaker half-filled with ice cubes, and shake well.
Strain into a cocktail glass, and serve.

name: Absinthe Frappé
description: The Absinthe Frappé is a classic, refreshing absinthe drink that's great for cooling down on a hot summer day, and it makes for a more straightforward alternative to the traditional method of absinthe preparation with an ice-water drip. It packs a bit of a punch simply due to the high proof of most absinthes, but the crushed ice and water take the edge off of the strongest flavors. If you want a bit of effervescence, you can use soda water instead of still water—just make sure to add it after you shake.

ingredients.name: Oz Chilled Water Or Soda Water

instructions.description: Add all ingredients (except soda water if you're using it) to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into an absinthe glass filled with crushed ice.
If using soda water, top with soda.
Top with more crushed ice and serve with a straw.

name: Belvedere Spritz
description: The Belvedere Spritz takes a minimalist approach to mixing—combining equal parts Belvedere Vodka and Lillet Blanc with fresh garnishes and refreshing toppers. The result is a thirst-quenching cocktail perfect for sipping during the warmer months, and one that won't knock you over after you've had a couple.

instructions.description: Combine first four ingredients in a wine glass with ice.
Top with equal measures of sparkling water and tonic water.

name: Irish Coffee
description: The Irish Coffee is a perfect drink for when you need to wake up halfway through a long night, or kick yourself out of bed and fight off a hangover. It's an exceedingly simple cocktail, consisting of just Irish whiskey, coffee, a bit of brown sugar simple syrup, and some heavy cream (preferably homemade). If you're looking for whiskey recommendations, be sure to check out our collection of the best Irish whiskey under $50.The Irish Coffee is eponymously served in a mug called an "Irish Coffee Mug". The style of mug most commonly used is the version with a side handle, but our preference is the more aesthetically-pleasing Georgian Irish Coffee Mug (pictured) as championed by both Jeffrey Morgenthaler and San Francisco's Buena Vista Cafe.The Irish Coffee was, unsurprisingly, invented in Ireland in the 1940s. It came to America by way of the Buena Vista Cafe in the early 1950s, and has been associated with the City by the Bay ever since. For more of the story, check out our complete guide to the history of the Irish Coffee.

ingredients.name: Hot Black Coffee (Opt For A Higher Quality Coffee And Brew A Bit Stronger Than Usual)
Heavy Cream (Opt For A Higher Quality Heavy Cream

instructions.description: First, pre-warm an Irish coffee mug by pouring hot water into it and let sit for a few minutes.
Then, dry shake the cream for about 15s.
Then, empty the water from the mug, and add Irish whiskey, simple syrup, and the hot coffee. Leave a little space at the top for the cream.
Finally, top with the cream, pouring slowly so it floats on top.

name: Amalfi Spritz
description: A simple way to enhance your summer parties is with the liberal use of sparkling wines. Serve them on their own, if that's your style, but don't sleep on deploying bubbly into your mixed drinks. Case in point: the Amalfi Spritz, which combines easy-drinking Aperol with Prosecco, lime, and pineapple. It's the kind of drink that begs for a sunny patio, a pool, and maybe an umbrella. And considering its low-alcohol sensibilities, you can sip on this one all day long.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients into a wine glass with ice.
Garnish with a lime wheel.

name: Summer Gintonica
description: The easy-drinking Summer Gintonica is a simple riff on the classic Gin & Tonic. It starts with a base of Monkey 47, a unique gin that features 47 different botanicals. From there, fresh lemon juice provides an acidic kick while Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic adds a delicate floral note, plus some effervescence. Mix this up during summer and enjoy on your nearest patio.

instructions.description: Build ingredients in a wine glass over ice and top with tonic.
Garnish with blackberries, mint sprigs and a lemon twist.

name: Gimlet
description: The Gimlet is a classic three-ingredient gin cocktail that tastes great and is simple to make. It is essentially a Gin Sour, and the Gimlet closely resembles its rum-based cousin the Daiquiri.Interestingly enough, both the Gimlet and the Daiquiri were supposedly employed by the British Navy to ensure that sailors got their daily rations of citrus, thereby keeping them safe from scurvy. (Originally, they just gave the sailors limes, but they couldn't actually get them to eat or drink the limes until booze was added to the rations).Thanks in part to the modern cocktail renaissance, bartenders have reinvented the Gimlet from its early days as a functional, medicinal drink on ships. Today it's a modern favorite served all over the world and counted among the drinking public's favorite gin cocktails, right up there with other classics like the Martini and Negroni.What's in a Gimlet cocktail?The classic Gimlet had only two ingredients—gin and lime juice. The early recipe from The Savoy Cocktail Book by Harry Craddock specifically calls for Plymouth Gin. The same Gimlet recipe also calls for Rose's lime juice (formally called Rose's Lime Cordial)—a sweetened and bottled commercial lime juice. Because Rose's is a sweetened product, no additional sugar is necessary when using this recipe.Today, however, Gimlets are commonly made using a broad range of gins, fresh lime juice (because fresh-squeezed juices have the best flavors), and a bit of simple syrup. Moving away from the bottled lime juice dials back the sweetness and dials up the refreshment, making the Gimlet more suitable for modern palates.If you're not a fan of juniper or other botanicals in your alcohol, then the Vodka Gimlet may be more your speed. It is a popular alternative that's just as easy to make: substitutes vodka, a more neutral spirit, in lieu of the gin.How to Make a Gimlet CocktailTo make a Gin Gimlet, start by adding two ounces gin, a half ounce lime juice, and a half ounce simple syrup into a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake vigorously until it's cold, then strain into a cocktail glass (aka a Martini glass). Alternatively, you can strain the mixture into a coupe glass for a softer and more modern presentation. Pro tip—pre-chill your glassware for best results. Finally, garnish with a lime wheel or a twist, and serve.

instructions.description: Add the gin, lime juice, and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lime wheel or twist.

name: Highball
description: The Highball, while technically referring to an entire family of drinks made with a spirit and a non-alcoholic mixer served in a tall glass with ice, is a name often given to a simple combination of whiskey and soda water. This refreshing drink first became popular in the UK in the late 19th or early 20th century, and is often referred to as a Scotch and Soda, although you can make it with any whiskey you please. Add a lemon twist or lemon wedge for a touch of zesty citrus, and you're done—the Highball is just as easy to make as it is to drink.

ingredients.name: Lemon Wedge Or Twist For Garnish

instructions.description: Add scotch to a Highball glass filled with ice.
Fill with soda water.
Garnish with a lemon wedge or twist and serve.
Combine ingredients in a shaker half filled with ice. Shake well, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a stick of cinnamon, and serve.

name: Dragonfruit Mule
description: The Dragonfruit Mule is an attractive, cooling cocktail that hails from The Continental in Miami. But it's an easy drink to make at home, should you be so inclined. First, you'll need to score some dragonfruit puree—which is relatively easy to find online. The bright, exotic fruit is popular in Central America and Southeast Asia, and has a mildly sweet flavor. Paired with vodka, lime, and ginger, the result is an easy-drinking cocktail that's light, refreshing, and everything you want on a hot day.

instructions.description: Add the Dragonfruit purée and lime juice to an ice-filled collins glass.
Top with vodka and ginger beer, then stir and serve.

name: Pineapple Mint Mojito
description: Pineapple mint is a great variety of mint to use in tropical cocktails, and this one might be its finest application. You can find it at specialty food stores or, if you're the gardening type, try growing your own!

instructions.description: Lightly muddle lime, pineapple mint leaves, and simple syrup in sugar-rimmed Collins glass, and then fill with ice.
In a cocktail shaker, briefly shake rum and pineapple juice with ice and strain into glass, then top with a splash of club soda.
Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

name: Pineapple Upside-Down Cake Cocktail
description: The Pineapple Upside-Down Cake cocktail is a fun riff on the delicious dessert. It features vanilla vodka, pineapple juice and grenadine, plus a maraschino cherry garnish. The vanilla vodka acts as the cake in this recipe, while the pineapple juice plays the role of the fruit. Grenadine, which is sunk to the bottom of the cocktail glass, creates the layered effect, with its bright-red color sitting below the pale yellow top.The Pineapple Upside-Down Cake drink is sweet, fruity, and easy to make. If you want to liven up the cocktail, try using fresh pineapple juice. Otherwise, Dole pineapple juice or another canned or bottled variety works just fine. To make the drink, add the vanilla vodka and pineapple juice a shaker with ice, shake until it's chilled, then strain the liquid into a cocktail glass. The last step is to slowly add the grenadine—it will sink to the bottom of the glass, which creates the layered effect you see in the photo.If you want a shooter version of the Pineapple Upside-Down Cake, that can be arranged. The Pineapple Upside-Down Cake Shot is just as easy to make as the cocktail, but the recipe is dialed back slightly to create less volume, so the contents fit neatly into a shot glass.

instructions.description: Add the vanilla vodka and pineapple juice a shaker half-filled with ice, and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into cocktail glass.
Slowly add the grenadine, so it sinks to the bottom of the glass and creates a layered effect.
Garnish with a skewered pineapple wedge and maraschino cherry.

name: Refresher Cocktail
description: If you need to rejuvenate yourself, or just need a break from booze, try this refreshing... Refresher. It comes from JW Marriott San Antonio Hill Country Resort & Spa, and it's combining a couple of fresh juices with mint, agave, and sparkling water. Drink one on site, or try making one at home then next time you're craving a tasty and invigorating mocktail.

instructions.description: Muddle lime and mint in a shaker. Add liquid ingredients, and shake with ice.
Strain into a Collins glass.
Top with sparkling water, and garnish with lime and mint.

name: Apple Martini
description: The Apple Martini (or Appletini) is a popular cocktail that, despite its reputation as a punchline, can actually be pretty fun in the right circumstances. There are many variations of the Apple Martini recipe, with the most basic formula simply featuring two ingredients: vodka and sour apple schnapps. But this recipe adds apple juice to the equation, which amps up the apple flavor and tames the sweet, artificially flavored schnapps.The Apple Martini falls into a weird gray area between shaking and stirring. It has fruit juice, so by the general rule it should be shaken—but because it's apple juice, and that doesn't work as well when it gets frothy, this drink can also be stirred.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled (or, for a less frothy drink, stir in a mixing glass).
Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
Garnish with an apple slice and serve.

name: Sazerac
description: The Sazerac is a classic New Orleans cocktail, and the official cocktail of New Orleans. It is recognized as one of the oldest cocktails, and in some circles it's arguably recognized as America's first cocktail.What's in a Sazerac cocktail?The original Sazerac recipe likely used cognac—a French brandy—as its base spirit. This cognac was called Sazerac de Forge et Fils, and is also where the cocktail derives its name. The cognac served as the main ingredient, and was mixed with Peychaud's bitters, absinthe or anise liqueur, and a sugar cube. This drink is typically garnished with a lemon peel spritzed over the top of the drink to release its oils, lending rich aromatics with each sip.In the ensuring years, the Sazerac recipe was modified to use rye whiskey, an occurrence widely attributed to a cognac shortage resulting from the European wine grape epidemic in the late 1800s. Since rye was plentiful and readily available in America, it assumed the mantle. Rye's trademark spice notes held up well to the rest of the Sazerac's ingredients, making rye a natural fit, and the recipe modification stuck.This combination would prove to be timeless—the Sazerac is a beloved classic that can be found at bars all over the world, alongside other classic whiskey cocktails like the Old-Fashioned and the Manhattan. The Sazerac has cemented its reputation as one of the most important drinks in American history.This modification to the recipe has carried over into modern times, with the rye whiskey version of the Sazerac being widely accepted today as the classic Sazerac recipe.The history of the SazeracThe invention of the Sazerac is often credited to Antoine Peychaud, a Creole immigrant and the owner of an apothecary in New Orleans in the 1830s, who came up with a liquid mixture of cognac, absinthe, sugar, and a tonic he created that later became known as his eponymous Peychaud's bitters. The drink was a hit.Back then, the Sazerac was served regularly in bars and saloons in the French Quarter, and it became the drink of choice at the Sazerac Coffee House. Eventually, it spread across the city and beyond, making its way to both shores and many places between.As lovely as that story sounds, and as widely accepted and retold as it is, it turns out the above narrative may be false. Hey, cocktails are often soaked in rumor and innuendo. Nevertheless, it makes for a fun read while you sip on a drink.What is definitely true is that the Sazerac has continued to shine over the years—and the modern cocktail renaissance has reintroduced it to many new drinkers, as the recipe finds itself on an endless array of cocktail menus around the world. In 2008, the Sazerac was recognized as the official cocktail of New Orleans, a city that still serves many fine examples of the drink.How to make a Sazerac cocktailThe Sazerac is a stirred drink that is traditionally served without ice. Start by adding a small rinse of absinthe or Herbsaint to an empty Old-Fashioned glass (aka rocks glass) until the inside of the glass is generously coated. Dump out the excess.Then add the rye whiskey (or cognac if you're feeling old-school) to a separate mixing glass with a few dashes of Peychaud's bitters, simple syrup, and ice. You can use a muddled sugar cube, but simple syrup creates a silkier texture without any gritty bits. Stir until well-chilled, and strain into that absinthe-rinsed Old-Fashioned glass. All that's left to do now is garnish your drink with a lemon twist.Popular whiskeys for a Sazerac cocktailThese days, rye whiskey is the spirit of choice for most Sazeracs. Any quality rye with bold flavor notes will work nicely, so feel free to use your favorite. We like a rye with a little heft to it, preferably something closer to 90 or 100 proof, but feel free to experiment.The Sazerac Company makes a great rye whiskey—Sazerac Rye Whiskey—that is a popular choice for Sazeracs, though it's not affiliated with the origin story of the Sazerac cocktail. We like Rittenhouse Rye, a bonded rye whiskey coming in at 100 proof, which adds a little extra stiffness against the backdrop of bitters and absinthe. Wild Turkey 101 will also treat you right.

ingredients.name: Ounce Simple Syrup (One Part Sugar, One Part Water)

instructions.description: Add the absinthe (or Herbsaint) to an Old-Fashioned glass and swirl to coat the inside, discarding the excess. Fill the glass with crushed ice to chill and set aside.
Add the rye, simple syrup, and Peychaud's bitters to a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled.
Discard the ice from your prepared glass, and strain your cocktail into it.
Express a lemon peel over the top of the drink, and drop it in to garnish.

name: Gin Fizz
description: The Gin Fizz is a classic gin cocktail made with simple syrup, lemon juice, soda water, and, optionally, egg white. It's probably the most famous fizz recipe, a category of drinks that are typically made with soda (hence the name), citrus, and sometimes egg white for texture (its cousin, the Ramos Gin Fizz, is another favorite). It's tart, rich, and has just a bit of bubbles, making it a crowd-pleaser for more than a century.The first printed recipe for the Gin Fizz (or any fizz, as far as we know) appeared in the 1887 edition of Jerry Thomas' seminal Bartender's Guide. It was popular throughout much of the 20th century, and has long been associated with the city of New Orleans.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except soda water to an empty cocktail shaker and shake for 30 seconds or so.
Add ice to the cocktail shaker and shake vigorously until chilled.
Add the soda water to a chilled Highball glass.
Double-strain into the glass and serve.
(Optional) Add 2 or 3 dashes of Angostura bitters to the egg-white foam on top.

name: Kahlúa and Cream
description: The Kahlúa and Cream is a simple, low-alcohol cocktail consisting of, well, Kahlúa and cream! It's a sweet, decadent after-dinner drink that can really stand on its own as a dessert, and it's great for fans of the White Russian who don't feel like getting quite as tipsy. It couldn't be easier to make, and you'll be happy you did.

instructions.description: Add Kahlúa to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice.
Float the cream on top and serve with a stir stick or straw.

name: Jungle Juice
description: Jungle Juice is a popular party drink that is often found at college parties and other festive gatherings. Rather than following one traditional recipe, Jungle Juice is a combination of spirits and juices, usually with a high alcohol content, that is made in large batches to serve a crowd.Jungle Juice is frequently served via a large container such as a punch bowl, a glass beverage dispenser with a spigot, a large pitcher, a cooler, or sometimes even a trashcan that's (hopefully) been fitted with a liner.What's in Jungle Juice?Jungle Juice doesn't have the best reputation. It's basically the opposite of a "craft" cocktail, and most recipes attempt to mask the taste of the hard alcohol with lots of sugary mixers.If your next party calls for Jungle Juice, try mixing up the recipe below. It features vodka, white rum, lemonade, fruit punch, and fruit juice for a result that's sweet and easy-drinking, but still strong.Other recipes may use different spirits such as gin or whiskey, other liqueurs such as triple sec or peach schnapps, and other mixers such as lemon juice, lime juice, lemon lime soda, Hawaiian Punch and soda water. Some recipes will also include additional ingredients or garnishes such as orange slices or lemon slices, strawberries, cherries and mint leaves.As you can see, there are no strict rules when making Jungle Juice. The basic premise is to throw a lot of ingredients into a large container, give it a quick stir and call it a day. Why is it called Jungle Juice, and who invented it?It would be easy to believe that this all-American drink was concocted by some ingenious college kid eager for fast intoxication at parties and desiring to make the taste of hard alcohol more palatable. But no.It's more likely that Jungle juice was "invented" by the US Army. It is believed that American soldiers in the jungle during World War II would combine available ingredients to ferment and flavor their beverages. They added what was available, relying on various juices, mixers and other ingredients they had on hand.According to Punch!, the first use of the term occurred in the October 25, 1945 issue of the New Yorker, where "jungle juice" was defined as "a name loosely applied to any of the spirituous beverages that were concocted by American soldiers in the Southwest Pacific."So there you have it.Will Jungle Juice get me drunk?Whether or not Jungle Juice will get you drunk will depend on the ingredients and their proportions, as well as your individual alcohol tolerance. The base spirits are typically 40% ABV or higher, ensuring that your Jungle Juice starts at full-proof before mixers are added. If you want to make your punch with less alcohol, dial back the booze.The inclusion of orange juice, pineapple juice and various other mixers is intended to mask the hard liquor, thus making the drink taste better. It's plausible to think that if a drink tastes better, more of the drink would be consumed—and one thing's for sure, drinking enough of these will certainly get you tipsy, likely leading to a rough morning.Note that some people choose to use grain spirits like Everclear in their Jungle Juice. Considering that Everclear is an incredibly potent 95% ABV, we suggest sticking to vodka or other 40% ABV spirits. Either way, remember to pace yourself.

instructions.description: Add all the ingredients into a large container.
Give it all a quick stir, and garnish with sliced fruit.
In an old fashioned glass filled with ice, add the Vodka, followed by the Pineapple juice, and last, the 7-Up. Stir and serve.

name: Naked Lady
description: Despite the name, the Naked Lady cocktail is actually somewhat classy, and an inexpensive Valentine’s date.It’s an aperitif with elements of the aromatic (vermouth), the sweet (grenadine, apricot brandy) and the sour (lemon juice). The result is a well-balanced cocktail with a name that’s sure to up your street cred, like when you tell your friends about your evening at home with five, maybe six naked ladies.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients until very cold, and double strain that baby into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with the lemon peel, and serve.

name: Caribou Lou
description: The Caribou Lou is a simple, rum- and pineapple-based cocktail that was popularized by Tech-N9ne's 2006 single "Caribou Lou." The lyrics outline the recipe ("151 rum / Pineapple juice and Malibu / Caribou get them all numb"), and while it's not entirely clear where the drink gets its name, it nonetheless became popular seemingly overnight.The most common overproof rum to use in the Caribou Lou is Bacardi 151, but you can use any brand. The same goes for Malibu Rum, which, even though it's mentioned in the song, isn't all that great. Cruzan Coconut Rum or even Parrot Bay Coconut Rum are better options if you've got 'em.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a highball glass with ice and stir.

name: Witch's Hat
description: The Witch's Hat cocktail is a fun, spooky drink that'll keep your Halloween party guests happy all season long. Made with black vodka (a novelty vodka with coloring added, but if you can't find it at the store you can either infuse regular vodka with raspberries or simply add food coloring), Chambord raspberry liqueur, and dark cherry juice, as well as a decadent rim of crushed chocolate wafers, this cocktail certainly looks like an upside-down witch's hat—and it's a great addition to any Halloween menu.

instructions.description: Run a lime or lemon wedge around the rim of a chilled Martini glass, then dip the rim in crushed chocolate wafers to coat it.
Add black vodka, Chambord, and cherry juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into the Martini glass and serve.

name: Italiano Mule
description: This Italian twist on the classic Moscow Mule comes from Chef Giuliano Matarese. Known for his time on Chopped and Beat Bobby Flay, as well as his work with restaurants like Arte Café in NYC and Mille Lire in Dallas, Chef Matarese's Italiano Mule calls for limoncello, Sicilian marmalade, and basil in addition to the traditional vodka and ginger beer.Shake it all up, and you get a refreshing cocktail that will satisfy your Moscow Mule craving while providing a rich and lemony kick.

instructions.description: Combine vodka, limoncello, lime juice, marmalade, and basil in a shaker with ice.
Shake well, then strain into a mule mug over fresh ice.
Top with ginger beer and garnish with the rosemary sprig and lemon slice.

name: Blood Sucker
description: The Blood Sucker cocktail is a fun Halloween drink that's made to look like it's dripping with gore—but don't worry, it's just berry puree! The base recipe is simple, calling for orange-flavored rum (spiced rum or regular white rum works fine too), Cointreau, and pineapple juice, but the real fun comes with the addition of raspberry or strawberry puree. To get the right effect, stick a drinking straw into the puree, then place your finger over the opening and dribble it down the inside edges of the drink. The Blood Sucker will have you growing fangs in no time...

instructions.description: Add rum, Cointreau, and pineapple juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice.
Drip raspberry or strawberry puree along the inside edge of the glass (using a drinking straw), where it will form blood-like blobs, and serve without stirring.

name: Boulevardier
description: The Boulevardier is a classic variation on the Negroni. While the Negroni is composed of gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth, the Boulevardier subs in bourbon as its base spirit.The Boulevardier first appeared in bartender Harry McElhone's 1927 bar guide, Barflies and Cocktails. At the time, the American barman was slinging drinks in Paris at Harry's New York Bar due to a dark period of American history called Prohibition. That's where he met Erskine Gwynne, the creator of this drink, who edited a magazine called... The Boulevardier. Some Boulevardier recipes call for equal measures of each ingredient, while others kick things up a notch by doubling the whiskey. Our preferred recipe, though, mirrors Gwynne's, and uses 1.5 ounces of bourbon alongside one ounce each of Campari and sweet vermouth. So play around a bit to see what you like best. Either way, we recommend using a good sweet vermouth, like Carpano Antica or Dolin Rouge—something with enough heft to stand up alongside the strong whiskey and bitter Campari.If you like the Boulevardier, you'll want to try another Negroni variation called the Old Pal. That one also employs whiskey, but in this case, it calls for rye. And instead of sweet vermouth, it features the dry variety.

instructions.description: If serving on the rocks:
Add all ingredients to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Garnish with an orange twist.
If serving up:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist.

name: Venceremos
description: The Venceremos cocktail (Spanish for "we shall overcome") was bartender Gn Chan's winning recipe at the 2016 Bacardi Legacy cocktail competition. It's a variation on the Piña Colada, but with a Taiwanese twist: cucumber and sesame oil. The Venceremos is refreshing, and features an artful use of vegetal and savory notes to round out what is traditionally a sweet and fruity drink.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a Hurricane or Old-Fashioned glass over a single, large ice cube.
Garnish with pineapple leaf and serve.

name: Gin Sour
description: The Gin Sour is a bit of a long-forgotten recipe, which seems a little ridiculous considering the popularity of its cousins, like the Whiskey Sour and Pisco Sour. But back in the day, this recipe was nearly as much of an icon.Like all sours, the Gin Sour follows a simple formula: gin, simple syrup, and lemon juice (though if you use lime juice, you're basically making a Gimlet). You should always use fresh-squeezed lemon juice, as the bottled stuff doesn't taste nearly as good, and using simply syrup instead of sugar eliminated the issue of undissolved granules in the bottom of your glass.You're welcome to add an egg white if you want a frothier, creamier drink, just make sure you do a dry shake (a hard shake without ice to emulsify the egg) at the start of the recipe.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except garnish to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Flash
description: One surefire way to increase your fruit consumption is by adding some fruit to your cocktails. Case in point: the Flash, a refreshing, vitamin-packed drink from San Francisco's The Treasury that merges Aviation Gin with fresh kiwi, cucumber, and lemon. Order one of these on site, and feel good about your decision. Or try making the Flash at home. Composed of just five readily-available ingredients, it's an easy DIY project with a built-in reward.

instructions.description: In a shaker, muddle kiwi and cucumber with lemon juice.
Add gin, simple syrup, and ice. Shake well to combine and chill.
Fine-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a thin slice of kiwi.

name: Flying Goose
description: The Flying Goose is a simple cocktail composed of just three ingredients: vodka, pineapple juice, and melon liqueur. For the latter, you can reach for Midori, a melon liqueur from Japan that's easy to find in stores. The drink is fruity and a bit sweet, and can be served on the rocks or strained and served as a shot.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice, stir gently, and serve.
Alternatively, add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker half-filled with ice cubes.
Shake until chilled and strain into shot glasses.

name: Christmas Bourbon Punch
description: This festive Christmas Bourbon Punch is easy to prepare and provides a nice centerpiece to any holiday party. With bourbon, fresh juices, and ginger ale, it goes down smoothly. But the real star of the show is the ice ring, which not only looks great, but also keeps your punch cold without over-diluting it.

ingredients.name: 1-1.5 Cups Of Bourbon Depending On How Strong You Want It

instructions.description: To make ice ring: add 4 oranges and rosemary stalks to ice ring mold. Fill with water and freeze overnight.
Pour liquid ingredients into the punch bowl, and stir.
Carefully add ice ring.
Garnish with sliced oranges and rosemary stalks.

name: Sloe Gin & Tonic
description: A Sloe Gin and Tonic is very similar to the traditional G&T, but it includes sloe gin, which is a gin flavored with sloe berries.
