The result is a cocktail that's more tart and colorful than the original, while still providing the refreshment you expect from your Gin and Tonics. Follow the recipe below to make one for yourself.

instructions.description: Pour ingredients into an ice-filled collins glass.
Garnish with a lime, and serve.

name: Remember the Maine
description: The Remember the Maine is a classic rye cocktail, and a bit of a play on the Manhattan recipe. The introduction of Cherry Heering and the dash of absinthe adds a lovely, layered complexity with just a touch of sweetness.The Remember the Maine recipe first appeared in The Gentleman’s Companion by Charles H. Baker, Jr., in 1939. As Baker wrote: "REMEMBER the MAINE, a Hazy Memory of a Night in Havana during the Unpleasantnesses of 1933, when Each Swallow Was Punctuated with Bombs Going off on the Prado, or the Sound of 3″ Shells Being Fired at the Hotel NACIONAL, then Haven for Certain Anti-Revolutionary Officers."The cocktail's name—Remember the Maine—is a reference to the USS Maine, which kicked off the Spanish-American War after being sunk in the waters around Cuba in 1898.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until chilled, about 20-30 seconds.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass or into an Old-Fashioned glass with ice.
Garnish with the cherry.

name: Fog Cutter
description: The Fog Cutter was one of the staple cocktails of the post prohibition tiki bar period. It was first published in 1947 by Vic Bergeron of the famous Trader Vic's. The original recipe and method for serving this cocktail vary based on your source (there were some competing claims with rival Don the Beachcomber about its origins, as well as dozens of copycat bars during the era), but its boozy nature and place in cocktail culture lore is never up for debate.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients and strain into a collins glass over shaved ice.
Top with a barspoon of sweet sherry and serve.

name: Cherry Smash
description: Summer is upon us, temperatures are heating up, and those are two easy ways to justify clutching a cold drink in your hand from now until pool season comes to a close. Cognac is often considered a cool weather spirit, something you might sip fireside in your smoking jacket. But don't neglect it as a summertime cocktail ingredient.Rémy Martin 1738 is a highly mixable cognac that you can add freely to your drinks. Its easygoing but flavorful nature stands up well in icy cocktails containing citrus and other fruits, so don't be shy. Take the Cherry Smash you see here, which combines cognac with Cointreau, lemon, and cherries. Whether you're sipping one on your patio, lounging by the pool, or hanging out at some kind of glass-friendly beach, it won't steer you wrong.

instructions.description: Muddle cherries in simple syrup in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.
Add remaining ingredients, and shake with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, and garnish with a lemon peel and cherry.

name: Irish Gold Rush
description: You know the Gold Rush, that cocktail composed of bourbon, lemon juice, and honey. Well, this is the Irish Gold Rush—the only difference being that it begins with a base of Irish whiskey. From there, it gets the same lemon and honey treatment, so it's an easy drink to make, whether you're celebrating St. Patrick's Day or just want to use that new bottle of Irish whiskey sitting on your bar.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker.
Shake until well chilled, about 10 seconds.
Strain into an ice-filled double old-fashioned glass over fresh ice, and garnish with a lemon peel.

name: Vesper "Bond" Martini
description: The Vesper is a spirit-forward cocktail that is the first Martini James Bond ordered in Casino Royale. It's distinctive in that it includes both gin and vodka, in addition to the French aperitif, Lillet Blanc, which takes the place of dry vermouth.The Vesper is an original recipe from author Ian Fleming. In the book, and subsequent movie, Bond orders the drink with explicit instructions: "Three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it’s ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon peel."Now, we hate to argue with Fleming (and Bond), but drinks composed of all spirits are traditionally stirred. It's well-known that Bond likes his Martinis shaken, but we suggest stirring the Vesper to keep its texture and appearance silky smooth.

instructions.description: Add the gin, vodka and Lillet Blanc into a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until very cold.
Strain into a cocktail glass or a coupe.
Garnish with a large, thin twist of lemon.

name: Jägerbomb
description: The Jägerbomb (or Jäger Bomb) has something of a bad reputation, and perhaps for good reason—it's almost always associated with crazy, regrettable nights out at a club, and the huge amount of caffeine in Red Bull mixed with the alcohol in Jägermeister can actually be quite dangerous if consumed in large quantities. That said, this is a hugely popular drink, and it will certainly get you in the mood for a party, so we'll just say: please drink responsibly!

instructions.description: Fill an Old-Fashioned glass 2/3 full with Red Bull.
Serve with a shot glass full of Jägermeister.
Drop the shot of Jägermeister into the Red Bull, and knock the whole thing back in one go.
Try to maintain your dignity.

name: Negroni Sbagliato
description: The Negroni Sbagliato can be traced back to Milan's Bar Basso, when a bartender mistakenly added sparkling wine to a Negroni in place of gin.The name itself translates to “wrong Negroni,” but the drink was so good, that it took hold and has stuck around ever since. Similar to the also-bubbly Americano, which opts for sparkling water instead of wine, the Negroni Sbagliato is a light and refreshing cocktail that pairs perfectly with sunny afternoons.

instructions.description: Add Campari and sweet vermouth to an ice-filled rocks glass or wine glass.
Top with sparkling wine, and garnish with an orange peel.

name: Irish Whiskey Mai Tai
description: You know the Mai Tai, that classic combination of rum, lime, orange curacao, and simple syrup. Well, this is the Irish Whiskey Mai Tai from Monkey King, an Asian fusion restaurant and bar in San Diego. They're riffing on the classic by switching up the base spirit, making some DIY orgeat from cashews (instead of the typical almonds), subbing dry curacao for orange, and tossing in some sarsaparilla bitters.The result is a cocktail that's reminiscent of the classic Mai Tai but different enough to make you take notice. If you're in the neighborhood, stop in for a drink. Otherwise, you can try mixing up your own version using the recipe below.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, and garnish with a mint sprig.

name: Tempting Tigress
description: Created by The Nomad Lounge in Disney's Animal Kingdom Park, the Tempting Tigress is made with Russell’s Reserve 10 Year Old Bourbon, St. Elizabeth’s Allspice Dram, tamarind syrup and lime juice, and comes served on ice in a rocks glass with a slice of lemon.Intended for fans of The Old-Fashioned cocktail, the Tempting Tigress is part of Disney's efforts to serve quality cocktails to adult patrons of select theme parks.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice.
Stir well, strain into an old-fashioned glass over a large ice cube (use several smaller ice cubes if a large cube is not available).
Garnish with a lemon twist.

name: Bicicletta
description: The Bicicletta is a simple and refreshing cocktail that riffs on the classic Americano and combines Campari with white wine and sparkling water. It's a popular drink in its birthplace of Italy, but with just three readily-available ingredients, the Bicicletta can easily be enjoyed at home.

instructions.description: Combine Campari and white wine in a glass with ice.
Top with soda, and garnish with an orange wedge.

name: Sacred Cenote
description: Created by SF cocktail maestro Saul Ranella out of Hog Island Oyster Company, this is an incredible drink that highlights the versatility of both amaro and mezcal. Bright, funky and beautifully balanced, this one gets top marks.

ingredients.name: Mint Leaves And Sprig For Garnish

instructions.description: Shake mint, mezcal, amaro, honey syrup, and lime juice in a shaker.
Double strain it into a cognac glass.
Garnish with lime wheels on the side of the glass.
Add some ice and top with soda water.
Garnish with a sprig of mint and three dashes of bitters.
*To make the honey syrup, warm two parts honey and one part water in a pan.

name: Strawberry Kiss
description: The Strawberry Kiss is an easy-drinking, crowd-pleasing cocktail that combines vodka, strawberries, and basil with lemon and sugar. All that is topped with some sparkling wine, which adds effervescence and tames the sweetness.

instructions.description: Muddle strawberries in a shaker, then add remaining ingredients (minus sparkling wine) and shake with ice.
Double strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass, and top with sparkling wine.

name: Between The Sheets
description: Between the Sheets is a classic cocktail that riffs on the Sidecar recipe, adding rum to the combination of cognac, orange liqueur, and lemon juice. Rumored to have been invented in Paris in the 1930s, the Between the Sheets cocktail is spirit-forward, with a citrusy-sour flavor profile. It's shaken and served up in a cocktail class or a coupe glass, per your preference.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients well in a shaker half-filled with ice cubes.
Strain into a coupe glass, garnish with a lemon twist, and serve.

name: Cinnamon Toast Crunch Shot
description: If you're a fan of the cereal Cinnamon Toast Crunch, and you just happen to fancy the same flavor in a libation, then this Cinnamon Toast Crunch recipe is for you. It's fun, sweet, and spicy, so it's a perfect choice for parties, happy hours and other events where shots aren't out of place.Rumchata and FireballBelieve it or not, the Cinnamon Toast Crunch shot is a simple combination of just two ingredients: Rumchata and Fireball whiskey. When mixed together, the duo has a flavor that is very similar to Cinnamon Toast Crunch cereal, and some fans of this drink have experienced feelings of deja-vu while waxing nostalgic about their childhood.You can shake the Cinnamon Toast Crunch Shot with ice and strain it into a couple shot glasses, knocking the drink back quickly in one go, or you can pour the drink into a rocks glass or cocktail glass, if you want to enjoy it more slowly. Either way, try accenting the drink with a cinnamon sugar rim for a little extra flavor with each sip.Fireball and RumchataFireball is a 33% ABV cinnamon whiskey that combines Canadian whisky, cinnamon flavoring and sweeteners. It is the best-selling cinnamon flavored whiskey and among the best-selling whiskeys in the United States, by volume. Rumchata is a 13.75% ABV cream liqueur made from rum, dairy cream, cinnamon, vanilla, sugar, and other flavorings. It's the second best-selling cream liqueur after Bailey's, and the name is a play on horchata, the traditional Mexican rice drink. Put them together in equal parts, give it all a shake in a cocktail shaker, and you get this fun concoction.If you make the Cinnamon Toast Crunch cocktail and think it needs a bit more vanilla flavor to mirror the cereal, try adding a touch of vanilla vodka to the recipe alongside that Rumchata and Fireball. You can add it in the same proportions as the other ingredients, and this will boost the alcohol content while also lending more of that vanilla sweetness you crave.To Each Their OwnWe don't quite get the allure of the Cinnamon Toast Crunch drink ourselves. When we crave Cinnamon Toast Crunch we eat a bowl of cereal, and when we crave booze we drink booze—but this mixed drink certainly seems to enjoy some popularity. So hey, to each their own.

instructions.description: Dip a shot glass (or an Old-Fashioned glass) into a cinnamon sugar mixture to rim the glass (optional).
Add Rumchata and Fireball into a shaker with ice, and shake well.
Strain into shot glasses (alternatively, strain into an Old-fashioned glass over ice).
Lightly grate some cinnamon over the top.
If serving as a shot, serve as-is.
If serving on-the-rocks, garnish with a cinnamon stick (optional) and serve.

name: Daiquiri
description: The Daiquiri is named for a small village in Cuba where it was invented in the early 20th century, but similar drinks have existed for hundreds of years.The combination of rum, citrus, and sugar dates back to the early years of European colonization of the Caribbean, and was used by the British Navy to combat scurvy (and keep their sailors happy at the same time).The classic Daiquiri was a favorite of Ernest Hemingway, and more recently the late, great cocktail legend Sasha Petraske. For more, check out our full history of the Daiquiri.

instructions.description: Add the rum, lime juice and simple syrup into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.
Double-strain into a chilled cocktail glass and serve.

name: Kamikaze
description: This Kamikaze drink recipe can be served either in a cocktail glass or as a shot. It's more or less like a Margarita made with vodka instead of tequila, and if you want to class it up a bit we recommend using Cointreau instead of a standard triple sec. And if you use citrus vodka and a splash of cranberry juice, you've got yourself a Cosmopolitan!By some accounts (notably that of cocktail historian Dave Wondrich), the Kamikaze shot was the original shooter. According to his research, it was invented in 1976, making it one of the true "disco cocktails" of that oh-so-maligned era. Compared to some of its contemporaries, though, the Kamikaze is a downright sophisticated drink, and it's certainly salvageable if you know what you're doing.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, or two shot glasses.

name: Mezcal Mule
description: The Mezcal Mule is a simple Moscow Mule variation that differs from the original only by substituting (you guessed it) mezcal for the classic vodka. The result is a delicious and surprisingly complex cocktail, considering it's a highball that's mostly comprised of ginger beer. But the rich smokiness of the mezcal cuts through the ginger and makes for a fantastic summer sip.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mug (preferably copper, if you want the classic aesthetic) or Collins glass with ice, garnish with a lime wedge, and enjoy.

name: Vauvert Slim
description: Vauvert was home to a Carthusian monastery where Francois Hannibal d'Estrees presented the monks with a manuscript contianing a recipe for "elixir of long life" in 1605.

instructions.description: Muddle 6 mint leaves with the lime juice
Add everything else, dry-shake. Shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled, Laphroaig 10-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch-rinsed egg coupe.
Garnish with a mint leaf

ingredients.name: ¼ – ½ Oz Simple Syrup Or Gum/ Syrup
Dashes Bitters (Angostura Works, But Feel Free To Experiment)

instructions.description: Stir ingredients over ice, if you’re using a large ice block you will need to stir longer. Stirring is the key to making this drink correctly, with so few ingredients getting the appropriate level of ice melt is crucial. Lastly, using a microplanner, grate some nutmeg over the top.

name: Down the Rabbit Hole
description: Down the Rabbit Hole hails from Copper Spoon Cocktails & Kitchen in Oakland. They're employing two liquors—mezcal and celery gin—for a boozy, savory base that's accented by carrot-apple cider shrub, lemon, and turmeric-ashwaganda honey. If you're unfamiliar with that last one, ashwaganda—also known as Indian ginseng—is a small, bitter plant that's used in Ayurvedic medicine.The inclusion of carrot makes Down the Rabbit Hole a fine cocktail to consider on Easter. The turmeric and ashwaganda make it reasonably healthy. And the mezcal and gin, well, those make it worth drinking.

instructions.description: Build all ingredients (except chili oil and flowers) in a shaker with ice.
Shake hard, then strain into a coupe.
Top with chili oil drops and garnish with edible flowers.

name: Scotch And Water
description: Scotch and Water isn't exactly a cocktail, per se, but it is an extremely popular way of enjoying the world's favorite whisky. All you'll need is some scotch (usually you don't want to use a super expensive single malt, since it gets pretty washed out), water, an Old-Fashioned glass, and some ice.Some people get picky about the kind of water they use, but that's honestly overkill. If your tap water's gross, by all means use bottled, but otherwise it should be fine. Feel free to adjust the ratio of your Scotch and Water to taste—whatever takes the bite off and gives you the strength you're looking for.

instructions.description: Fill an Old-Fashioned or highball glass with ice.
Add the scotch and water, stir gently, and serve.

name: Anisette Cocktail
description: A sweet, anise-flavored cocktail that’s popular in the Mediterranean and in Spanish-speaking countries. This particular recipe is also known as a Café de Paris cocktail.

instructions.description: Shake and strain into a cordial glass. Sprinkle with nutmeg.

name: Mexican Mule
description: A slight variation on the original Moscow Mule recipe, the Mexican Mule (sometimes known in cruder circles as the Donkey Show) pairs together tequila and ginger beer. Capped off with fresh lime juice, the Mexican Mule is a refreshing option for hot days (and the expectation of hotter nights), and a fine alternative to the classic margarita.

instructions.description: Fill copper mug or Collins glass with ice.
Add lime juice and tequila, then fill with ginger beer and stir.
Garnish with lime wedge.
Add infused vodka (or lemongrass bits and vodka), ginger, cilantro and muddle. Add the rest, share and strain into a whisky glass with big rock. Garnish with cilantro / pineapple.
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with a grapefruit twist and serve.

name: Boilermaker
description: A boilermaker is an American beer cocktail consisting of a shot of whiskey and a glass of beer (usually less than a pint). Although the beer can be used as a chaser for the whiskey, the boilermaker is frequently consumed by dropping the whiskey into the beer, and drinking it in a single go.In the UK, a boilermaker is used to describe a half pint of draught mild ale mixed with a half pint of bottled brown ale.

instructions.description: Fill shot glass with whiskey.
Drop full shot glass into the beer.
Drink immediately in one go.
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
Shake vigorously, then strain into a coupe glass.
Garnish with an orange twist.

name: Bourbon Sidecar
description: A Bourbon Sidecar is a simple three-ingredient variation of the classic Sidecar. While the original calls for cognac as its base spirit, here you're using bourbon alongside the triple sec and fresh lemon juice. The result is a similar cocktail to the original, but with more of those classic whiskey notes (oak, vanilla, spices) rather than the fruit and floral notes associated with cognac.To make a Bourbon Sidecar, shake the ingredients with ice and strain into a cocktail glass. And to see how it compares to the original, try making both and sipping them side by side. It's a fun experiment.

instructions.description: Pour the whiskey, triple sec and lemon juice into a cocktail shaker with ice cubes.
Shake well, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon peel and serve.

name: 50/50 Martini
description: The 50/50 Martini is a variation on the classic Dry Martini that uses equal parts gin and dry vermouth, making it quite a bit smoother and softer than its gin-heavy counterparts. It's a great vehicle for a really juniper-forward London dry gin, as you want something that won't get lost in the vermouth.50/50 Martinis have become more popular in recent years, as vermouth itself is finally throwing off decades of stigma thanks to the craft cocktail movement. No longer a mixer to be scoffed at, vermouth has reclaimed its place as a core component of the Martini, and in the 50/50, it's on full display.

instructions.description: Add gin and vermouth to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Scotch and Soda
description: The Scotch and Soda is a classic highball cocktail that consists of—you guessed it—scotch whisky and soda water (club soda or seltzer would do). The Americans claim the invention of the Scotch and Soda, although the Brits appear to be the ones to have popularized it in the late 19th or early 20th century. The Scotch and Soda is a crisp, refreshing cocktail that's made for summers but perfect anytime. Although many imbibers like to garnish this with a lemon twist, wedge or wheel—it is commonly served ungarnished.

instructions.description: Build in a highball glass filled with ice, pouring the scotch first, and then adding the soda water.
Optionally garnish, and serve.

name: Irish Blackthorn
description: The Blackthorn is a deftly conceived yet often overlooked whiskey cocktail that is not for the faint of heart. It's like an Irish Manhattan, but with dry vermouth instead of sweet, and with the addition of absinthe or Pernod.The directness of the Irish whiskey complements the refined, herbal flavors of the vermouth and absinthe, giving it a mature and balanced taste. Stir for maximum clarity and garnish with the twisted rind of an orange.A note about the vermouth: In Harry Johnson's Bartender's Manual (1900 edition) and the famed Savoy Cocktail Book (1930), dry vermouth is the preferred choice for the Blackthorn Cocktail—and it's used in equal portions to the whiskey. But in more recent recipe iterations, it's common to see sweet vermouth employed instead. Both make for a good drink, but we like how the dry vermouth plays with the absinthe. Feel free to experiment with vermouths and ratios to find what you like best. We've enjoyed an even split between sweet and dry vermouths, so there's room to play around.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice until cold.
Strain into a cocktail glass.

name: Vodka Gimlet
description: The classic Vodka Gimlet is simply a vodka-based variation on the Gimlet, which is traditionally made with gin. It's light, refreshing, and easy to make. Where the gin can sometimes be too complex or strongly flavored for some drinkers, substituting vodka gives rise to a smooth, straightforward drink that is equally at home on hot summer days by the pool and relaxing nights at home.What's in a Vodka Gimlet cocktail?The Vodka Gimlet recipe is most closely related to the Daiquiri, which is a nearly identical recipe, but made with rum instead of vodka. Both the Daiquiri and Gimlet were enjoyed by the English Navy to ensure British sailors got their daily rations of citrus, thereby warding off scurvy, an ailment that arises from a lack of vitamin C in the diet.The recipe is incredibly simple with only three ingredients: vodka, lime juice, and simple syrup. It's recommend to use a quality vodka, though there's no need to pick up anything too expensive—just choose something you like and steer clear of the super cheap stuff. A good, medium-priced vodka should serve you well and make a great Gimlet. Fortunately, vodka is an affordable category, with several great bottles available for around $20.Although many old-school recipes suggest Rose's Lime Cordial, we always think that fresh is best. Try using fresh lime juice for a more flavorful and better tasting cocktail.How to Make a Vodka Gimlet CocktailTo make a Vodka Gimlet, start by pouring two ounces vodka, a half ounce lime juice, and a half ounce simple syrup into a cocktail shaker.Add ice, shake vigorously for about 20 seconds, then strain your drink into a chilled cocktail glass—aka a Martini glass. Alternatively, use a coupe glass instead for a softer, rounder, and more modern aesthetic. Optionally garnish with a lime wheel (some people also add a mint leaf), and serve.The Vodka Gimlet in Popular CultureThis Vodka Gimlet was a favorite of Betty Draper on Mad Men, making it a perfect drink for period-piece parties. Hers would have used Rose's Lime, but as we noted above, yours will present its best self when mixed with fresh lime juice. Ernest Hemingway and Philip Marlowe, the protagonist in Raymond Chandler's detective novels, also drank Gimlets, but they served theirs with gin.Of course, once you've mastered the Vodka Gimlet, it's just a quick spirits swap to make the classic Gin Gimlet, so go ahead and try both to see which you prefer.

ingredients.name: Lime Wheel Or Twist For Garnish (Optional)

instructions.description: Add vodka, lime juice, and simple syrup into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lime wheel or twist (optional) and serve.

name: Nancy Pelosi
description: The Nancy Pelosi cocktail is an adult beverage (emphasis intended), eponymously named after the United States senator from California, and the first female Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.Created by Lupo Verde, a rustic Italian restaurant located in the heart of the nation’s capital, the Nancy Pelosi recipe pays homage to the American politician, and features ingredients that reflect aspects of her life.The amaro nocino liqueur is from Northern Italy, where Pelosi's mother is from. The avocado puree pays tribute to California, where she represents the 12th District. Pelosi is also known to enjoy chocolate and beer, which have also been incorporated into the recipe. As she is the youngest of seven children, the Nancy Pelosi cocktail features a total of seven ingredients to pay tribute to her and her siblings.

instructions.description: Shake all liquid ingredients (except beer) in a cocktail shaker, with ice.
Double-strain into a collins glass over ice.
Top off with the beer, garnish with the chocolate crumbles, and serve.

name: Cape Codder
description: The Cape Codder (also known as a Cape Cod) is a simple, tart cocktail that's perfect for anything by the seaside, whether it's on a boat or sunbathing on the beach. The drink was actually invented by cranberry juice moguls Ocean Spray in 1945 (though originally they called it the Red Devil), and it caught on to become a popular choice at bars all over the world.

instructions.description: Add vodka and cranberry juice to a Highball glass or Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
Stir, garnish with the lime wedge, and serve.

name: Four Horsemen
description: The Four Horsemen drink (or 4 Horsemen Shot) is a simple shooter that combines four varieties of whiskey—bourbon whiskey, Tennessee whiskey, Scotch whiskey, and Irish whiskey—used in equal-parts and served in a shot glass.Why is this drink called the Four Horsemen?It is named for the most popular brands of each type of whiskey that comprise the drink's ingredients: Jim Beam, Jack Daniel's, Johnnie Walker, and Jameson (named for John Jameson), all of whom come together like the four horsemen of the apocalypse. A bit cheeky if you ask us, but it's fun to consider that these top-selling spirits all feature gentleman whose names begin with "J."What alcohol is in a Four Horsemen shot?As far as we can tell, the original recipe for the Four Horsemen shot includes only whiskeys, and only the aforementioned whiskey brands.Some recipes found online include Jose Cuervo, which is a tequila and therefore ruins that whiskey streak. Other recipes call for all kinds of additional ingredients including Grand Marnier, Jagermeister, Bacardi, Captain Morgan, or even (gasp) sour mix, which sort of defeats the purpose of the name. If you see anyone calling for everclear or a method that involves flames, you may want to steer clear. When in doubt, stick to the classic four ingredients and nothing else.How to make a Four Horsemen shot?Some variations of the Four Horsemen recipe suggest shaking all the whiskeys with ice in a cocktail shaker to chill the shot, which you can do. But if you don't want to dilute the spirits, then there's no need to shake, stir or strain anything. Either drink the shot at room temperature, or chill the bottles before you make the Four Horsemen shot to enjoy it ice-cold.When making this drink, we suggest keeping it simple with the original Four Horsemen recipe. Just pour equal parts of each whiskey into a shot glass or lowball glass, and you're done. Easy peasy.Is the Four Horsemen shot strong?The Four Horsemen shot is often misperceived as an extra-strong drink made from hard liquors with high alcoholic content, but it is in fact no stronger than any other straight shot of whiskey, provided you're consuming an equal portion of liquid. Because, at the end of the day, you're still shooting two ounces of whiskey (per the usual half-ounce pour of each), regardless of how many whiskeys go into the glass. Of course, you should use caution whenever you're downing shots, but you already knew that.Does the Four Horsemen shot taste good?While the novelty of the name and the multi-part drink can certainly be fun, we're not sure we see the point in mixing a bunch of whiskeys together to create this shooter. Perhaps for the same questionable reason someone came up with the Three Wise Men shot—but hey, to each their own. If you like it, drink it!Combining four different whiskey brands in a single shot won't make you any more drunk when you're consuming the same volume of alcohol. But it's a fun way to work through some bottles in your home bar.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a shot glass and serve.

name: Old Pal
description: The Old Pal is a riff on the Boulevardier, itself a riff on the classic Negroni. It maintains the standard template of spirit, vermouth, and Campari, opting for rye whiskey and dry vermouth. The whiskey provides a stout backbone for the other two ingredients to stand on. The Campari does its jobs, providing a punch of bitterness, and the dry vermouth provides a floral unifier to tie it all together. The final result is a stiff drink that can be sipped before dinner as an aperitif, or indulged in fireside, proving its value as a versatile addition to your drinking arsenal.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass (or into an Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube).
Optionally garnish with a lemon twist, and serve.

name: The Robin Scherbatsky
description: The Robin Scherbatsky is a fun, ridiculous and just plain awesome drink from the popular American TV sitcom How I Met Your Mother. This cocktail was ordered so many times by Robin that McClaren's Pub named it after her.It combines coconut rum, peach schnapps, vanilla vodka, and strawberry creme liqueur with cranberry juice, sugar (yes, more sugar) and maraschino cherries. It's then blended together and served tall with a straw.The Robin Scherbatsky recipe is about the furthest you can get from a craft cocktail, and it's liable to give someone diabetes. But if you'd like to recreate this TV-famous drink, you can do so by following the below recipe.

instructions.description: Blend all ingredients together except for the cherries.
Pour into a hurricane glass, garnish with the cherries, and serve with a swirly straw.

name: Curacao Cooler
description: The Curacao Cooler is a tall, refreshing cocktail that combines orange liqueur with vodka and citrus juices. Triple sec provides that bittersweet orange-flavored base, while blue curacao lends a bit more orange flavor and gives the drink its blue hue. Lemon, lime and orange juice lengthen the drink, which is typically served in a hurricane glass. Follow the recipe below to make one for yourself.

instructions.description: Pour into a collins glass filled with ice. Add a spiral of lime, and serve.
Optionally serve this in a Hurricane glass for an alternative look.

name: Genever Old-Fashioned
description: A variation on the Old-Fashioned featuring genever, the predecessor of modern gin originating in the Netherlands and Belgium.

instructions.description: Add sugar cube, two dashes of orange bitters, and a few drops of water to the bottom of an Old-Fashioned glass, then muddle until sugar is dissolved.
Add 2 oz of Bols barrel-aged genever.
Add one large ice cube. The best ones barely fit inside the glass.
Stir until chilled.

Finally, cut a slice of peel from a fresh, firm orange using a vegetable peeler or paring knife. Aiming the cut side over the surface of the drink, twist it to squeeze out a mist of essential oils, then drop it in the glass.

name: Absinthe Old-Fashioned
description: Invented by bartender Doug Petry of Rye in Louisville, Kentucky, this cocktail truly stretches the boundaries of its namesake. While it presents a soft color palette (reddish Peychaud’s bitters floated atop milky white absinthe), the Absinthe Old-Fashioned packs a punch. If you didn’t already have enough reasons to make a pilgrimage to Kentucky and explore its cocktail scene, this one alone is worth the trip.

instructions.description: Combine all the ingredients (except the Peychaud's bitters) in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over a large chunk of ice.
Float the Peychaud's bitters on top.
Shake all ingredients well with ice.
Strain over ice into a Hurricane glass.
Add a splash of soda water, garnish, and serve.

name: Eggnog
description: There are countless Egg Nog recipes out there, many with small differences, but they share one thing in common: They're almost all labor intensive, requiring you to separate eggs and form peaks and other things that you likely don't ant to deal with when you're thirsting for a good drink.Lucky for you, this Egg Nog recipe from Portland bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler is a snap to make. All you need is a blender, a few basic kitchen staples, brandy, rum, and a few hours for it to chill in the fridge. It makes two servings, but you can easily increase the yield by multiplying your ingredients by however people you want to serve. Once you've mastered this recipe, mix things up with the Whiskey Eggnog, which is even easier to make, requiring nothing more than a shaker, strainer, and glass.

instructions.description: Beat eggs in blender for one minute on medium speed.
Slowly add sugar and blend for one additional minute.
With blender still running, add nutmeg, brandy, rum, milk and cream until combined.
Chill thoroughly to allow flavors to combine and serve in chilled wine glasses or champagne coupes, grating additional nutmeg on top immediately before serving.

name: Kentucky Mule
description: The Kentucky Mule is a Southern twist on the classic Moscow Mule, swapping the vodka for bourbon. Like many other Moscow Mule variations, all it does is change the base spirit, and the rest of the recipe remains the same: ginger beer and lime juice in a snazzy copper mug. We recommend using a strong, spicy ginger beer, as it's really the star of the show, but unlike the original recipe, the Kentucky Mule's use of bourbon gives it a slightly sweeter, oakier profile that shines through the soda better than vodka.The Kentucky Mule follows the naming conventions of other drinks that freely swap their base spirits, adopting its title from the home of bourbon itself. It's a great cocktail for those hot summer days when you don't really feel like drinking a Mint Julep, but still want to feel like a genteel Southerner.

ingredients.name: Mint And/Or Lime Wheel For Garnish (Optional)

instructions.description: Add bourbon and lime juice to a copper mug or Collins glass with ice (crushed or cubed).
Fill with ginger beer, garnish with a lime, and serve.

Optional: We've always liked our bourbon drinks with a bit of mint on the nose, so if you'd like you can also clap a sprig of fresh mint between your hands (to bruise it) and garnish with that as well.

name: The Agave Cocktail
description: Featuring a truly authentic speakeasy atmosphere (the doorman asks for a password upon arrival) and inventive takes on classic tipples, San Francisco’s Bourbon & Branch has become legendary in the cocktail community. This Old-Fashioned variation, concocted by Erick Castro, employs the smoky sippability of añejo tequila and agave nectar to create a compelling, provocative drink for those more thoughtful trips south of the border.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients except cinnamon in an Old-Fashioned glass.
Add a large chunk of ice and stir until chilled.
Garnish with grated cinnamon.

name: Grapefruit Collins
description: Volcan de mi Tierra is a new tequila that was first released in 2017. The Blanco combines agave from the lowlands and highlands of Jalisco, and has an austere and herbaceous flavor. Drink it neat or on the rocks if that's your thing, but if you'd like to mix it into a cocktail, try the extra-refreshing Grapefruit Collins.The Grapefruit Collins has a lot to like, provided you like tequila and citrus. It sports lemon and grapefruit alongside simple syrup, and it's all topped with soda water for some effervescence. The result is a light and summery cocktail perfect for backyard barbecues or literally any other time you've got tequila and citrus fruits on hand.

ingredients.name: Volcan De Mi Tierra Blanco Tequila

instructions.description: Shake tequila, lemon, simple syrup, and grapefruit with ice.
Strain into a double rocks glass over a large cube of ice.
Top with soda water, and garnish with a grapefruit wedge.

name: Moscow Mule
description: The Moscow Mule is an approachable and popular vodka cocktail that comes from a family of cocktails known as the "buck"—a drink made with ginger beer, citrus, and a base spirit.Served in eye-catching copper mugs, easy to drink, and made with readily available ingredients, the Moscow Mule cocktail has enjoyed a spot near the top of the modern cocktail canon. It's easy to see why; it's tasty, refreshing and great on hot summer days or a night out on the town.What's in a Moscow Mule?The Moscow Mule is composed of just three ingredients—vodka, lime juice, and ginger beer—so it's very easy to make. Like all classic cocktails, we recommend using fresh juice, as the final product will taste far superior to anything made with bottled lime juice or certainly sweet-and-sour.The best ginger beer is up for debate, but choosing a high-quality product will go a long way in this recipe. Some ginger beers have a bolder flavor that others, with more sweetness or spicy notes, so feel free to experiment with a few different brands until you find one that makes the best Moscow Mule for you. Two of our favorites here at Bevvy are Fever Tree Ginger Beer and Q Ginger Beer, but there are many great options on store shelves.Importantly, do not be confused and substitute ginger ale for the ginger beer, as it's a different mixer that will result in a different drink. You want the robust spice of real ginger beer.A common garnish for the Moscow Mule is a lime wedge, but a sprig of mint has also been well-received. You can experiment with other garnishes, or skip the garnish entirely—you really can't go wrong here.The recipe below is for the classic Moscow Mule, but there are plenty of Moscow Mule variations for those who want to experiment. For example, the Kentucky Mule calls for bourbon whiskey instead of vodka, while the Mexican Mule uses tequila, and Audrey Saunders—owner of the dearly departed New York bar, Pegu Club—slips gin into her beloved Gin-Gin Mule.Who invented the Moscow Mule?The traditional Moscow Mule cocktail is widely believed to have been invented as the result of a 1941 collaboration between three men: John G. Martin, who had recently purchased the rights to the Smirnoff vodka brand; Jack Morgan, the owner and proprietor of Cock'n Bull ginger beer; and Rudolph Kunett, former rights holder to the Smirnoff brand.Martin and Kunett were struggling to sell Smirnoff in a post-second World War America, as Americans didn't know the first thing about vodka and it was largely unpopular. Morgan was struggling to sell an overzealous order of ginger beer. The trio, perhaps in desperation, concocted a drink recipe combining their products and devised a marketing campaign to sell the cocktail. They struck gold with the fortuitous concoction served in an eye-catching copper mug.The Moscow Mule helped to popularize vodka in the United States for decades to come. (The full history of the Moscow Mule is a fascinating one and worth a read if you're a fan of the drink).Why is a Moscow Mule served in a copper mug?The Moscow Mule's signature copper mug played a part in the intrigue and ensuing popularity of the Moscow Mule. That much is a fact. What remains relatively mysterious is who was responsible for the idea of using a copper cup in the first place.One account includes an unnamed woman who was struggling to sell her handmade mugs. Supposedly, she happened to know one of the drink's inventors—and was possibly even a girlfriend—but the rest of the story is quite murky. Another account claims the then-head bartender of Cock ‘n’ Bull restaurant in LA created the Moscow Mule as a way to use up an excess supply of ginger beer and mugs, and had the cocktail on the menu for a while before his boss and associates took credit for inventing it. Like a lot of cocktail history, the origin story is not entirely clear, but Price’s account seems a bit more likely, if less intriguing.Regardless of who invented the original Moscow Mule recipe, Martin was the one who picked it up and ran with it, embarking on a tour of bars across the United States with a mountain of bright copper mugs and one of the earliest Polaroid cameras in tow.He would show up at a bar, get the bartender to make his Moscow Mule for guests, and then take a picture of them with his camera. Other guests, fascinated by the snazzy copper cups, would inquire and often order the same cocktail for themselves.Martin would then leave one copy of the photograph with the bar to display, and take the other—along with many more like it—to the next bar. It was a serious case of “all the cool kids are doing it” marketing, and it was extremely effective in popularizing the Moscow Mule.While the copper mug is fun and frosty, you don't necessarily need one to enjoy the drink. Other glassware options for serving Moscow Mules include the highball glass and the Collins glass. They may not look quite as interesting, but the drink will be equally delicious.Safety tip: When using a copper Moscow Mule mug, always look for options that are coated with a food safe lacquer or lined with another metal, like stainless steel. Unlined copper mugs—and other containers like shakers—can leach copper into drinks, especially if they are acidic and the liquid remains in contact with the copper vessel for a long period of time.

instructions.description: Fill a copper mug with ice (or use a Collins glass if no mug is available).
Add vodka and lime juice, then top with the ginger beer.
Garnish with an optional lime wedge.

name: El Presidente Cocktail
description: El Presidente is a classic rum cocktail that originated in Havana, Cuba in the 1920s and was named for President Gerado Machado. The cocktail was traditionally made with Bacardi, the biggest name in Cuban rum at the time. Combining light rum with dry vermouth, orange curaçao, and grenadine, El Presidente is slightly sweet and dry, yet balanced. For the best results, try making your own grenadine, which is far superior to the fake-colored bottled stuff, and will really let this drink shine.

instructions.description: Add ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist.

name: Young Laddie
description: Invented by Joaquin Simo of Death & Co in Manhattan, the Young Laddie is an Old-Fashioned variation that uses Bruichladdich scotch (pronounced "brook-laddie," hence the name of the cocktail) instead of bourbon or rye. While the recipe calls for grapefruit bitters, it works pretty well with Angostura if you don't have any lying around. That said, using both the orange and grapefruit twists really ties the drink together, so make sure you don't forget them.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients (except twists) in an Old-Fashioned glass.
Add a large chunk of ice and stir until chilled.
Squeeze the twists over the drink and drop them in.

name: Dark 'n Stormy
description: Unlike pretty much any other cocktail in the world, the name "Dark 'n' Stormy" is actually a registered trademark of Gosling Brothers, the Bermudan company that produces Gosling's Rum and Gosling's Ginger Beer. As a result, technically any bar that serves a Dark 'n' Stormy is legally obligated to use Gosling's Black Seal Rum—that said, good luck enforcing it.Since it's questionable whether food and drink recipes are even eligible for trademark in the first place, the only obvious protection it offers is from sales of bottled, ready-to-drink Dark 'n' Stormy cocktails. Gosling's official trademark states that it is for "Pre-mixed alcoholic cocktail, namely rum and ginger beer," which is just ambiguous enough to cause confusion. Though they've earned a reputation for being fairly litigious, we can't say we've ever heard of them suing a home bartender—so go ahead and mix away!

instructions.description: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add the dark rum and lime juice, then fill the rest of the glass with ginger beer.
Stir gently.
Garnish with a wedge of lime and serve.

name: Rob Roy
description: From dive bars to fancy cocktail joints, you don't get much more basic than a Rob Roy—and for good reason. This classic, Scotch-based variation on the Manhattan has been a favorite for generations.The Rob Roy is basically a Manhattan that uses Scotch instead of rye. It’s believed to have been named after Robert Roy MacGregor, who was a Robin Hood-like figure in 18th century Scotland. Hence the Scotch.For best results, opt for a blended Scotch here. Dewar’s or Famous Grouse are both simple yet effective.

instructions.description: Stir ingredients with ice until chilled and strain into a cocktail glass.
Garnish with orange twist and serve.

name: The Bartender
description: A variation on the Old-Fashioned cocktail concocted by Robert Simonson, illustrious author of The Old-Fashioned, that uses a bit of Fernet-Branca to keep this classic interesting.

instructions.description: Muddle sugar, bitters, and a few drops of warm water in an Old-Fashioned glass.
Add bourbon and Fernet.
Add a large chunk of ice and stir until chilled.
Twist lemon peel over the drink and drop it in.
Shake all ingredients with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, and serve.

name: Vodka Tonic
description: The Vodka Tonic is one of those wonderfully self-explanatory mixed drinks, like a Gin and Tonic or Rum and Coke. The tonic water allows some room for variation and experimentation, though, so check out the lesser-known tonic brands at your local liquor store before settling for the likes of Canada Dry and Schweppes—brands such as Fever Tree, Q Tonic and Fentiman's have much higher-quality products and will make for a superior drink. You can even get creative and mix your own from a tonic syrup, which can be fun to give the Vodka Tonic cocktail more of a DIY element.One of the easiest ways to change the taste and flavor of this most simple of vodka cocktails is to switch up the garnish. Although it's classically finished with a lime wedge, drinkers might opt for another citrus like lemon wedge or orange, berries or even a squeeze of lime juice (but not that much lime juice—the vodka gimlet is its own drink).Drinkers who are calorie conscious can also swap out the tonic water in favor or soda water to make it a vodka and soda.

ingredients.name: Lime Wedge Or Wheel For Garnish

instructions.description: Add vodka to an Old-Fashioned glass or Highball glass with ice, then fill with tonic water.
Garnish with a lime wedge or wheel and serve.

name: Siciliano
description: The Siciliano cocktail is a delicious cold-brew coffee drink that bucks the trend of coffee cocktails needing to be served hot. It's a fairly low-alcohol cocktail, made with just a few ounces of sweet Italian vermouth and Amaro Averna, and combined with the kick of some good coffee this is a great way to either ease into your night or finish off a nice dinner.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients (except orange twist) to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass, garnish with an orange twist, and serve.

name: Mexican Martini
description: Believe it or not, The Mexican Martini is actually a riff on the Margarita rather than the Martini. It is essentially a cocktail variation of a Margarita, but served straight up in a cocktail glass like a Martini.

instructions.description: Shake tequila and vermouth with ice. Strain into a cocktail glass, add pepper slice.

name: Vodka Collins
description: The Vodka Collins is a simple vodka-based cocktail that's typically served in a Collins Glass (the latter was named after the drink it so often contained).The Vodka Collins recipe is a riff on the Collins-family of cocktails, such as the classic gin-laced John Collins and Tom Collins—the former was made with London dry gin while the latter was traditionally made with Old Tom Gin, hence the name. The Tom Collins dates back to at least 1877, when it appeared in The Bon Vivant's Companion by famed barkeep Jerry Thomas. In this family tree of Collins-cocktails, the Vodka Collins is known as the Joe Collins. But you don't need to worry about that. In fact, try ordering a Joe Collins at the bar, and the average barkeep will give you a blank stare. Right, so, Vodka Collins it is.What's in a Vodka Collins?The Vodka Collins recipe consists of a couple of ounces of vodka, lemon juice (fresh is best), sweetener, and sparkling water (club soda or seltzer water). The spirit acts as a solid backbone, while the lemon brightens the drink and the sparkling water lends effervescence. Many Vodka Collins recipes will also include a cherry garnish (or a lemon slice) for a nice presentation, but this is optional—the drink tastes just as good without it.Our preference for the sweetener is to use basic simple syrup, as it mixes well and does not impart additional flavors, but bartenders may selectively choose an alternative sweetener for their own recipe variations. For the cherry garnish, we like using a high-quality maraschino cherry if available, rather than the bright-red versions packed in preservatives.We do not recommend using sweetened versions of soda water substitutes such as Cherry 7up or Sprite, which we've seen in some Vodka Collins recipes elsewhere online—that adds empty calories, but more importantly, it messes with the flavor profile of the classic drink.How to make a Vodka Collins?Many bartenders will build a Vodka Collins directly in the glass, adding each ingredient, plus ice cubes, and giving it all a quick stir. It appears this was the original way of making the drink. However, you can also shake it with ice in a cocktail shaker to better incorporate the ingredients. Just know that this method brings additional dilution into your glass, so you may need to dial back the sparkling water slightly. Whichever route you choose, the result is a delicious and refreshing drink

instructions.description: Add the vodka, simple syrup, and lemon juice into a Collins glass, then fill with ice.
Top with the soda water.
Optionally garnish with a cherry (or a lemon slice, or both if you'd like) and serve with a straw.

name: Black Hole Sun
description: Invented by Houston bartender Bryan Hutchinson, the Black Hole Sun brings the Old-Fashioned into the realm of coffee cocktails with a splash of cold-brew and a delicious combination of orange, Angostura, and chocolate bitters.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into Old-Fashioned glass and garnish with a lemon wheel floating in cocktail.

name: Three Wise Men
description: The Three Wise Men cocktail is a "mixed" drink that blends three different whiskeys together. The drink's name is inspired by The Three Wise Men referenced in the Bible that visited the infant Jesus the night he was born, and the brands typically called for in the Three Wise Men recipe include brand names named after men—Johnnie Walker, Jack Daniel's, and Jim Beam (aka the "wise men").Why anyone would think this was a combination worthy of inventing is a bit beyond us, and we're resigned to simply believe that the Three Wise Men was created in an era where clever drink names trumped flavor and creativity. But as we wrote with the Four Horsemen shot, to each their own.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a shot glass, and serve.
Alternatively, add all ingredients to an old-fashioned glass (ice optional), and serve.

name: Aventura Cocktail
description: The Aventura is an original cocktail from the Bevvy Cocktail Lab. It features the smokiness of mezcal, the freshness of mint, and the sweetness of seasonal berries, and is further enhanced by the lively flavors of St. Germain and luxurious Grand Marnier. Delightfully elegant and devilishly sweet, the Aventura is a drink you'll remember with fondness for years to come.

instructions.description: Add the sugar and citrus juices to a cocktail shaker and stir.
Add a small handful of fresh raspberries and muddle thoroughly.
Add ice, mezcal, Grand Marnier, and St. Germain and shake.
Strain through a mesh strainer into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a fresh sprig of mint.
Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and serve.
Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.
Shake, and strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.
Garnish with an orange slice.
Muddle apple wedge in the bottom of a mixing glass.
Add all other ingredients (except club soda) and shake with ice.
Strain into a highball glass over new ice and top with club soda.
Garnish with an apple slice.
Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain into a chilled nick and nora glass.
Garnish with a slice of mandarin orange or an orange peel.

name: Strawberry Mojito
description: The Strawberry Mojito is a slight variation on the classic Mojito, but with a little more fruit-forward sweetness to balance out the citrus. The addition of Crème de Fraise des Bois (or any other strawberry liqueur, really) gives an extra boost to the muddled fresh strawberries, which are delicious in combination with the mint and lime. This is a great cocktail for a summer afternoon barbecue, a day at the beach, or those long winter nights when you just want to pretend it's July.

instructions.description: In the bottom of your chilled highball glass, muddle strawberries, mint, lime and Creme de Fraise des Bois.
Add rum, then fill the glass with soda water and stir.
Garnish with a sprig of mint (clap the leaves between your hands once to bruise them and bring out the aroma) and a strawberry.

name: Elderflower Martini
description: The Elderflower Martini is a lovely, slightly sweeter and flowery take on the classic Dry Martini that uses St. Germain elderflower liqueur to complement the floral notes of a good gin. Elderflower-inspired drinks have become increasingly popular with the advent of St. Germain—the popular liqueur even earning the moniker of "bartender's ketchup" as it became ubiquitous with the craft cocktail movement—and the Elderflower Martini certainly doesn't disappoint. Some of you might even want to try modifying the Elderflower Martini recipe by using an Old Tom gin instead of a traditional London Dry gin, as it's a bit sweeter and less powerful on the juniper.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass (we prefer using the coupe glass as an alternative) and serve.

name: Vodka Soda
description: The Vodka Soda is an extremely simple, low-calorie mixed drink that's great for those days you don't want anything fancy. It uses just two ingredients, vodka and (you guessed it) soda water, and you can optionally garnish it with a lime or lemon wedge for an extra bit of citrus. A favorite of nightclub-goers, dieters, and lazy bartenders everywhere, the Vodka Soda isn't so much classic as it is obvious—but that doesn't mean it isn't exactly what the doctor ordered from time to time.

instructions.description: Add vodka and soda to a Highball glass with ice and stir gently.
Garnish with a lime or lemon wedge (optional) and serve.

name: Noble Punch
description: The Noble Punch is a refreshing tequila drink that employs pineapple alongside lime, simple syrup, and soda. The tequila provides a firm base for the other ingredients to stand on, and the topper of soda offers a touch of hydration and effervescence perfect for fighting the summer heat. It's an easy cocktail to make, whether you're mixing up a solo serving for yourself or batching up a large vat for a party.

instructions.description: Place tequila, lime juice, pineapple juice, and simple syrup into a shaker with ice.
Shake until chilled, then strain into an Old-Fashioned glass.
Top with soda and bitters, and garnish with a pineapple wedge.

name: Negroni
description: The Negroni is a classic cocktail featuring Campari front-and-center, along with equal parts gin and sweet vermouth, resulting in a spirit-forward drink with a strongly bitter profile. It's typically either built in an Old-Fashioned glass on the rocks, or stirred and served up in a cocktail or coupe glass. A London dry gin typically balances the other flavors best, and be sure to use a good sweet vermouth like Carpano Antica or Noilly Prat.The Negroni was probably invented around 1905 by one Count Count Camillo Negroni, an Italian noble who had abandoned his home country for the adventure of the American Wild West. Upon returning to Florence after decades of hard living, he ordered an Americano cocktail—Campari, sweet vermouth, and soda water—but instead of the traditional soda, he requested a measure of gin for a bit more kick. There's some controversy surrounding the history of the Negroni, though, and it certainly makes for a hell of a tale.

instructions.description: Stir the gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth over ice and strain into an Old-Fashioned glass with a single, large ice cube (alternatively, strain into a chilled cocktail or coupe glass).
Garnish with an orange twist.

name: Vodka Martini
description: The Vodka Martini is, as the name would imply, simply a variation of the classic Dry Martini that uses vodka instead of gin. It makes for a very different drink, in which the aromas from the vermouth are more pronounced relative to those of the spirit, as vodka does not contain the botanicals found in gin. And, as a bonus, the Vodka Martini lets you order a sexy-looking Martini even if you can't stand the thought of drinking gin.What's in a Vodka Martini?Crucially, vodka. It will also contain dry vermouth (sometimes called "French vermouth"). The ratios between the vodka and the vermouth will vary according to the recipe and client preferences; the driest of dry Vodka Martinis might only have a vermouth wash, while "wetter" Vodka Martinis could hold a whole ounce of vermouth or more.It will typically be accompanied by a garnish, though this will also differ according to customer preference. A lemon twist might be added for a touch of citrus tang, a skewer of olives can provide a briny touch and turn it into a Dirty Vodka Martini, and cocktail onions can make it a Vodka Gibson.The history of the Vodka MartiniAs is the case with many classic cocktails, the precise origins of the Martini—whether that's a classic Gin Martini or the Vodka Martini—are shrouded in mystery. Some sources claim that the drink derived its name from a brand of vermouth called Martini, while other suggest it was a riff on the Martinez cocktail.What's not in doubt is that James Bond, in the original novels and the subsequent films, did perhaps more than any bartender to promote the Vodka Martini, with his famous "shaken, not stirred" order. How's that for an advertisement?How to make a Vodka Martini To make a Vodka Martini, first gather the necessary ingredients: vodka and vermouth, and depending on your garnish preferences, olives, a lemon peel, or a cocktail onion.Make sure your tools are at hand, also. You'll want a cocktail mixing glass (or a cocktail shaker, should you want to take Bond's advice to heart), plus a stirring spoon, ice cubes, and a chilled Martini glass. As the Vodka Martini is a drink that benefits from a frosty temperature, you may want to keep that cocktail glass in the freezer for at least 20 minutes before before you pour the finished cocktail into it. Popular vodkas for a Vodka MartiniThe choice of what vodka should be used in a Vodka Martini rests with the drinker, depending on their own flavor preferences. Tito's and Grey Goose may be two of the most commonly asked-for vodka brands, although these days 007 is partial to Belvedere.

instructions.description: Add vodka and dry vermouth to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cocktail olive and serve.

name: A Zephyr Star
description: Soft, floral, and flavorful, Zephyr Gin is a unique gin that counts elderberries among its botanicals. Here it's getting the cocktail treatment with A Zephyr Star, which pairs that gin with lemon, simple syrup, honey bitters and Allspice Dram. The latter is a liqueur made from allspice berries from the pimento tree. You can try making your own at home, but if you'd rather just pickup a bottle, St. Elizabeth makes a great one.Throw some star anise on top, and you've got a refreshing, easy-drinking cocktail that's loaded with aromatics.

instructions.description: Mix all ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake and strain into a coupe, then garnish with star anise.

name: Clover Club
description: One of the truly definitive drinks of the early 20th century, the Clover Club is one of the most famous cocktails to use egg white. The backbone of gin, the freshness of lemon juice,  and the beauty of homemade raspberry syrup combine with the egg white to produce a frothy, deeply colored drink that continues to impress over 100 years after it's inception.The drink is named for the legendary Clover Club in Philadelphia, founded by a group of senior journalists around 1880. The club was famous for inviting politicians and other personalities of note, requiring them to give a speech after dinner, and then heckling them incessantly. The recipe for the Clover Club first appeared in print in 1901.

ingredients.name: Lemon Twist Or Raspberries For Garnish

instructions.description: Shake the ingredients vigorously in an empty cocktail shaker, then add ice.
Resume shaking until the foam is fully formed and the sides of the shaker produce condensation.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with raspberries or a lemon twist.
Shake first three ingredients with ice, and strain into a chilled champagne flute.
Top with sparkling wine, and garnish with a lemon peel.

name: Tropical Rum Punch
description: Punches are great when you want to serve your guests fun drinks without playing bartender all night. This Tropical Rum Punch allows you to do exactly that. It's combining two rums—Bacardi Superior and Bacardi Banana—for an extra tropical base, along with coconut cream, orange juice and lemon juice. It's refreshing, delicious, and a good antidote for a hot day.The Tropical Rum Punch recipe can be easily scaled up or down via some simple math. So whether you're making drinks for one or 100, follow the ratios below, and you'll be in good shape.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients into a punch bowl with a large block of ice.
Garnish with orange slices, and serve.

name: Harvey Wallbanger
description: The three-ingredient Harvey Wallbanger rose to prominence in the 1960s and enjoyed a two-decade run as one of the most popular drinks in the country. It's similar to the classic Screwdriver, but includes Galliano, an herbal liqueur with flavors of anise and vanilla.The Harvey Wallbanger fell out of favor for many years, but after Galliano reformulated and relaunched with a new recipe, it's begun to pop up once more.

instructions.description: Pour vodka and orange juice into a collins glass over ice cubes and stir.
Float Galliano on top and serve.

name: Angry Spell
description: Combine cider and something scary, and you’ve got a damn seasonal cocktail that’s perfect for fall and Halloween. That’s exactly what’s happening here with the Angry Spell, a cider-spiked drink courtesy of Angry Orchard and mixologist Jeremy Oertel.It follows the classic El Diablo template (tequila, lime, ginger, crème de cassis), but swaps out tequila for white rum, and subs in cider for ginger beer. Here’s how you make it.

ingredients.name: Crème De Cassis Or Crème De Muir

instructions.description: For cocktail: Add rum, lime and ginger syrup to a shaker with ice. Shake then strain into a Collins glass with fresh ice. Top with cider and crème de cassis. Garnish with lime wheel and blackberries.

For ginger syrup: Peel the ginger and then finely chop. Add all ingredients to the pot and bring to boil. Allow to cook for two minutes, then remove from heat and let steep for 20 minutes. Strain syrup through a fine strainer. Keep refrigerated.

name: Vodka Cranberry
description: The Vodka Cranberry is one of the simplest cocktails out there, and probably one of the most popular. While it's not entirely clear how this differs from a Cape Codder, the easiest distinction is that the Vodka Cranberry doesn't require that you squeeze a lime into it. That said, they're essentially the same drink—vodka and cranberry juice.

instructions.description: Add vodka and cranberry juice to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice and serve.

name: Rum Mule
description: The Rum Mule is a take on the classic Moscow Mule that subs rum for vodka. In this case, we're using Havana Club Añejo Clásico Puerto Rican Rum, which is Bacardi-owned and available stateside, so it's easy to procure.Topped off with ginger beer and bitters, the Rum Mule is a refreshing and simple-to-make cocktail perfect for backyard gatherings that require more than just cold beers. It's a friendly drink that should appeal to rum drinkers and mule fans alike.

ingredients.name: Havana Club Añejo Clásico Puerto Rican Rum

instructions.description: Fill a copper mug with ice, and squeeze in lime wedges.
Add rum and ginger beer, then top with bitters, and stir gently.
Garnish with a mint sprig and a seasonal berry.

name: Champagne Julep
description: The Champagne Julep is a fairly simple, creative, and bubbly variation on the classic Mint Julep. While it begins just like the original, with bourbon, sugar, and mint, this recipe adds champagne to mellow out the sugar and to give the drink a dash of cosmopolitan elegance on top of its genteel roots.As if the Kentucky Derby wasn't fancy enough, the Champagne Julep is the perfect cocktail for any black-tie viewing party, New Year's Eve bash, or other occasion that might benefit from a festively effervescent drink. Even if you're not the biggest fan of bourbon, this cocktail is softer than the classic julep, so it should appeal to everyone.

ingredients.name: Tsp Superfine Sugar (Or 0.5 Oz Simple Syrup)

instructions.description: In a julep cup, gently muddle the mint leaves and the sugar or simple syrup (if using sugar, also add a few drops of water to help with dissolution).
Fill cup three-quarters of the way with crushed ice.
Add bourbon and stir very gently.
Add more crushed ice.
Add champagne.
Top the cup with a dome of crushed ice, garnish with a sprig of mint, and serve.

name: Watermelon Paloma
description: The Watermelon Paloma is a twist on the classic Paloma cocktail that employs watermelon and seltzer instead of grapefruit soda. This change results in a tall glass of refreshment that will keep you hydrated on hot days. Throw in some cilantro and salt, and you get a savory foil to the thirst-quenching watermelon. So all throughout summer, mix up a Watermelon Paloma, drink one down, and repeat as necessary.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass, excluding seltzer, and shake vigorously with ice.
Add seltzer, then double strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with a watermelon wedge, and rim the glass with paprika sea salt.

name: Old Hat
description: Old Hat is a whiskey cocktail that was cooked up at Bull in China, a barware shop in Portland, Oregon. Turns out, they can create more than just bar tools and mixing glasses, as evidenced by what we've got here.Old Hat begins with Uncle Nearest 1856, a Tennessee whiskey that pays homage to Nathan “Nearest” Green. Considered the Godfather of Tennessee Whiskey, it was Green who first taught a young, orphaned Jack Daniel how to distill whiskey all those years ago.From there, you get a well-balanced mix of maple syrup, allspice dram, and bitters, plus a pinch of salt to further bring out those flavors.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice.
Stir to chill, then strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
Garnish with an orange peel.

name: French 125
description: A French 125 is a twist on the classic French 75, but instead of using gin, it is a brandy-based cocktail. It has a sweet and sour flavor with a refreshing carbonation.

instructions.description: Pour brandy and sweet and sour into a collins glass over ice cubes and stir well. Fill with chilled champagne and stir lightly. Add the slice of lemon and serve.

name: Vodka Greyhound
description: The Vodka Greyhound is a simple variation on the Greyhound, made with vodka (obviously) instead of the traditional gin. It's typically served on the rocks in either a Highball glass or an Old-Fashioned glass, and almost literally couldn't be easier to make. As always, we recommend squeezing your own grapefruit juice instead of using the store-bought stuff—it just tastes fresher. If you feel like salting the rim, you can easily turn this into a Salty Dog.

instructions.description: Add vodka and grapefruit juice to a Highball glass or Old-Fashioned glass over ice and stir.
Garnish with a grapefruit twist (optional) and serve.

name: Cosmocello
description: The Cosmocello is a simple variation on the original Cosmopolitan recipe that substitutes limoncello in place of the fresh lime juice. Thanks to that extra citrusy kick, you don't really need to use citrus-flavored vodka, but you're welcome to if you're so inclined.

instructions.description: Add vodka, Cointreau, limoncello, and cranberry juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Not Your Daddy's Manhattan
description: There's more than one way to make a Manhattan. Some prefer bourbon, while others choose rye. Your sweet vermouth options are nearly endless, especially if you consider other forms of fortified wine. And then you've got your bitters. Angostura is the most obvious choice, but mixing things up is an easy way to tweak the cocktail.Here we've got a mostly classic version from STK Downtown, the New York steakhouse. The barkeeps are using George Dickel Rye alongside the rich and flavorful Carpano Antica Formula, an Italian sweet vermouth. All that is accented with two types of bitters—Angostura and Peychaud's. It's an easy riff on the classic recipe, and one that Manhattan fans are damn near guaranteed to enjoy.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

name: Michelada
description: The Michelada blends two great brunch-cocktail qualities: it's bubbly, and it's savory. Less sweet than a Mimosa and less boozy than a Bloody Mary, this is a great excuse to drink beer at any time of day. Plus, Michelada is just so dang fun to say you'll find yourself ordering them just to tell people about it.

instructions.description: Rub the edge of a pint glass with your lime wedge, then rim it with a mixture of salt and cayenne pepper.
Add lime juice, Tabasco, Worcestershire sauce, celery salt, and ground black pepper to the glass.
Fill with a Mexican lager like Modelo, Tecate, or any other brand of your choosing.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

Stir well with ice. Strain into a prechilled cocktail glass. Very pleasant with an onion stuffed olive. Some bartenders pour a soucon of Absinthe into the glass, swirl it around and then add the martini.

name: Old-Fashioned
description: The Old-Fashioned cocktail is a simple drink, consisting of bourbon whiskey or rye whiskey, sugar or simple syrup, Angostura bitters, and an orange twist, over ice.The cocktail dates back to the turn of the nineteenth century, the very dawn of the word “cocktail” itself—and is often regarded as the most essential of the classic cocktails, if not the best-known whiskey drink of all time. James Beard, the well-known American culinary icon, considered the Old-Fashioned one of the best of cocktails.Classic Old-Fashioned Cocktail RecipeCocktail aficionados have long argued about the "proper" recipe for an Old-Fashioned. Sugar cube or simple syrup? Orange twist or muddled fruit? A large cube of ice or something else? At Bevvy, our preferred Old-Fashioned calls for the simpler formula of the "classic recipe"—consisting of whiskey, sugar, and bitters over a large cubed ice—there'll be no muddled fruit or bright cherries. That being said, the recipe below is very close to what people would have been drinking back when it was first invented in the 1800s.This Old-Fashioned recipes call for building your drink in the glass, but an alternate method involves stirring the ingredients with ice in a mixing glass before straining them into the serving glass.Who invented the Old-Fashioned cocktail?Among those that have laid claim to inventing the Old-Fashioned, the Pendennis Club in Louisville, Kentucky may be the best known and has been credited to have created the drink—but this claim has been debunked. Many other attempted claims have also been debunked, some due to strange recipes, others to date and timeline inconsistencies.The first known recipe for the Old-Fashioned is from a Chicago bartender named Theodore Proulx, in his book The Bartender's Manual, but even still a connection has never been made that Chicago was the Old-Fashioned's birthplace, nor Proulx the creator.So who did invent the Old-Fashioned? We may never know for sure. As Robert Simonson said in his book The Old-Fashioned: The Story of the World's First Classic Cocktail, with Recipes and Lore: "[The history of] the Old-Fashioned is a much more complicated case. Being an outgrowth of the Whiskey Cocktail, it evolved more than it arrived. Claiming that one bartender created it is a bit like saying a single person invented jazz."

ingredients.name: Sugar Cube Or 0.25 Oz Simple Syrup

instructions.description: Add sugar cube, Angostura bitters, and optionally a few drops of warm water to the bottom of an Old-Fashioned glass and muddle until the sugar is dissolved (alternatively, just add simple syrup and bitters).
Add the whiskey.
Add one large ice cube and stir gently.
Garnish with an orange twist and serve.

name: Vodka Piña Colada
description: A Vodka Piña Colada (also known as a "Chi Chi") is a simple riff on the classic Piña Colada that uses vodka as the base spirit instead of rum. From there, you're still employing coconut cream and pineapple juice as your mixers, and serving the drink in a Hurricane glass, if you've got one. If not, any tall glass will do. The Vodka Piña Colada can be shaken with ice and then served with ice in your glass. Or it can be blended. If you'd like to do the latter, just add all of your ingredients to a blender with ice, and blend until smooth. Garnish with a slice of pineapple and an optional cherry, and you're ready to enjoy this fun and tropical cocktail.

instructions.description: Add ingredients to a shaker with crushed ice, and shake well.
Strain over ice into a piña colada glass.
Garnish with a slice of pineapple and optionally a cherry, and serve with a straw.

name: The Amethyst
description: The Amethyst cocktail is inspired by Greek mythology. The ancient Greeks believed that amethyst (from the word "amethystos") had the power to ward off drunkenness. We've come up with a cocktail that uses vodka, maraschino liqueur, crème de violette, and Dubonnet to do just the opposite. Allow us to present to you: The Amethyst.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled, about 30 seconds.
Strain into a large Martini glass.

name: Scarlet Hour
description: Port has a reputation as a warm-weather drink—something you sip fireside in your smoking jacket, perhaps with a nice cigar. But unless you're drinking the old, heavy, sipping ports, don't hesitate to throw this bold punch of flavor into your next cocktail.The Scarlet Hour combines the five-year-old Sandeman Porto Founders Reserve with two kinds of rum, lime, grapefruit, and cinnamon syrup for a refreshing tiki-style drink that hits all the right notes. It's boozy, it's tart, and it's packed with a myriad of dark fruit flavors—both of the rum and port variety. So you don't have to wait for winter. Mix up the Scarlet Hour any time of the year.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into a chilled Old-Fashioned glass.
Garnish with a lime wheel.

name: Hanky Panky
description: The Hanky Panky cocktail is a pre-Prohibition drink made with gin, sweet vermouth, and fernet. It's an exceedingly simple recipe, and draws on the early gin-and-vermouth framework of the Martini and Martinez.The Hanky Panky was invented by famed Savoy Hotel bartender Ada "Coley" Coleman, who was quoted in 1925 with its origin story:"The late Charles Hawtrey... was one of the best judges of cocktails that I knew. Some years ago, when he was overworking, he used to come into the bar and say, 'Coley, I am tired. Give me something with a bit of punch in it.' It was for him that I spent hours experimenting until I had invented a new cocktail. The next time he came in, I told him I had a new drink for him. He sipped it, and, draining the glass, he said, 'By Jove! That is the real hanky-panky!' And Hanky-Panky it has been called ever since."

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with an orange twist and serve.

name: Death in the Afternoon
description: Ostensibly invented by Ernest Hemingway, this cocktail shares a name with the author's classic treatise on bullfighting. The drink is simply made by combining absinthe and champagne together in a glass, but Pernod or another anise-flavored liqueur is a good substitute when real absinthe is not available.The Death in the Afternoon is easy-to-make, effervescent, and potent. Drink too many of these during the day, and you might not make it to the evening.
