instructions.description: Add the absinthe to a Champagne flute or coupe.
Top with chilled Champagne.

name: Milano-Torino
description: The Milano-Torino is a classic Italian cocktail and a predecessor to the Negroni that features equal parts of Martini Rosso sweet vermouth and Campari.

instructions.description: Add vermouth and Campari to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice and stir.
Garnish with an orange twist.

name: The Chilton
description: The Chilton is an easy-to-make, three-ingredient drink that combines vodka with fresh lemon juice and soda water. It allegedly hails from West Texas, possibly the city of Lubbock, where legend says that it was first concocted by a Lubbock Country Club bartender for one Dr. Chilton. The good doctor wanted a drink that was strong, citrusy, and not too sweet, and this is certainly that.Whether or not that origin story is true, the drink has particular sway in West Texas, and it's easy to see why. The Chilton is bright and refreshing, exactly what you need to cool down on a hot day. There's no sugar in the Chilton recipe, so it drinks very dry. But the salted rim gives the effect of a salted lemonade with each thirsty sip.

instructions.description: Rim a tall glass with salt, and fill with ice.
Add vodka and lemon juice, then top with soda water.
Stir gently, and serve.

name: The Highview
description: Uncle Nearest Whiskey was inspired by the best whiskey-maker the world never knew, and the first African-American master distiller on record in the US, Nathan “Nearest” Green. He taught Jack Daniel how to distill, so clearly he's had a major impact on the whiskey world.The whiskey itself makes for a good sipper, but it also works well in cocktails. Case in point: the Highview that you see here. It's named after the cemetery in which Green is buried and comes from California barkeep Nick Priedite, who whipped this up for The Lark in Santa Barbara. The cocktail combines Uncle Nearest with Italicus (a bergamot-flavored aperitif) and Branca Menta, the minty cousin to Fernet-Branca. It's strong and complex, but still refreshing—perfect for a late-summer drink or to fortify yourself against the colder months to come.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
Stir to dilute and chill, then strain into an Old-Fashioned glass with a large piece of ice.
Express oils from a Meyer lemon peel above the cocktail, then drop into the drink.

name: New York Sour
description: The New York Sour is a 19th-century classic that riffs on the sour drink template of spirit, sugar, and citrus. But here, we're upping the ante with a float of dry red wine. It's a fine way to combine your vices, and it looks great, too. So mix up some New York Sours and impress your house guests, or just keep them all to yourself.

instructions.description: If using egg white: Add whiskey, lemon juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a cocktail shaker WITHOUT ice and shake well for 30 seconds to one minute. Then add ice to shaker and shake until chilled.
If not using egg white: Add whiskey, lemon juice, and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Double-strain into an Old-fashioned glass over ice, or into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
Float the red wine on top, using an upside down barspoon to help with layering as necessary.
Garnish with a lemon twist, and serve.

name: The Grove Keeper
description: The Grove Keeper is a rich, flavorful cocktail that features a delicious homemade apricot syrup and a heavy, meringue-like foam. The sweetness of the apricot syrup is balanced by a small amount of Campari, which gives the drink an amazingly rich color.

ingredients.name: Juice Of Half A Lemon (0.75 Oz)

instructions.description: Add the ingredients to a cocktail shaker without ice and shake until foamy.
Add ice and shake for a second time, hard.
Strain into a chilled martini glass and garnish with a slice of apricot.

name: Hula Daiquiri
description: The Hula Daiquiri hails from NYC bar, Savanna Rooftop. It's a fun take on the Daiquiri (rum, lime, sugar) that begins with Plantation Pineapple Rum. From there, the tropical base is sweetened with creamy, coconut-y Coco Lopez and a hint of Hawaiian Punch, which lends some color. Fresh lime keeps the sweetness in check and a dash of coconut water adds extra refreshment.Call for the Hula Daiquiri at Savanna Rooftop, or try mixing one up at home with the below recipe. It's not quite the same as an island vacation, but it's a lot easier to come by on a random Thursday night.

instructions.description: Shake or blend all ingredients with ice.
Serve with a pineapple slice in a tall glass.

name: The Communist
description: While there's nothing particularly communistic about the Communist cocktail (nor is it even particularly red), this is a great, simple, orange juice-based drink that's sure to be a crown pleaser. This recipe is slightly adjust from the original, so as to reduce a bit of the sourness and add some bitter notes.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and serve.
Shake all ingredients well in a shaker half-filled with ice cubes.
Strain into a Nick and Nora glass, and serve.
To make the cocktail, shake all ingredients except ginger beer and strain over fresh ice into rocks glass. Top with ginger beer, and garnish with a Thai chili pepper.
For infused Pavan* blend 2 orange bell peppers and 5 thai chili peppers with 750ml of Pavan, then fine strain. Keep refrigerated.

name: Turf Club
description: From the eponymous Turf Club in Manhattan, circa 1884, this cocktail is an early predecessor of the Martini. Originally made with equal parts Old Tom gin and sweet vermouth, the Turf Club also works well with juniper-heavy gins.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until chilled and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

name: G & Tea
description: Embrace your inner Briton with this very English cocktail. The G &Tea combines two quintessential British staples, gin and tea, into one topic-topped package. It begins with a base of the modern and unique London No. 1 Gin,  which includes aromas of balsamic and juniper berries, plus a long, dry finish that highlights the botanicals. Pair that with some Earl Grey Tea, fizzy tonic water, and a hint of St Germain for floral sweetness, and you've got a quaffable cocktail perfect for sipping all year long.

instructions.description: Shake first three ingredients with ice, then strain into an Old-Fashioned glass with fresh ice.
Top with tonic water, and garnish with lavender sprigs.

name: Star Fucker
description: Despite the name—or perhaps because of it—the Star Fucker is a popular cocktail. Combining Canadian whisky, watermelon liqueur, and Red Bull, it's typically served as a shot. The drink is potent, sweet, and caffeinated, so everything one needs to keep a lively night going.The recipe below makes two servings, because, let's be honest: no one should be drinking a Star Fucker alone.

instructions.description: Add Red Bull, Crown, and Pucker to a shaker with ice.
Shake, then strain into a double shot glass.

name: Irish Breakfast Shot
description: The Irish Breakfast shot (sometimes called an Irish Pancake Breakfast) is one of the stranger cocktails we've come across, but it turns out to be a real thing that has enjoyed some rising popularity over the years. The recipe features Irish whiskey and butterscotch schnapps in one glass, and orange juice in another. The orange juice in the Irish Breakfast recipe is meant to be served separately as a chaser, and consumed immediately following the main shot.Notes of maple syrup, pancakes, toast, and (literally) bacon in the Irish Breakfast shot bring back pleasant memories of Nanna's kitchen in the countryside, and for a sweet moment, you'd swear this truly is the Breakfast of Champions.

instructions.description: Pour the Irish whiskey and butterscotch schnapps into the first shot glass.
Pour the orange juice into the second shot glass.
Serve both shots with the bacon on a separate small plate.
Alternatively, swap 1 or more shot glasses with old-fashioned glasses, and use the bacon as a garnish.

name: French Cosmopolitan
description: The French Cosmopolitan cocktail is a variation on the original Cosmopolitan recipe that uses Grand Marnier instead of Cointreau as the orange liqueur, and is topped with a small dash of grenadine. You can garnish it with either an orange, lemon, or lime twist to give it some nice hints of essential citrus oils and an extra bit of color.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange, lemon, or lime twist and serve.

ingredients.name: London Dry Gin (Bombay Sapphire Is A Popular Choice)

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients well with ice.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and serve.
Shake ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice. Strain into glass.

name: Escorpión
description: Jettison in Dallas is a champion of all things sherry and mezcal, and given that it's attached to a coffee shop, they don't shy away from infusing coffee into their cocktails, either. But it's this mezcal-and-tequila-spiked drink that's grabbed our attention of late. The Escorpión combines the aforementioned agave spirits, plus apricot liqueur, citrus, bitters, and orgeat for a smoky, tiki-inspired drink that's perfect for fighting the summer heat.That said, the cocktail gives off some heat of its own via a lime shell full of flaming 151-proof rum. So... be sure to blow that out before drinking, lest you lose an eyebrow.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients into a shaker, and shake with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over crushed ice.
Sprinkle cinnamon powder on top.
Garnish with a citrus peel circle filled with 151 rum, and set on fire.
Blow out fire before drinking!

name: Aviation Cocktail
description: The Aviation cocktail is a gin-based cocktail that is spirit-forward with citrus notes and a hint of lavender. It's considered by some to be a variation on the Gin Sour, and is similar to the Blue Moon cocktail, the Moonlight cocktail, and the Casino cocktail. The Aviation cocktail was invented by Hugo Ensslin, a bartender at the Hotel Wallick in New York in the early 1900's, and first appeared in his 1916 book Recipes for Mixed Drinks. The crème de violette gives the Aviation a pale, sky-blue color (hence the name).

instructions.description: Add the gin, maraschino liqueur, crème de violette, and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker and shake until chilled, about 30 seconds.
Strain into a cocktail glass, garnish with a cherry (optional), and serve.
Pour the ingredients over ice, allow it to chill for a moment and then strain into a red wine glass.
Garnish with an orange and serve.

Warm the bottle of Midori so that it is hot to the touch, by first loosening the cap half way, then set the entire bottle in a saucepan half full of water on high heat. Meanwhile, bring 1 cup of water to a rolling boil then stir in the Jello and Gelatin until dissolved. Stir in hot Midori. Pour mixture into a flat bottom pan and slice into cubes when cooled, or place in small cups.

name: Midori Sour
description: The Midori Sour is a popular cocktail distinguished by its melon flavor and bright green color. Originating in the disco clubs of the late 1970s, the Midori Sour enjoyed an impressive run through the '80s and '90s. Today, it has lost some of its original luster, especially as bars and consumers have moved toward craft cocktails. But it deserves an appreciative nod for its ubiquity over the decades, as it served millions of drinkers across the globe.What's in a Midori Sour?The Midori Sour cocktail is a riff on classic sour cocktails, a family of mixed drinks that contain a base spirit, citrus, and a sweetener.The traditional Midori Sour features Midori Melon Liqueur—a Japanese honeydew melon liqueur produced by Suntory, plus a sour component, sugar and club soda. The liqueur is where the cocktail gets its name. It also happens to be where it gets its color, as "midori" is the Japanese word for green. Midori liqueur is quite sweet. And many drinks originating in the 1970s and '80s, including the Midori Sour, called for sour mix—typically from a soda gun—which is cloyingly sweet, artificially sour and just not great. Fortunately, bartenders since then have embraced fresh ingredients during the modern craft cocktail renaissance.These days, creative bartenders are making efforts to update the Midori Sour recipe. This usually includes skipping the bottled, store-bought sour mix in favor of fresh juices, which creates a markedly better drink.The New Midori SourFor the Midori Sour recipe below, we use fresh lemon juice combined with simple syrup to make homemade sour mix. Our preference here is to use lemons, but you can also mix lemon and lime juice in a 50/50 ratio for a lemon-lime kick. Experiment with the citrus to see which taste you prefer.Once your ingredients are set, pour everything except the soda water into a rocks glass or Collins glass, add ice, and stir. There's no need to shake this drink in a cocktail shaker, as that brings in extra dilution that will alter the balance of the cocktail.Optionally, you may add an ounce of vodka to the mix if you want a stronger drink, since the melon liqueur is a lower-proof alcohol.Finally, add a splash of soda water to add refreshing effervescence and to temper the sweetness. Some cocktail recipes suggest using a lemon lime soda, such as Sprite, but we don't recommend going that route, as it will alter the flavor and add more sugar to the recipe.The cocktail may now be served as-is, or if you wish to garnish your Midori Sour, feel free to add a lemon wedge, lime slice or even a maraschino cherry. Whatever makes you happy.

instructions.description: Build directly in the glass by adding Midori liqueur, lemon juice, and simple syrup to a rocks glass or Collins glass.
Add ice, top with club soda, and stir to combine.

name: Perfect Daiquiri
description: BlackTail is one of the best drinking establishments in New York, and therefore, the world. This rum-fueled haven channels old-world Cuba, a place flush in Daiquiris. And BlackTail just so happens to make a great one, opting to concoct their with a quartet of rums.That quartet consists of four parts Cana Brava 3 Year, three parts Plantation 3 Star, two parts Barbancourt White, and one part El Dorado 3 Year. So it's something you can recreate at home, if you've got a well-stocked rum cabinet.Says BlackTail Head Bartender Jesse Vida: "We made the Cuban Rum blend to represent a style of rum that no longer exists. Through researching old menus and styles from the early 1900s, we made a balanced blend of rums from what's available in the current market."

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice, and strain into a sour glass.

name: Pearl Harbor
description: The Pearl Harbor is an easy-to-make, easy-to-drink cocktail that combines vodka, melon liqueur, and pineapple juice. Simply shake all three with ice, and strain into your glass. The tropical-tasting Pearl Harbor is fruity, a little sweet, and very refreshing on warm days.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
Shake until chilled, then strain into a Highball or Old-Fashioned glass with fresh ice.

name: Brandy Old-Fashioned
description: The Brandy Old-Fashioned is a variation on the classic Old-Fashioned made with brandy (obviously) instead of whiskey, and explicitly calls for muddling an orange slice and a cherry in the bottom of the glass along with the simple syrup and Angostura bitters.The Brandy Old-Fashioned is a contentious drink. For some Old-Fashioned purists, it represents an affront to all the progress made in the last few years of the cocktail renaissance.But for others, particularly those from its home state of Wisconsin, it's a classic that deserves recognition in its own right. Our verdict? This is a separate drink entirely, and that's just fine. That said, you're free to break the rules. If you'd like to use brandy but are a staunch member of the no-fruit camp, go for it—the result is spirited and more akin to the whiskey-spiked version.

instructions.description: Muddle orange slice, maraschino cherry, simple syrup, and bitters in the bottom of an Old-Fashioned glass.
Add ice.
Add brandy, stir gently, and serve.

name: Mango Mojito
description:
The Mango Mojito is a popular variation on the Mojito. You'll find this recipe being used in parts of Palm Beach County, Florida and Crested Butte, Colorado.

If the standard Mojito wasn’t enough to get you in a tropical state of mind, this fruity twist will definitely do the trick.

instructions.description: Muddle the mint leaves and lime wedge in the bottom of an old-fashioned glass.
Add Cruzan mango rum and club soda as above or adjusted to taste.
Add ice cubes, and serve.

name: Ramos Gin Fizz
description: One of those great classic cocktails that are simply amazing when properly made, the Ramos Gin Fizz is a citrus-forward cocktail — deliciously balanced between sweet, sour, and acidity — with a foamy yet airy mouthfeel.The Ramos Gin Fizz cocktail has a storied history. Invented at the Imperial Cabinet Saloon in New Orleans in 1888 by Henry C. Ramos, the Ramos Gin Fizz was originally called the New Orleans Fizz before being eponymously known for its creator.The Ramos Gin Fizz is not an easy drink to make. Aside from the long list of ingredients (including the irreplaceable but harder to find orange flower water), the light silky texture of the cocktail requires vigorous shaking to aerate the cream and egg white combo. Legend has it that Henry Ramos employed dozens of "shaker boys" whose sole purpose is to shake orders of Ramos Gin Fizz after the bartender has prepared the drink, for as long as 12 minutes by some accounts!Perhaps due to the immense and almost immediate popularity of the cocktail when it was first introduced, the Ramos Gin Fizz recipe was rumored to be a closely guarded secret. However, once America entered Prohibition, the recipe became publicly available which we are thankful for today.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients (except the seltzer/soda) to a shaker filled with cracked ice, and shake vigorously for 5-6 minutes (Wondrich's recipe calls for 2 minutes but we prefer the longer shake time here at Bevvy).
Strain into a chilled Collins glass, and top with the seltzer water (or club soda).

name: White Walker
description: The latest season of Game of Thrones may be over, but that doesn't mean you can't break out this White Walker cocktail inspired by the show. Because White Walkers are scary, and it's Halloween time.This drink comes from Hemant Pathak at Junoon restaurant in NYC. Starting with a base of blended scotch and applejack, it's got a lot going on--including citrus, spicy Ancho Reyes, silky egg white and an absinthe rinse, for good measure.The scotch requires an infusion, which is actually pretty easy. And considering you'll be infusing a whole bottle of Dewar's, you'll have plenty of scotch on hand for all your friends.

instructions.description: For cocktail: Rinse a coupe glass with absinthe, and discard the excess. Add all other ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake. Strain into that coupe.
* For Dewar's Infusion: Infuse all ingredients together for two hours, then strain through the cheese cloth.

name: Jack Rose
description: The Jack Rose is one of the six basic drinks David Embury listed in his book The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks, and rose to prominence in the Roaring 20s (and 30s). It was a favorite drink of noted author John Steinbeck, and the Jack Rose also made an appearance in Ernest Hemingway's novel The Sun Also Rises.Made with applejack, lemon or lime juice, and grenadine—the latter giving it a rose-colored hue (quite possibly giving it its name despite other theories)—the Jack Rose cocktail has fallen out of fashion over the years. Nevertheless, it's still a delicious cocktail, which is good enough for us.

instructions.description: Shake well with ice.
Strain into a cocktail glass or coupe glass, and serve.
Garnish with a lemon or lime twist (we've also seen wedges used, and even cherries or apple slices).

name: Grass Is Greener
description: Turns out, fresh-pressed wheatgrass isn't just for doing shots at smoothie places. It's also for adding a healthy, vegetal kick to your cocktails. The Grass is Greener combines easy-going vodka with wheatgrass, lime, agave, and mint for a healthy cocktail that pairs nicely with your breakfast. Drink one down to start your day, or anytime you want to infuse some wheatgrass into your life without giving up the vodka.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain into a short rocks glass with no ice.
Garnish with a sliced watermelon radish and serve.

name: Southside
description: The Southside is a refreshing cocktail that lands somewhere between a Mojito and a Gimlet. It takes the mint and soda water of the former, and the gin of the latter, to create a delicious hybrid. Then again, maybe it's more of a mint-spiked Tom Collins. No matter how you want to look at it, the Southside is a popular summer cocktail that you'll find dotting country club menus all over the northeastern U.S.Its favor among the preppy sporting class eventually expanded, and now you can find the Southside in cocktail bars across the country. Seek it out, or make one for yourself, and you'll see why it's been enjoyed for decades. The mixture of gin, citrus, mint, and soda is a winning combination that you can drink all summer long.

instructions.description: In a cocktail shaker, gently muddle 6-8 mint leaves with simple syrup.
Add remaining ingredients (except soda) and ice cubes, and shake well.
Strain into a chilled coupe, top with soda, and garnish with a mint leaf.

ingredients.name: Homemade Spiced Syrup (Cinnamon, Star Anise, Cloves)

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a dusting of cinnamon and a single star anise, and serve with chocolate coffee beans.
Shake ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a sprig of mint, and serve.

name: Green Machine
description: The Green Machine is a simple two-part cocktail composed of gin and green juice. Now, if you make that juice for yourself, well, that adds a few more ingredients to the mix. But with juice places popping up on nearly every block, you're just a quick stop (and about $8) away from securing some green juice of your own.If you're going the at-home route, try juicing a handful of kale, spinach, celery, and parsley, plus an apple to sweeten things up.The result is a very refreshing and easy-to-drink cocktail that's perfect for brunch or anytime you need a little vitamin-packed pick-me-up... spiked with gin.

instructions.description: Blend apple, lemon, and assorted greens to create the "green juice," then fine strain it into an Old-Fashioned glass with ice.
Add Tanqueray No. TEN and stir.
Garnish with a mint sprig and serve.

name: Irish Mule
description: The Irish Mule cocktail is a simple Moscow Mule variation, made with Irish whiskey as the base spirit instead of the traditional vodka. It's similar in character to the Kentucky Mule, with its slightly sweet, malty whiskey (depending on the brand you use, of course), but this one's a little more at home on St. Patrick's Day.When it comes to the Irish Mule, we suggest using a dry, spicy ginger beer, as a sweet one can be cloying (especially in concert with the Irish whiskey). Fentimans or Reed's work great, but even if you can't find those, make sure that you're using ginger beer, never ginger ale. Otherwise it's not an Irish Mule.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mug (preferably copper) or Collins glass with ice, garnish with a lime wedge, and enjoy.

name: Gold Rush
description: The Gold Rush is a modern classic that first reared its head at New York's famed Milk & Honey bar circa the mid-2000s. Composed of just three ingredients—bourbon, lemon, and honey—the Gold Rush is a blessed hybrid that merges the Whiskey Sour (whiskey, lemon, sugar) and the Bee's Knees (gin, lemon, honey).This synergistic trio of components results in an easygoing cocktail that's simple to make at home, whether you're shaking to order or batching in bulk for a party. Just remember that, given the few ingredients, there's nowhere to hide. So be sure to employ a good bourbon and fresh lemon juice.

instructions.description: To make honey syrup, combine equal parts honey and hot water until honey is dissolved. Let cool before use.
Shake bourbon, lemon juice and honey syrup with ice.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice, and serve.
Stir over ice cubes in a mixing glass, and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Serve with a glass of ice water.
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Hawaiian Screw
description: The Hawaiian Screw is reminiscent of a screwdriver, but with a tropical twist. Experiment with different combinations of fruit juices for a variety of flavors. The Hawaiian Screw can also be enjoyed up by shaking and straining into a coupe glass.

instructions.description: Pour vodka over ice into an old-fashioned glass. Add pineapple and orange juice to taste.

name: Hot Buttered Rum
description: There are few cocktails that taste better on a chilly fall or winter evening than Hot Buttered Rum. Featuring a delicious, spiced buttery batter, dark rum, and hot water or apple cider (we prefer the cider, because why miss a chance for flavor?), variations on this Hot Buttered Rum recipe date all the way back to the colonial Americas. If it was enough to keep the pilgrims warm through the winter, we think it'll probably do the trick for you, too.

instructions.description: First, you'll need to make the batter: combine butter, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves in a bowl and mix together thoroughly. Place in the refrigerator until it's mostly firm. (This makes enough for about 6 servings.)
Spoon 2-3 oz of batter into each mug.
Add dark rum.
Fill the mug with boiling water or hot apple cider.
Stir and serve.

name: Manhattan
description: The Manhattan cocktail is simple, elegant and sophisticated. Included on the IBA (International Bartender Association) list of official cocktails, it's a true classic, right up there with other favorites like the Old Fashioned, Negroni and Martini. Since its creation, the Manhattan has has remained a favorite among bartenders around the world. But while the classic recipe is still beloved, the drink has spurred many popular variations that have attained their own following and fame.What's in a Manhattan Cocktail?The Manhattan recipe calls for three ingredients—whiskey, sweet vermouth and bitters—plus a garnish.For the best Manhattan cocktails, we like using a good rye whiskey, but many drinkers use bourbon or other types of whiskey. Feel free to experiment with your favorite brands, and take note of the nuances each plays in creating the drink's overall flavor profile. Some folks prefer the sweeter flavor of bourbon, while others like the spicier flavor of rye. Both spirits make great drinks.When choosing your sweet vermouth, reach for a top-quality bottle, such as Noilly Prat Rouge, Carpano Antica, or Dolin Rouge, to bring additional depth to the cocktail. The classic Manhattan recipe also calls for two to three dashes of Angostura bitters, which lend balance and complexity.As for the garnish, most people opt for a cherry (or occasionally an orange peel), but stay away from the bright, fluorescent options commonly found on top of sundaes. Instead, choose a gourmet offering, like a jar of Luxardo cherries. They're more expensive, but they're worth it, turning the garnish into a delicious treat that complements the total package, rather than a simple afterthought.Manhattan VariationsPopular variations of the Manhattan cocktail include the Rob Roy, which uses scotch instead of American whiskey, the Perfect Manhattan, which uses equal parts sweet and dry vermouth, and the Brandy Manhattan, which substitutes brandy for whiskey.Still other recipe variations include a host of New York-named drinks, like the Red Hook and the Brooklyn, which are classics in their own right. Both call for a dash of maraschino liqueur, while the latter uses dry vermouth instead of sweet vermouth. The Manhattan template is ripe for experimentation, so you're likely to find a unique spin on the classic recipe on bar menus all over the world.How to make a Manhattan CocktailThe classic Manhattan cocktail is a stirred drink that's traditionally served up. Add two ounces of whiskey, one ounce of sweet vermouth, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass with fresh ice, and stir until the liquids are properly chilled. Then strain the contents into a pre-chilled cocktail glass (a coupe glass or Nick and Nora glass will also work nicely here), and finally garnish with a maraschino cherry.Note the drink is stirred, not shaken. Shaking a Manhattan introduces too much dilution into the cocktail and also affects the drink's texture, creating little ice shards that ruin the silky smooth aesthetic. So put the cocktail shaker away, and instead grab a bar spoon and mixing glass.Who invented the Manhattan Cocktail?The Manhattan cocktail traces its roots to the late 19th century and was likely invented in New York City, hence the name. The famed Manhattan Club claims that it created the first Manhattan, and this may be true. One reports says that it was stirred into creation at a party for Lady Randolph Churchill (Winston Churchill's mother) in 1874, but research by cocktail historian David Wondrich seems to disprove the story. More likely, the Manhattan as we know it came about sometime in the 1860s or 1870s. It's easy to imagine the cocktail popping up at multiple places during this period, as whiskey, sweet vermouth and bitters were all popular and readily available.Regardless of when it was first concocted, this is one of the most legendary whiskey cocktails in the world. Try one today and see why, 150 years after its creation, it's just as popular as ever.

instructions.description: Add the whiskey, sweet vermouth and bitters into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cherry, orange twist, or nothing at all.

name: Black Forest
description: The Black Forest cocktail features chilled espresso to give you an extra kick and help out with those particularly groggy mornings. There are several different recipes for this drink, but this one comes from the original, 1947 edition of the Angostura Professional Mixing Guide.

instructions.description: Combine all of the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled champagne flute.
Let settle until only a small head of foam remains on the top.
Garnish with a coffee bean and serve.

name: Campari and Soda
description: The Campari and Soda is a simple, refreshing Italian cocktail that's perfect for sipping on a hot summer day. It's made with the beloved (but divisive) liqueur Campari, a bitter amaro that Italians say you have to try three times before you'll like it. This is similar to an Americano, but minus the sweet vermouth, so it's a bit lower in alcohol content and makes for a great midday drink.

instructions.description: Add Campari to a Highball glass with ice.
Fill with soda, garnish with an orange twist (optional), and serve.

name: Pegu Club
description: The Pegu Club cocktail is a classic of the colonial era and incorporates a few favorite ingredients of the day—namely gin, dry curaçao and fresh lime, plus bitters.The cocktail was originally named after the Pegu Club bar in Burma, a British Colonial Officers' hangout and a haven for British drinkers who, thanks to a healthy dose of racism and general snobbery, didn't want to interact with the locals. Membership was limited to those who were unanimously approved by the existing members, determined anonymously by each person placing a white or black marble into a jar. A single black marble meant that the applicant would be denied, giving rise to the phrase "blackballed."In more recent years, the Pegu Club cocktail is most closely affiliated with Audrey Saunders' pioneering New York cocktail bar by the same name, the Pegu Club, an establishment that eschews its forebear's exclusionary practices for a welcoming vibe and expertly-made drinks.The modern Pegu Club's alumni roster is a who's who of the cocktail world, many of whom have gone on to open iconic bars of their own—including Jim Meehan of PDT, Tony Maloney of Violet Hour, Phil Ward of Mayahuel, Chad Solomon of Midnight Rambler, and many others.Sadly, the Pegu Club announced on April 30, 2020 it was closing its doors for good, largely due to devastating conditions for restaurants and bars created by the coronavirus pandemic.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass (traditional) or coupe glass (Bevvy's preference).

name: Glasgow Mule
description: The Glasgow Mule, invented by Damon Boelte of Brooklyn, NY's Prime Meats, is a seriously delicious and creative Moscow Mule variation that features blended scotch whisky, St. Germain, and Angostura bitters along with the standard ginger beer and citrus.

ingredients.name: Lemon Wheel And Piece Of Candied Ginger For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mug (preferably copper) or Collins glass.
Add crushed ice and stir.
Garnish with lemon wheel and ginger and serve.

name: Colorado Bulldog
description: The Colorado Bulldog is an interesting variation on the White Russian, made with vodka, Kahlúa coffee liqueur, cream, and a splash of cola to top it all off. It's a simple recipe, and as a result it's hard to tell exactly where it comes from—like so many other one-ingredient additions or subtractions, the Colorado Bulldog was probably invented many times over before anyone settled on a name. A number of cocktail journalists have put out calls to see who claims to have concocted it first, and if anyone has any idea what this drink has to do with Colorado or bulldogs, but to no avail.As a drink, the Colorado Bulldog is certainly tasty, if a bit indulgent. The combination of cream, cola, and coffee liqueur isn't exactly low-calorie (or "craft," really, depending on your definition), but it makes for an interesting and sultry-sweet blend of creaminess and carbonation. Perfect as a dessert drink, or simply for those who have grown tired of the classic White Russian, the Colorado Bulldog is definitely worth a taste.

instructions.description: Add vodka and Kahlúa to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice.
Add cream.
Top with a splash of cola and serve.

name: Cosmobellini
description: The Cosmobellini is more of a hybrid cocktail than a descendant of any one recipe, combining both the original Cosmopolitan and the Bellini to make something entirely new. Bubbly, fruity, and citrusy, this is an absolutely delicious brunch cocktail that's sure to spice up your menu.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except Prosecco to a cocktail shaker and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled champagne flute.
Top with Prosecco and serve.

name: Adios Motherfucker
description: The Adios Motherfucker cocktail (or the AMF drink, in mixed company), despite its vulgar name, is basically just a Long Island Iced Tea with two ingredients swapped: blue curaçao instead of triple sec, and a splash of lemon-lime soda instead of cola. The name is a holdover from the bad old days of the late 20th century, when cocktails went for shock value over quality. The Adios Motherfucker has long been a favorite at nightclubs, where it's typically viewed as an efficient way to get smashed (despite containing a pretty standard 2 oz of spirits), but in recent years its popularity has waned thanks to the growth of the craft cocktail movement.While electric blue drinks don't have a great reputation among bartenders, the Adios Motherfucker actually goes down pretty easy, all things considered. You can class it up a bit by using fresh lemon juice and simple syrup instead of sour mix (a practice we endorse pretty much unequivocally), but save the nice bottles of booze for something else—a subtle aged rum, a craft gin, and a premium tequila are just going to get lost in the shuffle of the Adios Motherfucker's mixers.

instructions.description: Add vodka, rum, tequila, and gin into a Highball glass filled with ice.
Add lemon juice, simple syrup, and lemon-lime soda.
Top with blue curaçao and serve the AMF drink with a straw.

name: Tom Collins
description: The Tom Collins is a classic summer highball that's perfect for the golf course or a backyard barbecue, made from gin, lemon juice, simple syrup, and club soda. The Tom Collins is served in, you guessed it, a Collins glass, which is narrower than a typical highball. A nice side effect of this glassware is that when you tilt the drink all the way back to get those last few drops, the ice is a lot less likely to spill down the front of your shirt. But hey, come July, that might not be so bad!The origins of the Tom Collins recipe is a bit murky, but it seems likely that it was invented in England sometime in the early 19th century. That said, the Tom Collins cocktail first appeared in print in the 1876 edition of American barman Jerry Thomas' How to Mix Drinks.For a quick changeup, use vodka in place of gin, and you get the easygoing Vodka Collins.

ingredients.name: Maraschino Cherry And Lemon Slice For Garnish

instructions.description: Add the gin, lemon juice, and simple syrup to a Collins glass filled with ice.
Stir.
Fill the rest of the class with club soda.
Garnish with a cherry and lemon slice and serve.

name: Rosa Martini
description: The Rosa Martini takes its name from its base spirit—Código 1530 Rosa Tequila—which is rested for one month in uncharred Napa Cabernet French white oak barrels. Imbued with a light pink color, the tequila sports delicate, wine-y floral notes on top of fresh agave. All that makes for a fine addition to cocktails that you don't have to fuss with too much, as evidenced here. The Rosa Martini is a simple mix of tequila with grapefruit and Angostura bitters. It's easy-to-make, refreshing, and looks great in a glass.

instructions.description: Add ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake and strain into a cocktail glass.

name: Bacardi Cocktail
description: The Bacardi cocktail is a classic that has a balanced blend of sour and sweet with a spirit-forward flavor. Fresh juice rather than sour mix should be used for a tastier drink. The Bacardi Cocktail was originally the same as the Daiquiri, containing rum, lemon juice, and sugar, but then Grenadine was added to the mix.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a shaker half-filled with ice cubes, and shake well.
Strain into a cocktail glass, and serve.

name: Cosmopolitan
description: The Cosmpolitan Cocktail (or Cosmo as it's commonly known) is a relatively simple drink with a big reputation. It was the drink of choice on the hit HBO show "Sex and the City," where it was so frequently referenced by Carrie Bradshaw and her pals that the Cosmopolitan nearly had a persona of its own.Naturally, this pink-hued drink served in a Martini glass became a popular choice in the real world as well, and every night in America, countless bartenders made Cosmopolitans for hordes of thirsty patrons who enjoyed its sweet and tart taste.These days, the Cosmopolitan isn't quite as popular as it was during its heyday in the '90s and early 2000s, and it often gets a bad rap—unfairly, we think. The well-meaning Cosmo is often dismissed due to its color (hey, there's nothing wrong with pink drinks) or considered unsophisticated, but it's actually a classically-styled drink with a solid pedigree. The fact that it hit bar tops during the height of the over-the-top flavored Martini craze helped to popularize the drink, but you can't throw the Cosmo into the same category as the neon green, Apple Pucker-laced Appletini. What's in a Cosmopolitan Cocktail?Most modern versions of the Cosmopolitan recipe are made with citrus-flavored vodka, Cointreau, fresh-squeezed lime juice, and a splash of cranberry juice. You can dress up the glass with an orange twist or lemon twist garnish.Plenty of other Cosmopolitan recipe variations exist, ensuring there's something suitable for a multitude of preferences. The White Cosmo features St. Germain instead of Cointreau, plus white cranberry juice, while the French Cosmopolitan calls for Grand Marnier instead of Cointreau, and it adds a splash of grenadine to the mix. There's even the Cosmocello, a more obscure riff that uses limoncello instead of lemon juice. How to Make a Cosmopolitan CocktailThe Cosmo is easy to make. Add your vodka, Cointreau (or other orange liqueur—usually triple sec), fresh lime juice, and cranberry to a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake until your ingredients are well-chilled, then strain the contents into a Martini glass, aka a cocktail glass, and apply your garnish. The drink should be pink, not red, so if you find the color a bit too dark, you may need to scale back on the cranberry juice.Who invented the Cosmo?Great question. Ask five people and you may get five different answers, but a few origin stories always rise to the top. A version of the drink that commonly featured cheap vodka and bottled lime juice was likely created in the 1980s, with reports pegging it to both coasts—San Francisco bartender John Caine helped to popularize it in his city, while Cheryl Cook made Cosmos in Miami. In 1988, Toby Cecchini at Odeon bar in New York got wind of the drink from friends in San Francisco, and he retooled it with better vodka and fresh juice. His recipe is the cocktail we know from Sex and the City and bar menus all over the world. Bar legend Dale DeGroff sometimes gets the nod for the drink's creation, too, but he's said on the record that he did not create it. He did, however, make plenty of them with good ingredients at his bar in New York, and he added the orange twist garnish.That said, the Cosmo is essentially just a cranberry-dosed Kamikaze. And a different but similar Cosmopolitan cocktail recipe appears as far back as 1934, featuring gin, Cointreau, lemon juice, and raspberry syrup. No matter. You don't need to know all the details to know that the Cosmo is a fun drink with a larger than life reputation.

instructions.description: Add vodka, Cointreau, fresh lime juice, and cranberry juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist or lemon twist.

name: Truly Bitter
description: Truly Spiked & Sparkling is a crisp carbonated water with a hint of fruit. And per the name, it's spiked. In this case, with alcohol derived from cane sugar. It's bottled at 5% ABV. For a very, very simple beverage, you can drink it on its own. But if you'd like to mix up a cocktail, Truly makes a good topper. Here we've got the Truly Bitter, which mixes bittersweet Campari with Cointreau and Truly's Grapefruit & Pomelo flavor. The end result is refreshing and relatively light on alcohol, so you can have a couple and still engage in important activities, like flipping burgers in your backyard, or holding a conversation at the dinner table.

ingredients.name: Juice From One Lemon Or Orange Wedge

instructions.description: Combine first three ingredients in a rocks glass over a single large ice cube.
Top with Truly Spiked & Sparkling Grapefruit & Pomelo.
Garnish with an orange or grapefruit twist.

name: Dark Mojito
description: Here’s another one to add to your Mojito Recipe Files – a Dark Mojito. It’s truly just a slight variation of The Perfect Mojito and a Dirty Mojito and in our opinion, tastes the rummiest of the three! Use a dark rum with a taste that you find pleasant, as the dark rum taste does rise above the milder taste of mint and sugar.

instructions.description: Gently muddle the mint with the lime juice and brown sugar.
Add crushed ice and the rum.
Fill to the top of the glass with club soda.
Garnish with a sprig of mint.

name: Hemingway Daiquiri
description: While the basic Daiquiri might be more classic, the Hemingway Daiquiri is certainly more storied. Apparently, this is the recipe Papa used to order when he was in Cuba, and it was invented specifically at his request. The Hemingway Daiquiri forgoes the sugar of the original (as Hemingway was diabetic), and sets itself apart with grapefruit juice and maraschino liqueur.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice, strain into a chilled cocktail glass, garnish with lime, and serve.

name: White Cosmopolitan
description: The White Cosmopolitan Cocktail (or White Cosmo) is a simple variation on the original Cosmopolitan recipe. It uses white cranberry juice instead of red cranberry juice, giving it a crisp, white color without sacrificing any of the tartness that makes this such an iconic drink. Citrus vodka is recommended, but a standard straight vodka will do just fine.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist and serve.

name: Strawberry Sotol Highball
description: Espita Mezcaleria is a Southern Mexican-inspired restaurant in Washington, DC. Thanks to Beverage Director Megan Barnes and the Espita team, it's also a fine place to drink mezcal, tequila, and other Mexican spirits like sotol, either straight or mixed into cocktails. Cocktails like the Strawberry Sotol Highball.It begins with a house-made strawberry-tarragon syrup, which you can recreate per the recipe below. From there, it's just a simple mix of sotol and lemon. Sotol's green, grassy flavor profile works nicely in drinks, pairing well with fruits and herbs—both things you'll find here.If you're in the neighborhood, stop into Espita Mezcaleria for a cocktail. Maybe even this one. Otherwise, you can try making it for yourself. The syrup, despite the overnight process, is actually quite simple. So provided you live in an area that gets the occasional bottle of sotol on store shelves (and you've got access to a soda siphon), you'll have everything you need.

instructions.description: * Add 500g sugar to one pound diced strawberries. Mix thoroughly and let sit in sealed container overnight. The next day, add 500 ml of 140° water and mix until sugar is dissolved. Strain out strawberries, and steep tarragon in syrup to taste.
Add all ingredients into a soda siphon, and pour into a highball glass over ice.  Garnish with a pineapple leaf.

name: Mimosa
description: The Mimosa is a popular brunch cocktail typically served in a Champagne flute. It is commonly found at events such as weddings, picnics, and other group gatherings, and you often see it being poured on Mother's Day, Christmas, New Year's Day and other special occasions. There's good reason for this: the Mimosa not only tastes good, but it's a low-proof option that's very easy to drink. What's in a Mimosa?The classic Mimosa recipe is very simple with only two ingredients: Champagne and orange juice.A decent dry Champagne will work well, and there's no need to break the bank for an expensive bottle, as any of the wine's more delicate or nuanced flavor notes will be lost in the juice. Cava, Prosecco or another dry sparkling wine will work fine as a substitute when you don't have a bottle of Champagne on hand.Similarly, different types of fruit juices are sometimes used instead of orange juice, such as grapefruit juice, cranberry juice, pineapple juice, pomegranate juice, and even peach puree. Of course, your choice in juice will affect the overall flavor of the cocktail, and it might even change the drink entirely: Prosecco and peach puree is a Bellini, while Champagne and cranberry (plus orange liqueur) is a Poinsettia.For the best Mimosas, we suggest going with a low-pulp or pulp-free orange juice to avoid an overly-thick texture, but do whatever you prefer. Also feel free to experiment with different combinations and your ratio of juices to discover your own favorite Mimosa variations. But the classic Mimosa is classic for a reason: It's simple, clean and refreshing.How to make a Mimosa cocktailThe Mimosa cocktail is very easy to make, which may speak to its popularity and regular appearances at group functions and "self-serve" beverage stations.Start by pouring several ounces of chilled Champagne into a Champagne flute, then top it off with a smaller dose of orange juice. Give it a quick stir if you like, but the heavier weight of the orange juice will help to blend everything together, and the bubbles will soon even out the rest.Champagne flutes work well because of the narrow mouth of the glass, which helps to preserve the carbonation of the Champagne. If you don't have any flutes on hand, white wine glasses work in a pinch. Pro tip: chill your glassware ahead of time.There's some debate among Mimosa "experts" about whether you should add the Champagne or the orange juice to the glass first. For whatever reason, it seems that adding the orange juice first results in some annoyingly persistent foam, even when using a pulp-free orange juice. On the other hand, adding the Champagne first can cause the glass to overflow with effervescence once you add the orange juice. Nevertheless, our inclination is to use the latter method anyway. Start with the bubbles, then pour the juice slowly and carefully—tilting the flute slightly will help to reduce the foam and froth. At this point, the Mimosa is ready to serve.Our preference here is to skip a garnish, because with such a narrow opening on the glass, there's not much room for something like an orange wedge or wheel. It will only act as an impediment to your drinking. A garnish that floats in the glass or sinks to the bottom will move around as you tip the glass to drink, and nobody wants Mimosa splashing on their face when opening gifts at a wedding shower.You can pre-batch your Mimosa cocktails in a large pitcher to help you serve a crowd quickly. But the drink is so easy to make—literally just pouring two liquids into glasses—that making a large batch ahead of time is usually unnecessary. Besides, the large opening of the pitcher will release more carbonation over time, and your Mimosas will be less bright, less bubbly, and less delicious.

instructions.description: Add 4 ounces chilled Champagne to a chilled Champagne flute.
Add 2 ounces of orange juice, and serve.

name: Royal Clover Club Cocktail
description: The Royal Clover Club is a variation on—you guessed it— the Clover Club cocktail recipe. It uses grenadine in place of the raspberry syrup, and an egg yolk in place of the usual egg white (a relatively rare choice in the cocktail world). As a result, the Royal Clover Club is quite a bit less frothy than the original, but it makes up for it with a rich creaminess.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and serve.

name: Liquid Cocaine
description: The Liquid Cocaine is a remnant of the '90s cocktail era—soda guns, sour mix, and drinks with provocative names—that still enjoys some popularity today. There are several varying recipes to be found for the Liquid Cocaine shot, and contrary to what you may have heard from others, we do not agree it's a drink every bartender should know.The peppermint and cinnamon schnapps gives this shooter some brightness in the mouth and some heat to the finish, which may have lent some appeal to the Liquid Cocaine's popularity. As you may have guessed—and despite its incriminating name—this particular Liquid Cocaine drink doesn't have any actual cocaine in it. Instead, it features Jägermeister, cinnamon schnapps, peppermint schnapps and 151-proof rum. The Liquid Cocaine is strong, both in flavor and potency. The below recipe makes enough for two servings, so find an adventurous friend, pour two shots, and enjoy yourself.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
Strain into two shot glasses.

name: 7 and 7
description: A 7 and 7 cocktail (or Seven and Seven cocktail) is an extremely easy mixed drink to make at home, and although it is less popular than it used to be at bars these days, the Seven & Seven still sees a fair share of orders.It is a whiskey-based cocktail typically served in a Collins Glass, but it also works well in a Highball Glass—or any glass will do for that matter—as this is an unpretentious drink, in line with the rum and coke or Jack and Coke. The 7 and 7 has a simple recipe with only two ingredients, from which it derives its name: Seagram's 7 Crown Whiskey (a blended whiskey with Canadian origins) and 7UP or another common lemon-lime soda. You don't have to use Seagram's, but this is the sort of simple drink that shouldn't require your best whiskey to come out to make it. Once an iconic order thanks to Seagram's advertising campaigns, its popularity peaked in the '70s and '80s (helped by appearances in films like Saturday Night Fever and Mean Streets) but has fallen sharply since. However, the current vogue for a throwback drink is surprisingly putting the 7 and 7 back into the cocktail vernacular of modern drinkers. Follow the cocktail recipe below to learn how to make a 7 and 7 for yourself or for a friend.

instructions.description: Build over ice in a Collins or Old-fashioned glass by adding the Seagram's 7 whiskey, followed by the 7UP.
Stir, and serve.

name: Breakfast Martini
description: The Breakfast Martini is the best way to start your morning, provided your morning won't be derailed by some gin. It combines that gin with Cointreau, fresh lemon juice, and orange marmalade, which tastes good on toast, but tastes even better in a cocktail. The Breakfast Martini recipe comes from Salvatore Calabrese, who first began serving the drink circa 2000 at the Library Bar in London's Lanesborough Hotel.Mix one up to jumpstart your morning, or request a Breakfast Martini to accompany your next brunch.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a shaker, and stir well until marmalade dissolves.
Then fill the shaker with ice, and shake well.
Strain into a chilled cocktail or coupe glass.
Zest a little orange peel over the top, garnish with a orange twist (for an alternative garnish, shred some orange peel onto the top as Salvatore does it), and serve.

name: Spiced & Pineapple
description: Spiced & Pineapple is a simple drink combining just two ingredients: Bacardi Spiced Rum and pineapple juice. The refreshing cocktail is great for entertaining, especially when you don't want to spend all your time mixing up complicated drinks for your guests. Bacardi Spiced Rum is lightly aged in American oak and features notes of creamy vanilla, subtle honey, and charred wood, leading to a cinnamon and nutmeg finish. That spice works nicely with the sweet, juicy taste of pineapple.

instructions.description: Fill a highball or Tiki glass with cubed or crushed ice.
Pour in the rum, followed by the pineapple juice.
Give it all a gentle stir, then garnish with a pineapple wedge and a pineapple leaf.

name: Black Margarita
description: The Black Margarita isn't nearly as sinister as it looks—that's just what happens when you mix together blue curaçao and Chambord. Great for Halloween (or any other time you want to look a little edgy), this is a sweeter drink than the classic Margarita, and it makes up for a slight lack of balance with its fun look. So, while not an everyday recipe, the Black Margarita definitely deserves a spot on your next holiday cocktail menu.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled Margarita or cocktail glass and serve.
Muddle two strawberries in the bottom of a Belgian beer glass with the Campari, then fill with crushed ice.
Dry shake lime juice and simple syrup, and pour over ice.
Gently float Cruzan Black Strap Rum on top.
Garnish with berries and lime.

name: Lavender Mule
description: The Lavender Mule is a snazzy little Moscow Mule variation. It involves making lavender syrup (worth it), the recipe for which is below: 0.5 cup sugar 1 cup water 2 tablespoons dried culinary lavender. Combine the sugar and dried food-grade lavender in a heat-proof bowl. Pour boiling water over the sugar and lavender, and stir for a few seconds until the sugar is dissolved. Let the lavender steep for 10-15 minutes. Strain the lavender out and let the syrup come to room temperature, then refrigerate.

instructions.description: To make the lavender ice cubes, place a few pinches of dried culinary lavender in a ice cube tray, cover with water and freeze. (I also threw in a few dried food-grade rose petals for color and aroma.)
Combine all the cocktail ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, stir until chilled and strain over lavender ice cubes.

name: Spicy Mule
description: The Spicy Mule is a Moscow Mule variation that definitely has some kick, and not just from the vodka. Jalapeño peppers spice this cocktail up and make it a deliciously zippy drink. While it looks like a summertime tipple, the combination of hot peppers and ginger might just make the Spicy Mule a perfect for warming up in the dead of winter, too.

ingredients.name: Orange Liqueur (Such As Grand Marnier Or Cointreau)

instructions.description: Thinly slice the jalapeno and muddle a few slices with the lime juice and orange liqueur in a copper mug or Collins glass.
Add ice and stir in the vodka and ginger beer.
Garnish with a slice or two of jalapeño and serve.

name: Black Russian
description: The Black Russian is known as a "duo" cocktail, meaning a simple recipe of a spirit and a liqueur. This easy vodka cocktail originated in Brussels, Belgium in 1949, and has been a perennial favorite ever since (its sister drink, the White Russian, achieved cult status in the late '90s thanks to the movie The Big Lebowski). You can adjust the ratio of vodka to Kahlúa to taste, though we generally recommend not overdoing it on the coffee liqueur, as it's easy to make this too sweet.What's particularly fun about the Black Russian cocktail is that it's a great vehicle for trying out new coffee liqueurs. It seems like every craft distiller in the world makes one these days (apparently they're relatively simple to make, compared to other liqueurs), and it's boring to just use Kahlúa all the time. Since the Black Russian only uses two ingredients, it allows the flavors to shine through without needing to sip the liqueur straight.

instructions.description: Add vodka to an Old-Fashioned glass with ice.
Add coffee liqueur and serve.

name: Garden Mule
description: The Garden Mule is a fantastic riff on the classic Moscow Mule recipe, and is truly one of our favorites. It's been featured all over the web in various compilations (including our own), and its beautiful combination of fresh blueberries, cucumber, and mint make it one of the more refreshing summertime cocktails around.

ingredients.name: Mint Leaves, Plus A Sprig For Garnish

instructions.description: Put the cucumber, 8 blueberries and mint leaves in the bottom of a cocktail shaker. Muddle until crushed and juicy. Add a handful of ice, vodka and lime. Cover shaker and shake for about 15 seconds, until the shaker develops a nice coat of condensation on the outside.

Fill a Moscow Mule mug with ice. Strain the liquid from the shaker into the mug. Top with ginger beer and 4 blueberries. Thread 4 more blueberries and a piece of candied ginger onto a toothpick. Garnish with a sprig of mint and the toothpick of berries and ginger.

name: Kamikaze Shot
description: The Kamikaze Shot is a fun shooter version of the Kamikaze cocktail, which itself is structured similarly to a Vodka Gimlet (or perhaps a Margarita laced with vodka instead of tequila). It's made with vodka, triple sec and lime juice and has a soft, citrusy profile that acts as a crowd pleaser at bars around the world. The Kamikaze Shot rose in popularity during the 1970s as a party drink to knock back with friends. The alcohol content is lower than the cocktail version, so it's something you can drink a couple of without falling off your barstool. This ability to continue the good times may have contributed to its rise in popularity. And today, you're more likely to see the Kamikaze consumed in shot form than as a cocktail.What's in a Kamikaze Shot?The Kamikaze Shot is a simple drink, but that simplicity kept it from fully slipping into obnoxious nightclub shooter territory that befell so many of its contemporaries, despite its disco origins.The recipe for the Kamikaze has only three ingredients—vodka, triple sec (or other orange liqueur) and lime juice. Some recipes calls for Rose's Lime juice or other bottled lime cordial, but we always prefer to use fresh lime juice. It tastes better and tempers the drink's sweetness.How to make a Kamikaze ShotThe Kamikaze Shot is easy to make. Pour the three ingredients into a cocktail shaker half-filled with ice, and shake well. Strain into shot glasses, and serve chilled.Although it may sometimes be served with a lime wedge garnish, we don't see the need for this decoration—the shot is tasty enough and the alcohol kick tame enough to reduce the need for a chaser.When was the Kamikaze Shot Invented?According to noted cocktail historian David Wondrich, the Kamikaze shot was invented in 1976 and may have been the original "shooter" cocktail.Since then, it has stood the test of time, and it's still among the most popular vodka shots served in bars and clubs across the country.That said, it doesn't seem like there's much reason for the Kamikaze Shot to exist, considering the drink began as a cocktail with the same ingredients. This phenomenon didn't befall other popular cocktails like the Cosmopolitan (vodka, orange liqueur, lime juice and cranberry). So perhaps it's just a remnant of the prevailing trends in its heyday. We suggest trying the Kamikaze cocktail if you feel like a longer drink. That way, you get to sip it rather than knock it all back in one go, which is always nice. But, if you're going to make a shooter, the Kamikaze Shot is a good choice. It's the preferred shot of countless people, from college students to the after-work crowd, so you're in good company.

instructions.description: Add the vodka, triple sec and lime juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a shot glass and serve.

name: Mint Julep
description: Typically associated with the Kentucky Derby, the Mint Julep cocktail is a refreshing—if divisive—treat for the spring and summer. As far as the bourbon goes, we don’t recommend using anything too expensive unless you’ve got some income that desperately needs disposing, since the Mint Julep tends to get a little washed out by the other flavors. Be sure to find the freshest mint you can and crush the ice yourself for the classic experience.

instructions.description: Crush the ice in a canvas bag or cloth napkin using a muddler or mallet.
In the bottom of a silver or pewter julep cup (a highball glass will work in a pinch), muddle a few sprigs of mint along with the simple syrup.
Fill the cup with crushed ice.
Add the bourbon and let chill for a few minutes.
Top off the cup with more ice and garnish with a large sprig of mint.

name: Moscow Mule Jello Shots
description: Who said jello shots are just for trashy college parties? These incredible little guys were devised by the gurus over at Domesticate Me, and we simply had to share. Check out the link above to read their whole excellent article and learn about the nuances of cramming your favorite cocktail into bite-sized cubes.

instructions.description: Lightly spray your shot vessel with non-stick cooking spray. (I used a silicon 1-ounce ice cube tray, but you can also use a mini muffin tin, plastic ice cube tray, or even a sheet pan.) Wipe out any excess collected spray with a paper towel.
In a small saucepan, combine the ginger beer and lime juice.
Sprinkle the gelatin over the surface of the liquid and let it sit for 5 minutes to “bloom.” Basically, it will soften and form a film on the top of the liquid that looks sort of wrinkled.

Warm the mixture over medium-low heat for 1-2 minutes, stirring constantly until the gelatin is fully dissolved. Do NOT let the mixture boil, people!!! If you’re unsure whether or not the gelatin is dissolved, rub the liquid between your fingers. If it feels slipper and smooth with no grains of gelatin, it’s done.
Remove from the heat and stir in the vodka.
Pour the liquid into the prepared shot vessel. I recommend using a measuring cup with a lip to make things easier.
Refrigerate for 4 hours or overnight until set completely.

To remove the shots, use a thin knife to slice around the edges of each shot and press them out of the mold. (You can also invert the mold and run a little warm water over it to help loosen them, if you’re having trouble.)
Refrigerate until ready to serve.

name: Kentucky Coffee
description: We're big fans of combining vices, so never shy away from an opportunity to put coffee and liquor into the same glass.Fortunately, Bulleit Bourbon partnered with Revelator Coffee Company to bring the two delicious beverages together in a recipe that's perfect for starting your morning or extending your night.The Kentucky Coffee is a mixture of bourbon and cold brew that's sweetened with homemade vanilla brown sugar syrup. The latter is very easy to make—it's basically just a vanilla-accented simple syrup that uses brown sugar instead of white.Mix this up at home with the below recipe, and soon you'll enjoy the synergistic benefits of whiskey and coffee.

instructions.description: To make syrup: boil 1 cup water. Add 1 cup brown sugar, and stir until it dissolves. Add 1 vanilla bean, split in half. Let simmer for 5 minutes. Cool and store in the fridge for an hour, then strain through a sieve and discard the solids.
Combine cold brew and bourbon in a glass.
Add vanilla brown sugar syrup and creamer to taste.

name: Italian 75
description: A beautiful riff on the classic French 75, the Italian version replaces gin with Cannella Cinnamon Cordial, lemon juice with orange juice, and of course prosecco instead of champagne.Despite the simple ingredients, you will be surprised by the layers it brings. Happy brunching!

instructions.description: Add Cannella, simple syrup and orange juice to cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake well, double strain into champagne flute.
Top gently with prosecco.

name: Mezcal Pumpkin Pie
description: Pumpkin pie is a staple of Thanksgiving Day, but we say: why stop at the actual pie? Especially when you can drink the mezcal spiked equivalent.This Mezcal Pumpkin Pie comes from bartender Johnny Swet at New York bar, the Skylark. He's taking everything you love about pumpkin pie (pumpkin and spices) and merging that with everything you love about mezcal (the fact that it's mezcal). Throw in some fresh lime for a dash of acidity and Feretti Biscotti Liqueur or some holiday flair, and you've got yourself a delightful Thanksgiving cocktail to mix up for you and the family.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients and shake with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass, and lightly dust nutmeg on top.

name: Jack and Coke
description: Jack and Coke. The phrase alone is one of the most popular strings of words you'll hear at bars around the country. And the drink itself is exactly what it sounds like: a simple, two-part cocktail comprised of Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey and Coca-Cola. It's a classic pairing that's refreshing and goes down easy, and it acts as a foray into whiskey for many young drinkers not yet accustomed to drinking spirits on their own.So while the Jack and Coke isn't a particularly nuanced cocktail, there's comfort in knowing that it's readily available at almost any bar across the United States—and, in many cases, the world.Oh, and here's a fun fact: in 2016, fans of the band Motorhead petitioned to have the Jack and Coke renamed "The Lemmy," as it was the favorite drink of recently-departed frontman Ian Fraser "Lemmy" Kilmister. The initiative found some traction online, garnering more than 45,000 signatures, and it moved Food & Beverage Magazine to officially embrace the moniker.

instructions.description: Build over ice in a Collins glass or an Old-fashioned glass.
Serve.

name: Hudson's White Manhattan
description: The Hudson's White Manhattan is a simple Manhattan variation made with Hudson New York Corn Whiskey, a white (un-aged) whiskey. It also substitutes the classic vermouth with Lillet Blanc, a famous quinquina best known for its use in James Bond's original cocktail, the Vesper.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: The Darke Daiquiri
description: Halloween cocktails don't need to be black as night, but it sure helps to set the scene. Like this Darke Daiquiri, a Jäger-and-rum drink that, on the surface, is a modified sour. But toss in a capsule's worth of activated charcoal, and you get an extra spooky sour.Despite its sinister appearance, the Darke Daiquiri is an easy-drinking proposition. Used in small quantities, the charcoal is flavorless, so you're left tasting only the good stuff. And given its propensity for soaking up toxins, it might even help your hangover the next day.Note: activated charcoal can be a dicey proposition for some drinkers. It absorbs toxins, but also drugs—even prescription ones. So if you're on a prescription medication, it's wise to wait a couple hours after drinking activated charcoal to take your medication. That said, we're no doctors, so please do your own research.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice, and strain into a coupe.
If you've got edible ink and a skull stencil, feel free to tackle that garnish. Otherwise, just spritz some orange oil on top, and drop in the peel.

name: Sailor Jerry Cherry
description: The Sailor Jerry Cherry is a light, refreshing cocktail made with Sailor Jerry Spiced Rum, lemon-lime soda, Cherry Heering, and garnished with a homemade rum cherry (that they call "Jerry's Cherries"). It's a fairly low-alcohol drink, and serves as a nice, fruity tipple for most occasions.

instructions.description: To make the Jerry's Cherries: Drain a 10 ounce jar of Maraschino Cherries of its liquid. Fill with Sailor Jerry Spiced Rum. Return the lid and refrigerate for at least 1 week.
Add Jerry's Cherry to a chilled champagne flute.
Add rum and lemon-lime soda.
Top with a float of Cherry Heering.
Garnish with a sprig of clapped sage (optional) and serve.

name: Mezcal Negroni
description: The classic Negroni, with its recipe of equal parts gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth, is ripe for riffing. You can choose your favorite vermouth to add a dash of difference, or sub out Campari entirely for another bittersweet aperitif. Then there's the base spirit. Gin is a noble foundation for the Negroni, but swap it out for bourbon, rum, tequila, or mezcal... and you've still got yourself a fine cocktail.This Mezcal Negroni from Vermont's The Copper Grouse proves that point nicely. The mezcal provides a smoky twist on the original cocktail, and its earthy undertones play nicely with the bracing Campari and rich, herbal vermouth.And with just three ingredients, all mixed in equal proportions, the Mezcal Negroni is an easy drink to make at home.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice, and strain into your glass of choice.
Garnish with an orange peel.

name: Cupid's Hope
description: The Cupid's Hope is a Valentine's Day cocktail recipe from Reyka Vodka. It's made with fresh-squeezed lemon juice, homemade rosemary syrup (recipe below), and pear juice, and served over crushed ice in a Hurricane glass. The result is a refreshing, beachy cocktail that's sure to impress any time of year.If you want to learn how to properly swizzle a cocktail, check out this guide. If you don't have an authentic swizzle stick, you can easily use a barspoon instead.

ingredients.name: Rosemary Stick Or Dried Pear Slice For Garnish.

instructions.description: For the rosemary syrup: Briefly simmer equal parts water and sugar in a small saucepan over medium heat until dissolved. Let cool. Blanch the rosemary for about 30 seconds, then pat dry and remove the leaves. Place the syrup and blanched rosemary leaves into a blender and blend to a consistent texture. Fine strain and bottle.
Add all ingredients to a Hurricane glass filled with crushed ice.
Swizzle with a swizzle stick.
Garnish with a rosemary stick or dried pear slice and serve.

name: French 75
description: The French 75 is a classic cocktail featuring gin, lemon juice, simple syrup, and champagne. It's a crowd-pleaser at just about any occasion, with a perfect balance of flavors and enough effervescence to keep things bright.The French 75 takes its name from a famous WWI artillery piece (known as a field gun) that the French employed to great effect on the battlefield. It first appeared in 1927 in a New York humor magazine, and was picked up by the Savoy Cocktail Book in 1930. The rest, as they say, is history.

instructions.description: Add gin, simple syrup, and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a champagne flute.
Fill the rest of the glass with champagne.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

name: Espresso Martini
description: The Espresso Martini isn't technically a Martini at all, but we love it regardless. A simple combination of vodka, coffee liqueur (like Kahlua), and cold-brew espresso, this cocktail packs as much of a caffeine kick as it does a boozy one. The Espresso Martini is a versatile drink that can be served with brunch, after dinner, or to fuel a night out.While it's likely that many versions of the Espresso Martini have been served over the decades, the drink's origin story is most closely associated with London bartender Dick Bradsell. As the story goes, he first concocted the drink in the 1980s for a young women who asked for something to "Wake me up, and then f**k me up." The drink he created is certainly capable of both, and the Espresso Martini's popularity lives on, making it one of the most successful modern classic cocktails available today.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Float the coffee beans on top of the foam for garnish and serve.

name: French 95
description: The French 95 is a twist on the classic French 75 cocktail with bourbon whiskey replacing the gin. It has a sweet and sour flavor with a refreshing carbonation.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients (except champagne) with ice and strain into an ice-filled goblet.
Top with champagne, and serve.

name: Mezcal Paloma
description: Spanish for "dove," the Paloma is one of the most popular cocktail recipes made in Mexico, and features either grapefruit juice and club soda or one of the many traditional Mexican grapefruit sodas that can be found in most well-stocked grocery stores. While traditionally made with tequila, the smokiness of mezcal takes the Paloma to new heights.

instructions.description: Add mezcal, lime juice, and salt to a highball glass.
Fill with ice, then fill with equal parts grapefruit juice and club soda (alternatively, use a Mexican grapefruit soda) and stir.

name: The Snitch
description: A cocktail as classic and simple as the Paloma is bound to have variations, and one of our favorites comes from SIP (Southport & Irving Restaurant and Bar), a Prohibition-style neighborhood bar in North Lakeview, Chicago. They're merging smoky mezcal with grapefruit shrub (rather than the Paloma's traditional grapefruit soda), and mixing in a dash of Campari for a slight kick of bitterness. Put it all together, and you've got one hell of a refreshing drink.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake well.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over ice and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

name: Vampire's Weakness
description: What this drink lacks in subtlety, it makes up for in almost being a Boulevardier. The Vampire's Weakness riffs on the classic combo of bourbon, Campari and sweet vermouth with the Irish whiskey treatment—upping the ratios slightly from the traditional equal parts.The cocktail is spirit-forward and bittersweet, making a fine nightcap, whether you're closing down a bar, sitting fireside or, in this case, hosting a Halloween party. Because you really shouldn't garnish your drinks with an anatomically correct eyeball unless you're hosting a Halloween party.

instructions.description: Add the Irish whiskey, Campari and sweet vermouth to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.
Strain into a coupe glass.
Garnish with a bloody eyeball: lychee, a blueberry, and "blood" aka fruit preserves.

name: Mezcal El Diablo
description: Despite it’s name, El Diablo is a perfect cocktail to help you beat the heat this summer. The sweetness of crème de cassis combines perfectly with the tartness of ginger beer, and the intense smokiness of mezcal. These cocktails are especially good for summer get-togethers where exact measurements aren’t your top priority!

ingredients.name: Lime Wedge (And, Optionally, A Lime Wheel For Garnish)

instructions.description: Add mezcal to a Collins glass filled with ice.
Top with ginger beer, then slowly pour in the crème de cassis (it will settle to the bottom).
Squeeze the lime wedge over the top of the drink, then drop it in and serve.
Garnish with a lime wheel.

name: The Spooky Neighbor
description: The Spooky Neighbor is a spirited concoction combining the always-solid Glenfiddich 12 Year Old Scotch with China China (a bittersweet liqueur made with orange peels, seeds, and spices), Suze (a French aperitif), and a coffee liqueur of your choice. With just four ingredients, it's simple to mix (though might require a trip to the liquor store), with a complex taste that belies that simplicity. It's bitter, herbal, and flush with the taste of scotch and coffee.Despite the name, this one's more of a tasty whisky drink than something spooky, but hey, we'd be very happy to sip this on Halloween—or whenever.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice, and strain into a double rocks glass with one large ice cube.
Garnish with an orange and lemon twist.

name: Whiskey Smash
description: The Whiskey Smash is a classic whiskey cocktail, and a cousin of the Mint Julep—the only difference being that a smash contains fresh fruit, while juleps don't. The ingredients are a simple combination of bourbon, lemons, simple syrup, and mint, making this a strong but well-balanced formula.The classic Whiskey Smash dates back to the good old days of 19th century American mixology, and appears in some of the earliest cocktail recipe books around. The name likely comes from the muddling involved in mixing it up.
