ingredients.name: Half A Lemon, Cut Into Wedges

instructions.description: Muddle the lemon, mint, and simple syrup in the bottom of a cocktail shaker, then fill with ice.
Add the bourbon and shake until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice (or a single large cube).
Garnish with a sprig of mint, clapped once between your hands to release the aromatic oils.

name: Toronto
description: The Toronto was a somewhat obscure classic cocktail that has only recently been revived and brought into the spotlight. It's a Manhattan variation that skips the sweet vermouth and instead calls for rye whiskey, Fernet-Branca, simple syrup, and bitters. The Fernet adds some bitter, piney notes to drink and results in a complex flavor profile.Given the name, Canadian rye is a solid choice, but American rye whiskeys also work great in the Toronto cocktail, as the spice plays nicely with the Fernet. Follow the below recipe to mix up a Toronto for yourself.

instructions.description: Combine rye whiskey, Fernet, simple syrup, and bitters in a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe or other cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist and serve.

name: The Falcon
description: The Falcon is a cocktail dreamed up for Super Bowl LI by Johnny Swet, Cocktail Director at Lillie's Victorian Establishment and Papillon Bistro & Bar in New York City, but it's also super easy to make at home for your game-day party. Show your love (or bandwagon support) for Matt Ryan and the Atlanta Falcons with this combination of vodka, pomegranate liqueur (we usually use PAMA), agave syrup, fresh-squeezed lime juice, and ginger beer.If you hail from New England, check out The Patriot cocktail instead.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a highball glass filled with ice (add the ginger beer last) and stir gently.
Garnish with a lime wheel and serve.

name: Long Island Iced Tea
description: The Long Island Iced Tea cocktail is one of the most popular alcoholic drinks of the '70s and '80s, and it remains a popular order today—so many of us have a story about the crazy nights that started with a strong LIIT. It's rumored to have been invented on New York's Long Island during Prohibition and named because it resembles a large glass of iced tea.This is not a fancy cocktail by any means, but the Long Island (as it's commonly called) gets the job done, and depending on which ingredients you use it can actually be quite tasty.What alcohol is in a Long Island Iced Tea recipe?The Long Island Iced Tea is typically made with five types of liquors. That includes four full-proof spirits—vodka, gin, white rum (or light rum) and tequila—plus a triple sec or other orange liqueur.We suggest making a Long Island Iced Tea with middle-shelf booze, as mixing all of the different types of spirits together will muddle up any delicate flavors and nuances of your more expensive top-shelf bottles.How to make a Long Island Iced TeaBuild the Long Island Iced Tea directly in a collins glass or a highball glass. Pour your favorite brands of the above-mentioned spirits into the glass over ice with fresh lemon juice and homemade simple syrup. (For the best results, always opt for fresh citrus juice and steer clear of any store-bought sour mix.) Top it off with cola and give everything a little stir, then garnish the drink with a lemon wedge or an orange slice.There's really no need to shake the ingredients in a cocktail shaker, unless you are looking for some additional dilution. If you do choose to shake, just make sure to strain the contents over fresh ice, rather than dumping the whole drink into the glass straight from the shaker.Contrary to what you may find in some recipes elsewhere, we do not recommend substituting cranberry juice for the cola, as the flavor profile is completely different and you lose the bubbly brightness of the carbonated soda. Coke is the way to go here, as it gives you that trademark LIIT flavor you know and love (or hazily remember from your youth).Variations of the Long Island Iced TeaA popular variation of the Long Island Iced Tea recipe is the AMF drink (or the Adios Motherfucker, as the cocktail is delightfully known), which swaps two ingredients—blue curaçao instead of triple sec, and lemon-lime soda instead of cola—to create an electric blue version of this cocktail.As you take a sip of the Adios (as it's commonly called in more conservative circles), you'll notice that the taste is quite similar to the classic Long Island.

ingredients.name: Lemon Wedge Or Wheel For Garnish

instructions.description: Add the vodka, tequila, rum, gin, triple sec, lemon juice and simple syrup into a Collins glass with ice.
Top with the cola and stir briefly.
Garnish with a lemon wedge or lemon wheel and serve.

name: Negronino
description: I didn't have a grapefruit or an orange on hand, so I went without a garnish. Still delicious!

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice, and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

name: The Patriot
description: The Patriot cocktail was mixed up by Johnny Swet, he of Lillie's Victorian Establishment and Papillon Bistro & Bar in New York City, for Patriots fans (and bandwagoners) to show their team pride during Super Bowl LI. It's a simple recipe, made with rye whiskey, maple syrup, cranberry juice, and bitters, so you'll have no trouble making it at home for your game-day party.If you hail from Atlanta, or just can't stand Brady and Belichick, check out The Falcon cocktail instead.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients (except garnish) to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with a cinnamon stick and serve.

name: Grapefruit Crush
description:
A crisp and refreshing cocktail, the Grapefruit Crush is a delight on warm summer afternoons. This riff on the Orange Crush blends both grapefruit juice and lemon juice for a nice, citrusy tartness that's smoothed out by the simple syrup, with the soda water giving it just the right amount of brightness.

Frequently served in a collins glass with a straw, our preferred way of enjoying the Grapefruit Crush is in an old-fashioned glass.

ingredients.name: Grand Marnier Or Other Orange Liqueur (Optional)

instructions.description: Pour all ingredients except soda into a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
Shake vigorously, and strain into a cocktail glass filled with ice.
Top with a splash of soda, and garnish with a sprig of mint (optionally, can substitute mint with either a grapefruit peel or slice).
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker half-filled with ice, and shake well.
Double-strain into a chilled margarita glass.
Garnish with a cherry and pineapple slice flag, and serve.
Pour all ingredients into a shaker filled with ice, and shake well.
Strain into a cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lime wedge, and serve.

name: Civil War
description: A riff on the Manhattan from Portland, OR bartender Mike Robertson of The Driftwood Room, the Civil War blends some pretty inventive ingredients to great effect. Artichoke-flavored Cynar, Cocchi Vermouth di Torino, and a local bourbon called Burnside (you can use your favorite stuff in its place if it's not available) make for an excellent variation on the classic.

ingredients.name: Dashes Fee Brothers Old Fashioned Bitters

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients (except cherry) in a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with cherry and serve.

name: Greenpoint
description: Named for the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn, this cocktail is a very slight variation on a Manhattan that adds Yellow Chartreuse and Punt e Mes vermouth.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and serve.

name: Clint Eastwood
description: Who doesn't want to drink like Clint Eastwood? This Manhattan variation is made using Bulleit bourbon, Vya sweet vermouth, and orange bitters for a slight variation on the classic.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cherry and serve.

name: Raspberry Cosmopolitan
description: The Raspberry Cosmopolitan is a simple variation on the original Cosmopolitan recipe that uses fresh muddled raspberries in place of the usual splash of cranberry juice. Instead of using citrus vodka, you can also experiment with various raspberry vodkas, but we think the citrus-berry combo is pretty delicious as-is.

instructions.description: Muddle 3-4 fresh raspberries in a cocktail shaker along with citrus vodka, Cointreau, and lime juice.
Add ice to shaker and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with 2-3 raspberries and serve.

name: Bensonhurst
description: The Bensonhurst was first created by bartender Chad Solomon at NYC's Pegu Club bar. A riff on the classic Manhattan, and one of a popular series of drinks named for Brooklyn neighborhoods, the Bensonhurst subs sweet vermouth for dry. It gets a touch of bitterness from Cynar, an Italian liqueur, and a nod of bittersweet cherry from the addition of maraschino—an ingredient you'll find in the similarly-themed Red Hook cocktail.

instructions.description: Stir ingredients with ice in a mixing glass until cold.
Strain into a Nick and Nora glass or a coupe.

name: Sex on the Beach
description: The Sex on the Beach is a popular vodka cocktail that's probably best known for its provocative name, despite having nothing to do with either sex or the beach. It's fruity, sweet, and not particularly sophisticated, but the Sex on the Beach cocktail certainly has its place as a fun drink for those nights you don't want to take yourself too seriously.You can elevate your Sex on the Beach (ha!) a bit by using fresh-squeezed orange juice, which always makes for a nicer drink no matter the recipe. But aside from that, there's not a whole lot of room for improvement to the Sex on the Beach recipe—unless you're going to buy some kind of expensive vodka or peach schnapps, which honestly would be put to better use in something that doesn't bury them under a bunch of fruit juice.If you're interested in something more along the lines of a craft cocktail while keeping with a racy and provocative name—then give the Pornstar Martini a gander—it'll certainly be a bit more complicated, a bit more elaborate, and a whole lot tastier.

instructions.description: Fill a Highball glass with ice, then add all ingredients except garnish.
Stir gently, garnish, and serve.

name: Red Hook
description: The Red Hook cocktail is a modern classic that comes to us from bartender Enzo Errico, formerly of NYC's Milk & Honey. This drink was perhaps the first Manhattan variation that took its name from a Brooklyn neighborhood, creating a trend that has since given us cocktails like the Bensonhurst and Greenpoint.The Red Hook begins with a rye whiskey base. From there, it benefits from the addition of Punt e Mes, a mildly-bitter Italian vermouth, as well as some bittersweet maraschino liqueur. All together, it's a stout, well-balanced cocktail that manages to marry three strong flavors into a well-balanced, complementary package.

instructions.description: Stir ingredients with ice in a mixing glass until well chilled.
Strain into a cocktail glass.

name: Hair of the Dog
description: Hair of the Dog is a shortened version of "hair of the dog that bit you," which refers to an old belief that if you're hungover from drinking, you should have more alcohol to feel better. Does it work? That's debatable. But what's certain is there are dozens of hangover "cures" out there, from cocktails like the Bloody Mary (vodka and tomato juice), Mimosa (Champagne and orange juice) and Irish Coffee (whiskey, coffee and cream) to the aptly named Corpse Reviver No. 2, a classic gin drink that's laced with absinthe.Some people even go so far as to down a shot of hot sauce and lime or lemon juice, which we can't responsibly recommend. But this simple, three-ingredient drink takes the name of its entire category, so we're inclined to trust it. Well, as far as anecdotal hangover remedies go.The Hair of the Dog cocktail is meant to cure what ails you, assuming what ails you is a hangover. You know the feeling: pounding headache, stomach is mad at you, mouth is parched.With just three ingredients—whiskey, honey, and cream—the Hair of the Dog cocktail is a tasty and easy-drinking option for a morning pick-me-up. Pair it with a hearty breakfast, and you'll rise from the dead in no time.To make this possible hangover cure, pour blended scotch, honey syrup and cream into a cocktail shaker, and shake with ice. Strain it into your glass, no garnish necessary, and drink up. It's not exactly vitamins or Pedialyte, but this booze potion may do the trick and end your misery after a long night of drinking. If not, hey, at least you get to drink something tasty to start your morning.

ingredients.name: Ounce Honey Syrup (2 Parts Honey, 1 Part Water)

instructions.description: Make honey syrup by heating honey and water over low-heat until the honey dissolves. Let cool.
Add the scotch, honey syrup and cream to a shaker half-filled with ice cubes, and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass (optionally, use a coupe glass or cocktail glass) and serve.

name: Full Harvest
description: Everyone celebrates fall differently. Some people carve pumpkins and jump into leaf piles. Some drape themselves in flannel. And others combine seasonal ingredients like cranberry and cinnamon with that all-season spirit, bourbon.The Fall Harvest is doing exactly that. With a base of bourbon accented by festive limoncello, cranberry bitters, cinnamon syrup, and egg white, there's a lot to enjoy here as the weather turns cold.The cocktail is a fine merger of tart fruit, spicy cinnamon, stout bourbon, and silky egg white, and is exceedingly easy to drink—whether you're mixing up a nightcap or serving an entire table at Thanksgiving dinner.

instructions.description: Shake hard with ice, then strain into a coupe.
Garnish with a basil leaf.

name: Buttery Nipple
description: Rising to popularity in the 1980s, the Buttery Nipple is a straight shooter made with butterscotch schnapps liqueur and Irish cream. Most recipes call for the Buttery Nipple shot to be served layered, with the Irish cream floated on top of the schnapps. In this case, it's helpful to slowly pour the Irish cream over the back of a barspoon, which will help to create that layered effect.If that sounds like too much effort, no worries—the drink may also be served mixed, especially if several are being made simultaneously. And given the shot's sweet and creamy character (it tastes a bit like butterscotch candy) the Buttery Nipple is a popular party shot. So it's rare to just make one.If you like this shot, you can also try the Slippery Nipple. It's another two-ingredient shooter featuring Irish cream, but it skips the butterscotch schnapps and instead calls for Sambuca, an Italian anise-flavored liqueur.

instructions.description: Pour the butterscotch liqueur into a chilled shot glass.
Layer or float the Irish cream on top (use an upside down spoon to help if necessary), and serve.

name: French Rose Cocktail
description: The French Rose is an easy-to-make, three-ingredient drink that features gin, dry vermouth, and cherry brandy. Those ingredients combine to give the cocktail a gorgeous look that belies its simplicity, along with a light and floral flavor with just a hint of sweetness from the brandy.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, and serve.

name: Winter White Lady
description: The Winter White Lady is a riff on the classic White Lady cocktail (gin, lemon, Cointreau, egg white) that updates the ratios and adds aromatic bitters to the mix.Invented in 1919 by London bartender Harry MacElhone, the White Lady is a friendly introduction to egg white cocktails for the uninitiated. And the Winter White Lady is exactly that, but features additional Cointreau and lemon for a more orange/citrus flavor profile. Throw a healthy dose of bitters in there, and you've got a balanced cocktail worth sipping on all winter long.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice, and shake vigorously to emulsify the egg white.
Strain into a coupe, and garnish with lemon twist.

name: Mark Twain Cocktail
description: The Mark Twain cocktail, unlike a lot of other drinks named for famous people, can actually be traced to a letter he wrote to his wife in 1874 while visiting London:"Livy my darling, I want you to be sure and remember to have, in the bathroom when I arrive, a bottle of Scotch Whiskey, a lemon, some crushed sugar, and a bottle of Angostura bitters. Ever since I have been in London I have taken in a wine glass what is called a cock-tail (made with those ingredients) before breakfast, before dinner, and just before going to bed."He likely didn't invent the recipe (since it's basically just a Whiskey Sour made with scotch and bitters), but apparently it was one of his favorites—especially considering he seemed to enjoy it at all hours of the day. Be sure to use fresh lemon juice, and don't bother using a fancy scotch, since it'll be buried among the other ingredients.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist and serve.

name: Moonlight Cocktail
description: The Moonlight Cocktail is a variation on the Aviation (kinda trips off the tongue, huh?) invented by legendary barman and author Gary "Gaz" Regan. It swaps the maraschino liqueur for Cointreau, and uses lime juice instead of lemon (Regan's explanation? "I had no lemons").The crème de violette remains the same in The Moonlight Cocktail, and your best bet is probably going to be Rothman and Winter if you live in the States. It's one of the few that's available, but the market is growing, so you might have more options if you find a good liquor store. The floral notes of the crème de violette complement the orange and citrus notes of the Cointreau quite well, and makes for a well-balanced cocktail. If you enjoy a good Aviation, give The Moonlight Cocktail a go—chances are you'll be quite pleased.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist and serve.

name: Harvest Sour
description: The Harvest Sour cocktail comes from Chicago bartender Scott LoBianco. He's mixed up a tasty drink that's a perfect foil to cooler weather.The Harvest Sour begins as a classic Manhattan (rye, sweet vermouth, and bitters) before taking a turn and employing lemon juice and cinnamon syrup. The result is a festive, spiced, and surprisingly refreshing drink that's eager to join your winter parties and be consumed near fireplaces.The below recipe is easy to follow and uses ingredients that are readily available. To make that cinnamon syrup, just steep cinnamon sticks in hot simple syrup (equal parts sugar and water combined on the stove), strain them out, and let the syrup cool. Make a bunch, and you'll have enough cinnamon syrup to mix up Harvest Sours all winter long.

instructions.description: Add cherries to a cocktail shaker and muddle.
Combine remaining ingredients into that shaker, add ice, and shake.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

name: Alabama Slammer
description: The Alabama Slammer is one of those late-20th century nightclub drinks that actually holds its own pretty well despite having an obnoxious name. Though Southern Comfort, sloe gin, and amaretto don't sound like they go great together, the orange juice in the Alabama Slammer recipe actually serves as a decent bonding agent to blend the flavors.Now, we wouldn't go so far as to call the Alabama Slammer a "craft cocktail" by any means, but it definitely isn't bad. And if you use fresh-squeezed orange juice, the Alabama Slammer can be a really fun, refreshing drink for those nights you don't want to take yourself too seriously.

ingredients.name: Orange Wedge And/Or Cherry For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a Highball glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with an orange wedge and/or cherry and serve.

name: Dirty Martini
description: The Dirty Martini is a classic Martini variation that's extremely simple: all you need to do is add a barspoon or two of olive brine from the jar for a salty, savory kick. It's one of the few cocktails that's truly salty (although the extent of that saltiness depends entirely on your taste), so it's a favorite among folks who aren't into sweet, citrusy drinks.Traditionally, a Dirty Martini is made with a classic London dry gin, as lighter modern gins don't hold up as well to the briny flavors. That said, you're free to experiment—it's your drink, after all! Let us know in the comments if you come across a particularly delicious combination.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except the garnish to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until chilled, then strain into a chilled Martini glass.
Garnish with an olive or two on a toothpick or cocktail pick.

name: Whiskey Eggnog
description: Many traditional eggnog recipes feature brandy or rum (or both), but this versatile cocktail can also be made with whiskey. And you don't even need a blender to make it. Instead, simply shake whiskey with milk, egg, powdered sugar, and ice to create a rich and delicious Whiskey Eggnog in mere minutes, as opposed to the laborious process required by some recipes.When choosing your whiskey, you can opt for the oak-accented flavor of bourbon, which sports notes of vanilla and baking spices. You can use rye, which yields a spicer drink than bourbon. You can opt for easygoing blended scotches, with notes of honey and heather. You can even go the Canadian route, and choose from a wide variety of Canadian whiskies for your base spirit. The key is just to pick something you like because the whiskey here is meant to be highlighted, not covered up.The Whiskey Eggnog is a fan favorite during the holidays, so make a few glasses to enjoy around the fire. When you do, be sure to give that shaker a vigorous shake. Doing so will help the egg emulsify into the liquid ingredients, and it will give the drink the rich and creamy texture you want. Garnish each glass with some freshly grated nutmeg or a cinnamon stick for a festive dose of holiday aromas.

instructions.description: Add whiskey, sugar, egg and milk to a shaker with plenty of ice, and shake hard for 20-30 seconds.
Strain into a mug, and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
Optionally, garnish with a cinnamon stick.

name: Pimm's Cup
description: The Pimm's Cup cocktail is a British classic that's great for summer afternoons and brunches with friends. The Pimm's Cup is fresh and delicious, with plenty of citrus, spices and herbal notes. As it's light on alcohol compared to a full-proof cocktail, the Pimm's Cup is easy to drink and there's little guilt when ordering a second round.What's in a Pimm's Cup Cockail?The base spirit for the Pimm's Cup is Pimm's No. 1, a low-proof gin-based liqueur that was invented in Britain in the 1840s by James Pimm, the proprietor of a London-based oyster bar. The name is derived from a tankard he used to serve the beverages from that he called the "No. 1 Cup." As the drink rose in popularity, it began to be produced on a larger scale and was eventually sold commercially in various markets, including in America (the Pimm's brand is now owned by Diageo).The classic recipe for the Pimm's Cup includes a slice of cucumber, a slice of orange, and a strawberry and is topped off by fresh carbonated lemonade with a lemon twist garnish. Some recipes suggest the use of lemon-lime soda or ginger ale as a substitute for the fresh lemonade. This method works, but for most people it means using store-bought products. Whenever possible, we recommend using fresh juice in cocktails for the best flavors—and besides, it's easy enough to make your own carbonated lemonade with some fresh-squeezed lemon juice, soda water, and a little simple syrup.Experimentation is encouraged for additional recipe variations, as similarly to the Bloody Mary Cocktail, you can add nearly any fresh fruit and vegetable garnishes you want to make the Pimm's Cup your own. Some people even add a little gin or vodka to the recipe to boost its potency, but we're happy sipping this cooling refreshment as-is.The Revival of the Pimm's CupSince the early 2000s, the Pimm's Cup cocktail (as well as the Pimm's brand of products) has experienced a resurgence in popularity, thanks in part to the craft cocktail renaissance.The Pimm's Cup remains popular in England, and is an official drink of Wimbledon (along with champagne). Every year, the venue serves more than 80,000 Pimm's Cups to spectators, and the drink is also a standard cocktail at British and American polo matches. Then again, sometimes you'll find it in American cocktail bars and even dive bars, considering it's so easy to make. The Pimm's Cup may be associated with gentility and sports, but it's for everyone

instructions.description: To make carbonated lemonade, combine juice from one lemon, 1.5 oz soda water, and 0.25 oz simple syrup. Scale up for larger recipes.

To make the cocktail, add Pimm's No. 1 and lemonade to a highball glass with ice and stir to combine. Garnish with a cucumber, orange slice, strawberry,  lemon twist and fresh mint sprig, or whatever assortment of fresh produce you prefer.
Shake all ingredients in a shaker filled with ice, then strain into a rocks glass with ice.
Top with champagne and garnish with a mint sprig.

name: Melonball
description: A Melonball is a fruity vodka-based cocktail that is shaken and served on the rocks.

instructions.description: Fill tall glass with ice. Pour in Melon Liqueur and Vodka. Fill glass with juice. Orange juice may also be used.

name: Over the Moon
description: The Over the Moon cocktail is an Oscar-night drink concocted in honor of Best Picture nominee Moonlight. Using bourbon, St. Germain, simple syrup, lemon juice, and a float of bold red wine, this is a complex and gorgeous highball to match the film that inspired it.

ingredients.name: Lemon Peel Cut Into A Star Shape

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except red wine to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a highball or Collins glass over fresh ice.
Float red wine on top.
Garnish with lemon-peel star and serve.

name: Smoke Show
description: The Smoke Show cocktail is an original drink from The Botanist Gin, and one that we've had the pleasure of trying ourselves. Similar in makeup to the classic Penicillin—which mixes scotch with lemon, ginger, and an additional, smokier scotch—the Smoke Show starts with gin, but then gets back on track with lemon, ginger, and a smoky accent. In this case: mezcal.The result is a gin-forward, tart, refreshing, and ginger-spiced drink with subtle mezcal smoke, which you can dial up or down depending on which bottle you reach for.Gin is often incorporated into summer cocktails, but with fall-friendly ginger and hearty mezcal, the Smoke Show can be sipped all year round—and actually makes a great companion to rich holiday meals.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill with ice, and shake vigorously.
Strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with pickled ginger.

name: City of Stars
description: The City of Stars cocktail was devised by bartender Johnny Swet, of The Skylark in New York City, as a tribute to Oscar nominee La La Land. It's a riff on the Negroni, using Plymouth Gin, Carpano Antica vermouth, and Campari, as well as a spoonful of St. Elizabeth Allspice Dram to mix it up. You have a few options for garnish, but I think the star anise looks nicest.

ingredients.name: Orange Twist, Star Anise, Or Cinnamon Stick For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients except garnish to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with an orange twist, star anise, or cinnamon stick and serve.

name: Holiday Sidecar
description: The Holiday Sidecar is an easy and delicious take on the classic Sidecar (cognac, Cointreau, lemon). In this case, the holiday version simply tweaks the ratios, adds bitters, and changes up the garnish.The addition of aromatic bitters adds depth and spice to the cocktail, while the cinnamon-sugar rim provides even more spice. Drop in some star anise, and you've got a fragrant, seasonal drink to enjoy on Christmas Day, all throughout the holidays, or whenever the mood strikes.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into a cinnamon-sugar rimmed coupe glass.
Garnish with star anise.

name: Corpse Reviver #1
description: The Corpse Reviver #1 is part of a family of cocktails meant to wake you from other dead—or, in other words, cure your hangover. These drinks were especially popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, but they made a comeback in the early 2000s during the craft cocktail renaissance.The Corpse Reviver #1 combines cognac, Calvados, and sweet vermouth, stirred with ice and served in a cocktail glass. It precedes the more common Corpse Reviver #2, a wholly different drink featuring gin, lemon juice, orange liqueur (usually Cointreau), Lillet Blanc, and absinthe. While the former is stirred and boozy, with floral and herbal notes, the latter is tart, bracing and pairs nicely with brunch.

instructions.description: Add the cognac, Calvados, and sweet vermouth into a mixing glass with ice, and stir until well-chilled.
Strain into a cocktail glass.

name: Rum and Coke
description: The Rum and Coke is an incredibly simple drink (using just two self-explanatory ingredients), but it's a pretty delicious combination. Many rums (particularly dark rums or spiced rums) already have a cola-esque character to them, so the flavors are complimentary by nature. Note that if you add a lime, you've actually made a Cuba Libre instead of a standard Rum and Coke (the distinction is minor, but it's fun trivia if you're into that kind of thing).What's in a Rum and CokeRum, coke, and... well that's pretty much all she wrote. Naturally, you could get a little fancier and used Mexican Coke (which is still made with cane sugar) or maybe even a vanilla coke. And should you feel the urge to garnish, you won't have to get much fancier than a simple lime wedge. The history of the Rum and CokeWhile this Rum and Coke recipe has long been a go-to in nightclubs and other bars where you don't want anything complicated, it actually has a long history going back to the late 1800s. It was invented in the years following the Spanish-American War as the Cuba Libre (aka, "free Cuba") and started enjoying broad popularity during WWII. Because most American distilled spirits were rationed during the war, imported rum was often the only thing available, and Coca-Cola was one of the only companies with the resources to pay for heavily-rationed sugar. Ever since, the Rum and Coke has been a classic cocktail in the American and Caribbean pantheon.Popular rums for a Rum and CokeWhere this beyond simple cocktail can get interesting is through its alcohol element. Rum is a fascinatingly diverse spirit, and how a Rum and Coke tastes can be totally different depending on whether you opt for a Cuban-style light rum, a darkly sweet black strap rum, or even a funky Jamaican pot still rum.Spiced rums, like Captain Morgan, are also a popular choice for making a Rum and Coke, as these rums are already sweetened and contain a spice element that will introduce extra flavors to the drink. For something lighter, you can also consider Bacardi rum, which is widely available and inexpensively priced. How to Make a Rum and Coke cocktailTo make a Rum and Coke yourself, you'll just need to have your rum at hand and the cola ingredient. This is a cocktail where ratios can vary greatly based on personal preference, so whatever ounces of rum and ounces of coke ultimately go into the drink should be decided by the drinker themselves. That being said, 2 ounces of rum to 4-6 ounces of cola feels like a good rule of thumb.

instructions.description: Add rum into a Highball glass filled with ice.
Fill with Coke and serve.

name: Banana Daiquiri
description: The Banana Daiquiri is a frozen Daiquiri that's guaranteed to be a crowd favorite at your next summer party. While it has a reputation for being a bit girly, we dare any guy to take a sip and not want another.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients (except for the cherry) with 1 cup crushed ice in an electric blender.
Blend at a low speed for five seconds, then blend at a high speed until firm.
Pour contents into a goblet-style glass, top with the cherry, and serve.

name: Grasshopper
description: The Grasshopper cocktail is what's known as a "trio," a drink with two alcoholic ingredients (in this case, creme de menthe and creme de cacao) and a third non-alcoholic ingredient (in this case, cream). It's low in alcohol content, so you can make your way through a couple before you start to feel it, and it's almost always best enjoyed as a dessert drink. It was invented in New Orleans' French Quarter in the mid-20th century, and gained popularity in the decades that followed.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake well until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Grate a bit of nutmeg over the surface of the drink for garnish and serve.

name: Martinez
description: The Martinez cocktail is a classic cocktail and predecessor of the Martini, likely invented in the Bay Area city of Martinez, California in the mid-1800s. It utilizes a classic combination of gin, sweet vermouth, and bitters, and adds a bit of a twist with some maraschino liqueur. The first iteration of the Martinez is believed to have contained Old Tom gin, and using the sweeter style of gin still makes for a great cocktail today.While Martini drinkers may scoff at the use of sweet vermouth instead of dry, the Martinez recipe is actually much closer to the original Martini recipe than the modern Dry Martini, which utilizes dry vermouth (or, frequently and unfortunately, no vermouth at all).It's said to have been created at the Occidental Hotel by legendary 19th-century bartender Jerry Thomas, but like much of early drinking history the true facts are unclear. A recipe for the drink does, however, appear in the first edition of Jerry Thomas's Bar-tender's Guide.

instructions.description: Add the gin, sweet vermouth, maraschino liqueur and bitters into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a twist of lemon or orange.

name: Whiskey Sour
description: The Whiskey Sour is a classic drink, certainly, but it's never been accused of being a pretentious one. Nor, thanks to its unassuming simplicity, has it ever held a seat at the table with some of its classic brethren, like the Martini or Manhattan. As cocktail historian David Wondrich once put it, the Whiskey Sour "is the fried-egg sandwich of American mixology: simple, dull, reliable in a pinch." We're inclined to defend its reputation, however. Because while the Whiskey Sour might not be as complex in flavor as the Manhattan, it gets the job done. And, with a few easy tweaks, it does so in style. First, be sure to use fresh-squeezed lemon juice—no bottled stuff or sour mix. Additionally, if you want a little more texture and froth, you can add an egg white to the mix. If you do, just be sure to give it a good, long shake without ice—known as a dry-shake—first. Then shake again with ice to chill and dilute.The Whiskey Sour cocktail can be served up or on the rocks, depending on the drinker's preference, and the type of whiskey doesn't matter too much (though American whiskey, like bourbon or rye, is pretty standard). Either way, give this cocktail some attention, and it will treat you right for years to come.

instructions.description: If using egg white:
Add whiskey, lemon juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a cocktail shaker WITHOUT ice and shake well for 30 seconds to one minute.
Add ice to shaker and shake until chilled.
If not using egg white:
Add whiskey, lemon juice, and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Double-strain into a chilled sour or cocktail glass, or into an Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
Garnish with a lemon wedge (optional) and serve.

name: Thug Passion
description: The Thug Passion is a cocktail referenced by the late rapper Tupac Shakur in his eponymous song "Thug Passion" (from Shakur's 1996 album All Eyez on Me). The Thug Passion drink itself is a simple drink with only two ingredients: Alizé, a line of flavored liqueurs, and Cristal, a well-known and expensive champagne brand.In a pinch, or for those of us unable (or unwilling) to afford Cristal, just use any generic champagne (it is, after all, called Thug Passion and not Baller Passion).

instructions.description: Pour chilled ingredients into a champagne flute and serve (alternatively, pour ingredients over ice into an old-fashioned glass, stir, and serve).

name: Abuela's Old-Fashioned
description: Abuela's Old-Fashioned is a tequila-spiked riff on the classic cocktail that also features two types of bitters (Angostura and chocolate-mole) and a buñuelo syrup that mimics the popular fried dough fritter.The unique drink was created by Miami bartender Eddie Fuentes. He says: “The sweet buñuelo syrup, made with cinnamon and vanilla, pairs deliciously with Tequila Don Julio Reposado’s intense cooked agave finish.”

instructions.description: For cocktail: Combine ingredients into an old-fashioned glass with ice and stir. Garnish with an orange and lemon twist.

For Buñuelo syrup: Bring cracked cinnamon, vanilla sticks and star anise to a boil in 2 cups of water on high heat. Let boil for 10 minutes. Add sugar and stir until dissolved. Lower heat and let simmer for 1 minute. Strain into a large container. Add lemon juice and let cool.

name: Martini
description: The Martini is a timeless classic cocktail, traditionally consisting of gin and dry vermouth, and commonly garnished with olives or a lemon twist. Since its introduction, the Martini has become one of the best known and most recognizable cocktails of all time.Such is the Martini's popularity that the cocktail's name is used to reference the glassware it's served in—the Martini glass, aka the cocktail glass.James Bond, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Ernest Hemingway, and other fictional and historical greats have been known to enjoy the Martini, and it has been associated with high society and good living for over a century.The history of the Martini is an interesting one, rife with fascinating as well as controversial accounts of the origin of this iconic cocktail. It's worth diving into if you're a diehard Martini fan.What's in a Martini?The classic Martini recipe consists of dry gin, dry vermouth, and an olive or lemon peel garnish. Some recipes also call for orange bitters, which add a subtle note of bright citrus to the mix.For the best Martinis, it's important to use high-quality gin and vermouth. It's less important to identify a "best gin" or "best vermouth," as today there are lots of quality options in each category, and many bottles can make a delicious Martini with subtle flavor nuances.As with many classic recipes, creative bartenders have left their respective marks on the drink. Traditionally a gin-based cocktail, the Martini has over the years been commonly made with vodka or other spirits, as well as different types of vermouths. Experimentation with the ratio of gin to vermouth—as well as the use of alternative ingredients such as olive brine—has spawned a slew of Martini variations, many that are classics in their own right.The Dirty Martini adds a splash of olive juice to the traditional recipe.The Dry Martini uses more gin and less vermouth.The 50/50 Martini uses equal parts gin and dry vermouth.The Perfect Martini combines gin with equal parts dry and sweet vermouth.The Vodka Martini swaps gin for vodka.The Vesper Martini, made famous by James Bond in Ian Fleming's novel Casino Royale, includes both gin and vodka and swaps out vermouth for Lillet Blanc, a French aperitif.These are just several of the many Martini variations you will find with a little digging—many of them great, but some not so great. The '80s and '90s were rife with "Martinis" sporting all manner of fruit juices and syrups. The only thing these drinks had in common with the real thing was the 'tini suffix amended to the end of the name.How to make a Martini cocktail?Despite the popular but misplaced movie catchphrase "shaken, not stirred," the Martini is a stirred drink that is served up.The classic Martini cocktail is very easy to make. Just pour your ingredients into a mixing glass (not a shaker), and stir with plenty of ice until the drink is very cold. Then strain the contents into a chilled cocktail glass, garnish, and serve.

instructions.description: Add the gin and vermouth to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until very cold
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an olive or a lemon twist.

name: Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn cocktail finds a good balance between the sweetness of maraschino liqueur and a nice dry vermouth (instead of the sweet vermouth used in a Manhattan), making it a delicious twist on the original. And just like its namesake, this cocktail is a little bit weirder than its neighboring borough, using a relatively obscure French bitter called Amer Picon. If you can't find any, though, feel free to use a more popular amaro like Ramazotti, or just a few extra dashes of Angostura bitters.The Brooklyn cocktail is one of a loose family of New York-named drinks, including the Manhattan and the Bronx. Though its origins are unclear, it can most likely be traced back to the years before Prohibition. While the Brooklyn fell out of popularity in the '20s and '30s, it has come back into style in recent years thanks to growing interest in pre-Prohibition cocktails.

ingredients.name: Amer Picon, Ramazotti, Or 2-3 Dashes Angostura Bitters

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cherry and serve.

name: Mai Tai
description: The Mai Tai is an essential tiki cocktail that any beach bum worth their salt needs to know. Don't be fooled by any neon-colored pretenders or bottled mixes—this is a classic drink that doesn't need to show off. It's simple, delicious, and highlights the almond notes of a good orgeat alongside a timeless blend of rum, orange liqueur, and lime.The Mai Tai's ingredients are rum, lime juice, orange curaçao (or triple sec in a pinch), orgeat syrup, and rock candy syrup.So, to make a classic Mai Tai, you first need to make two syrups. Orgeat is an almond syrup that's used in a number of tropical drinks, and rock candy syrup is just simple syrup made with a 2:1 ratio of sugar to water (some people call this "rich simple syrup"—just know that, in both cases, you're using more sugar than water.) When choosing your rum, there's some debate over whether to use white rum, dark rum, or a blend of rums. Dark rum is a classic pick, but you can also start the drink with light rum and then float some dark rum over the top of the finished cocktail, if you like.Otherwise, be sure to use fresh lime juice and a high-quality orange liqueur. Grand Marnier is the most widely-available orange curaçao on the market, but you can find a handful of others. Some recipes call for extras like pineapple juice or orange juice, but we suggest skipping both. These juices were never in the original Mai Tai recipe, and they'll leave you with an overly sweet drink and a less balanced flavor.To make the drink, shake your ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice, and strain over fresh ice—many people choose to serve the drink on crushed ice. Garnish with a fresh mint sprig.Who Invented the Mai Tai?Good question. There's some debate surrounding the cocktail's origin. Victor “Trader Vic” Bergeron is often credited with first making the drink at his Oakland, California, bar Trader Vic’s in the 1940s. But another enterprising barkeep named Donn Beach also has some claim to the recipe, and it's believed that he served a similar drink a decade prior at his bar, Don the Beachcomber. Either way, the cocktail stuck, and the Mai Tai is still served all over the world today.

ingredients.name: Ounce Rock Candy Syrup (2:1 Ratio Simple Syrup)

instructions.description: Add the rum, lime juice, orange curacao, orgeat, and rock candy syrup into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass with fresh ice.
Garnish with a sprig of mint and an optional lime wedge.

name: Strawberry Cosmopolitan
description: The Strawberry Cosmopolitan is a simple, fresh variation on the original Cosmopolitan recipe that uses muddled strawberries in place of cranberry juice for a bit of color and fruity sweetness. The original citrus vodka works great in this cocktail, but you can also play around with all kinds of other flavored vodkas to see what tastes best. Make sure to save a couple of fresh strawberries for garnish!

instructions.description: Muddle 3-4 fresh strawberries in a cocktail shaker along with vodka, Cointreau, and fresh lime juice.
Add ice to the shaker and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with 2-3 fresh strawberries and serve.

name: Drambuie Cider
description: The Drambuie Cider is a warm, delicious cocktail for the fall and winter months. The honey and spices in the Drambuie blend beautifully with apple and a cinnamon stick, and it couldn't be easier to make.

instructions.description: Add Drambuie to a mug, then fill the rest of the mug with hot apple cider.
Garnish with a stick of cinnamon and serve.

name: Aperol Spritz
description: The Aperol Spritz is a classic Italian aperitivo cocktail made with prosecco, club soda, and (you guessed it) Aperol. Often regarded as Campari's less bitter cousin, Aperol is a wonderfully light amaro that's great for introducing people to the category, as its citrusy profile goes easy on the powerful flavors that can so often be a turn-off.The Aperol Spritz is one of the best recipes to display its charm, with a bubbly, sweet, and refreshing profile that's perfect for cooling off in the summer. Plus, it's fairly low in ABV (though there is most of a glass of wine in there, so not that low), so it's great for midday barbecues or beachside get-togethers.

ingredients.name: Orange Slice Or Twist For Garnish

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a wine glass or highball glass filled with ice.
Stir gently.
Garnish with an orange slice or twist and serve with a straw.

name: She-lei-lei
description: The She-lei-lei is an Irish-inspired cocktail by renowned bartender Joaquín Simó of Pouring Ribbons in NYC. Made with Irish whiskey, coconut water, and matcha, it's a very creative recipe with some pretty unconventional ingredients—and it comes out a vibrant green (with no food coloring, thankfully), which makes it perfect for all your St. Patrick's Day celebrations.

ingredients.name: Knappogue 12 Year Single Malt Irish Whiskey

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker (add tea last) and shake vigorously without ice to thoroughly incorporate the matcha into the liquids.
Fill rocks glass with ice to the top, then dump ice into mixing tin.
Shake very briefly, but vigorously to just chill ingredients.
Pour liquid and ice from mixing tin into rocks glass, grate cinnamon stick over top, and place cinnamon stick atop the ice.

name: Mudslide
description: The Mudslide, also known as a Blind Russian or a Baileys White Russian, is (you guessed it) a variation on the White Russian made with Baileys Irish Cream instead of cream or half-and-half. So grab your favorite vodka, some coffee liqueur (Kahlúa is the classic choice, but there are a lot of craft options on the market these days), a bottle of Baileys, and you're good to go!The Mudslide is simple, creamy, and decadent enough to stand alone as a dessert. If you really want to mix it up, try making one in a blender for a boozy milkshake.

instructions.description: Add vodka and coffee liqueur to an Old-Fashioned glass filled with ice.
Float Baileys Irish Cream on top and serve.

name: Joan of Arc
description: The Joan of Arc cocktail is a St. Patrick's Day cocktail invented by Jack McGarry of The Dead Rabbit, one of New York City's most renowned bars and winner of World's Best Cocktail Bar at the 2015 Spirited Awards. It's made with chamomile-infused Irish whiskey, a fresh combination of lemon juice and cucumber juice, honey syrup and a honey liqueur, and some champagne to top it all off.To make the infused whiskey, add 10 grams of chamomile flowers and a 750 ml bottle of Clontarf Irish Whiskey to an empty container. Let sit at room temperature for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. Strain into a bottle and store at room temperature.

ingredients.name: Rich Honey Syrup (2 Parts Honey, 1 Part Water)

instructions.description: To make chamomile-infused whiskey: Add 10 grams chamomile flowers and a 750 ml bottle of Clontarf Irish Whiskey to an empty container. Let sit at room temperature for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. Strain into a bottle and store at room temperature.
Add all ingredients (except champagne) to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Add champagne and strain into a champagne flute.

name: Tahitian Coffee
description: In the event that you'd like to recreate the Lady and the Tramp scene on Valentine's Day this year—or whenever—here's a cocktail meant for sharing. Dubbed the Tahitian Coffee, it hails from NYC bar, Slowly Shirley, and begins with a heady base of equal parts rum and pisco. From there, the drink is doctored with a handful of fruits and juices, namely: lime, orange, and guava, plus passionfruit syrup. Things are getting tropical.Cold brew concentrate adds a caffeinated accent, while falernum and honey syrup add sweetness.As you can see, it's a fine looking cocktail. So if you'd like to drink head-to-head with someone special, this might be for you. Or if you just want a big vat of rum, pisco, and accoutrements... same thing applies.

instructions.description: Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain over crushed ice into a Chemex glass (or something equivalent).
Garnish with grated coffee and an orchid.
Serves two.

name: Bloody Mary
description: Like a good casserole, stir fry, or smoothie, the beauty of the Bloody Mary is that it can be tweaked and adjusted to please just about any palate. Those who like them spicy can add a few extra dashes of Tabasco, veggie lovers can stuff theirs full of celery, carrots, and pickles, and epicureans can play around with a whole host of spices, sauces, and other tinctures to create their own signature flavors.While it's a versatile drink, though, it's important not to get too carried away. We can't count the number of times we've gone out to brunch with high expectations for this classic hangover cure, only to have them dashed against a drink so overwrought that it was more food than beverage. So take it easy, start with the basics, and try to limit yourself to only messing with one ingredient at a time.VodkaUnlike a lot of our favorite cocktails, the vodka you use in a Bloody Mary isn't particularly important. It's so heavily concealed under the tomato juice, spices, and sauces that you don't want to waste any of that fancy Stoli Elit or Crystal Head, unless all you've got in the house is top-shelf stuff.That's not to say we recommend just getting the cheapest spirit you can, because a truly awful vodka really can ruin a Bloody Mary. A standard Stolichnaya, Svedka, or Smirnoff will work just fine—luckily, vodka is a pretty inexpensive category all around, so it's easy to find a decent bottle for less than $20.Tomato JuiceTomato juice, on the other hand, is the Bloody Mary's heart and soul. No matter how many spices or spirits you mix with it, cheaping out on this stuff will make for a bad drink. R.W. Knudsen has gotten consistently good marks from various publications, as has Campbell's, and we tend to agree.Don't go nuts on fancy, heirloom brands, but stay away from anything remotely approaching a Bloody Mary mix. Like Margarita mix, it's cloying, unsubtle, and frankly, just plain gross.SpicesSpices and sauces are what make the Bloody Mary interesting, but it's important not to overdo them. There's no "right way" to balance the flavors, but a nice, basic combination goes as follows:To start, rim your glass with a lime and some celery salt. Into the shaker with your vodka and tomato juice, add a dash or two each of lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce (for the vegetarians out there, make sure to get a vegan Worcestershire sauce, as the regular stuff is made with anchovies), Tabasco sauce, and a pinch of ground pepper.The drink you're left with is simple, straightforward, and serves as a good starting point from which you can launch your own flavor experiments.GarnishUnfortunately, the garnish is where so many brunch places go off the deep end. Like a culinary arms race, it seems like every restaurant is trying to one-up its competitors these days with everything from bacon, shrimp, one of every vegetable ever pickled by man, and even entire cheeseburgers crammed heavy-handedly on top of your drink.While many of them have gotten attention for their novel creativity, we can't help but think that a Bloody Mary deserves better than to be a vehicle for food.You don't have to be a purist, but start simple: a stick of celery, a lime wedge or wheel, an olive, or (one of our personal favorites) a pickled green bean all work great in just about any combination. From there, you can play around with your own favorites and find your sweet spot.Final ThoughtsLike so many other cocktails, the Bloody Mary's origins are hotly disputed by the various bars and bartenders who claim to have invented it some 90 years ago, but what's important is that the drink we're left with today is something truly unique.It's unlike just about any other recipe in terms of its complexity and savory profile, but it's surprisingly simple to make—all you need to do is dump your ingredients into a shaker with ice, shake, and strain into a Collins glass.Cocktail snobs might dismiss it as something of a lesser drink, lacking the subtlety of other classics, but we think the world of great booze shouldn't be limited to spirit-forward tipples. Sometimes, especially after a night of too much champagne and celebration, all you really want is something tasty to take the edge off. The Bloody Mary does that with aplomb.

instructions.description: Rim the glass with your preferred choice of salt (optional).
Add all ingredients (except garnishes) to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously until chilled.
Strain into glass filled with fresh ice cubes.
Add salt and pepper to taste.
Add garnishes of your choice and serve.

name: Pineapple Upside-Down Cake Shot
description: The Pineapple Upside-Down Cake cocktail is a fun vodka-based shooter that, while not the most sophisticated drink in the world, is sweet, tasty, and a popular serve at parties and nightclubs. The Pineapple Upside-Down Cake shot is a layered shot, with bright-red grenadine at the bottom and pineapple juice on top to emulate the look of an actual pineapple upside-down cake. And all without having to bake anything or even turn on your oven.Some Pineapple Upside-Down Cake Shot recipes call for vanilla vodka (or other flavored vodka), which is also a totally acceptable option. This isn't a drink where you really need to worry about subtlety, so feel free to mess around with all kinds of different ingredients and variations. However, the traditional recipe includes just three simple ingredients: vodka, pineapple juice, and grenadine.Add the grenadine to a shot glass, then shake the vodka and pineapple juice with ice. Strain the contents of the shaker into the shot glass, slowly layering the liquid over the grenadine to create the two-tone effect. You may want to pour the shaken vodka and pineapple over the back of a spoon, which helps the liquid to layer softly on top of the grenadine without disrupting the visual.Note that some people choose to garnish their Pineapple Upside-Down Cake shots with a maraschino cherry. This adds another visual element, but we find that garnishing a shot usually just gets in the way of drinking it. If you love cherries, you may enjoy downing the shot and then eating the cherry as a chaser.

instructions.description: Add the grenadine to a two-ounce shot glass.
Add the vodka and pineapple juice to a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.
Slowly strain into the shot glass over a spoon to layer on top of the grenadine.
Chill a cocktail glass with ice.
Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into the cocktail glass, and serve.

name: Malibu Bay Breeze
description: The Malibu Bay Breeze is a twist on the Bay Breeze cocktail, using Malibu Rum in place of vodka. The Malibu Bay Breeze is a little lighter in alcohol, considering the swap from vodka to a lower-proof rum, and has a subtle coconut flavor. If you can, opt for fresh pineapple juice and some good bottled cranberry juice rather than something loaded with sugar. If the bottle says "contains 5% juice," put it back on the shelf and slowly back away. Fresh juice will turn this from a rather pedestrian drink that's cloyingly sweet to something tart and refreshing. The Malibu Bay Breeze isn't the craftiest of cocktails, but it's easy-drinking, easy to make, and pairs nicely with a beach chair.

instructions.description: Add ingredients into an old-fashioned glass filled with ice, and stir.
Garnish with a lime wedge, and serve.
Optionally can use a highball glass instead of an old-fashioned glass.

name: Liquid Marijuana Shot
description: The Liquid Marijuana shot is, well, not exactly the most subtle cocktail in the world. From what we can gather, the intent of the "liquid marijuana" drink is to get you tipsy, but the most common Liquid Marijuana recipe calls for equal parts spiced rum, coconut rum (commonly Malibu), blue curaçao and Midori melon liqueur—typically lower-proof spirits—making this a relatively low-ABV shooter compared to other shots and despite its druggy name. In addition to its boozy ingredients, the cocktail also features a splash of pineapple juice, lemon juice, and simple syrup. Some recipes call for sour mix, and many bars use it, but the pre-mixed bottled stuff contains artificial flavors and colors, imparting a chemical note to the drink. So, we suggest taking the extra step and using fresh lemon juice and simple syrup. The Liquid Marijuana cocktail has a sweet and fruity flavor and a bright green color. Order one at craft cocktail bars and you're likely to get a raised eyebrow and a quizzical look from your bartender. That said, sometimes it's fun to have a party shot that doesn't take itself too seriously, and many bars around the country are happy to shake up a round for you and your friends.To make the Liquid Marijuana shot, add all your ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake until well-chilled—this is definitely a drink that you want to consume ice-cold. Strain into a shot glass and knock it back. If you're making drinks for a crowd, simply scale up the recipe by multiplying the ingredients by however many servings you need.For the record, there is absolutely no actual cannabis or THC in this Liquid Marijuana drink. If real cannabis is what you're looking for, check out our guide to cannabis cocktails and learn how the real stuff works.

instructions.description: Add the spiced rum, coconut rum, blue curaçao, Midori, pineapple juice, lemon juice, and simple syrup into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a shot glass and serve.

name: Topsy Turvy
description: The Topsy Turvy is a riff on the Manhattan that comes from Brooklyn cocktail bar, Donna. It turns the traditional ratio on its head, opting for twice as much vermouth as whiskey, which makes for a lower proof cocktail. Throw in some coffee liqueur to sweeten things up with a coffee accent, plus some mole bitters, and that's that.Carpano Antica is one of the better sweet vermouths around, with a rich and complex flavor profile. It's a nice base for vermouth-forward drinks like this one, as it won't be drowned out by higher-proof spirits.

instructions.description: Stir all ingredients with ice, then strain into a Nick & Nora glass (or other cocktail glass).
Garnish with an orange twist.
Shake all three ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice.
Strain into a shot glass, and serve.

name: Malibu Peach Jello Shot
description: A Malibu Peach Jello Shot is a fun, colorful cocktail to mix up for your next party. Comprised of just three ingredients—Malibu Rum, Jello, and water—it's typically served as a shot in a shot glass. Follow the cocktail recipe below to learn how to make Malibu Peach Jello Shots for yourself, and enjoy the sweet and fruity shot whenever the occasion calls for something fun and festive.

instructions.description: Boil 1 cup water and add to peach passion fruit jello until dissolved (about 2 minutes).
Mix in 1 cup Malibu rum, then pour into shot glasses or 1 ounce cups found in party stores.
Chill for four hours before serving.

name: Mojito
description: The Mojito is one of the most popular rum cocktails in the world. It is simple to make and a delightfully refreshing drink. With a crisp, sweet, citrusy and minty flavor, the Mojito cocktail is a classic for a reason.From its humble origins in the sugarcane fields of Cuba, it went on to travel the world as a favorite of celebrities, dignitaries, and tourists alike. Now, it’s hard to imagine summertime anywhere without this popular drink.The Mojito was a favorite of Ernest Hemingway (though not as much as the Daiquiri), and is a great cocktail for sipping on the beach or at backyard barbecues.What is in a Mojito?The classic Mojito recipe is an old Cuban original, and the ingredients consist of white rum, mint, lime, sugar (or simple syrup), and sparkling water, like club soda.Start by adding fresh mint leaves to the bottom of a chilled highball glass. Some folks like to add a lime wedge here as well for an extra kick of citrus. If you are using granulated sugar as your sweetener, rather than simple syrup, you should add that now as well. In that case, go ahead and toss in the lime wedge because it helps to break down the sugar. Muddle the mint by pressing lightly with a cocktail muddler—no need to overdo it by crushing the mint leaves to bits, as that will release bitter compounds you don't want in your drink.Next, fill your glass halfway with ice, then add rum, lime juice, and simple syrup if you haven't already added sugar. Stir well to mix all of the ingredients until nice and chilled.Then fill the rest of the glass up with fresh ice, and top off with soda water. Give it another quick stir, garnish, and serve.The combination of rum, lime, mint, and sugar is so natural that it seems they were made for each other. Drink a Mojito on a hot day, and you'll surely agree.As with any celebrated cocktail recipe, bartenders can never leave the recipe alone. Over time, countless Mojito variations popped up as people tried to make the best Mojitos. Fruit-laced versions may include berries, pineapple, mango, peaches, strawberries, grapefruit and other fresh ingredients. And batched recipes resulting in a large pitcher of Mojitos ensure there's plenty to go around for every occasion, from happy hours to pool parties.Who invented the Mojito?As far a we can tell, there is no clear "inventor" of the Mojito. The storied history of the Mojito gives some indication that the drink's origin had something to do with Sir Francis Drake, the famed sea captain, navigator, and privateer known for his daring exploits during the Elizabethan era.In the nineteenth-century Caribbean, we find the first mention of Sir Drake's name associated with the drink that would ultimately become the Mojito—it appears as "El Draquecito" (now more commonly known as El Draque)—and was a popular nickname describing the simple combination of rum, sugar, lime, and mint.While there's no proof that Sir Francis Drake actually invented the cocktail or even drank one of these concoctions, it's reasonable to believe he may have enjoyed something very similar during his time in the islands. Cuban rum and other island spirits at this point were typically unaged with rough edges, so citrus and sugar were used to smooth things out. Since rum, limes and sugar were all abundant in the Caribbean, it seems plausible that drinkers would have thrown them together into a tasty drink that became the Mojito recipe we know and love today.Why is it called Mojito?The origins of the name Mojito are somewhat murky, and the name is believed by some to be derived from mojo, an African word meaning to cast a spell.Realistically, the name most likely comes from the family of Caribbean spices and marinades, or the word mojado, meaning “wet,” but that seems less interesting than casting spells, so let us have our fun.One thing's for sure—the word is recognized and understood across the world, and that makes the Mojito cocktail easy to order just about anywhere you go.

instructions.description: In the bottom of your chilled highball glass, muddle 5-6 mint leaves by pressing lightly with your muddler.
Add simple syrup, lime juice, and rum, then fill the glass with ice.
Top with soda water and stir to combine.
Garnish with a sprig of mint (clap the leaves between your hands once to release the aromas) and a wedge of lime.

name: Mojito Diablo
description: A Mojito variation featuring tequila and creme de cassis, giving it a very interesting profile that sets it apart from the original. The notes of agave and blackcurrant blend together nicely and make this one a must-try.

instructions.description: Muddle sugar, mint and squeezed lime wedges in mixing tin until mixture smells like spearmint gum.
Fill with ice, add tequila and cassis, shake until the tin is icey to the touch.
Pour into a Collins glass, top with soda and garnish with a sugarcane stick and fresh mint.

name: Pornstar Martini
description: The Pornstar Martini (or Porn Star Martini, depending on who you ask) is a delicious cocktail despite its dubious name. Originally invented around 2002 by Douglas Ankrah of The Townhouse in London, it has since become a global hit.The Pornstar Martini consists of two parts: the cocktail itself, made with vodka, passion fruit purée, vanilla syrup, and fresh lime juice; and the shot of champagne or sparkling rosé, which is served on the side. It's certainly glamorous, but it does take quite a while to prepare the ingredients.While you can use standard vodka in the Pornstar Martini, it can also be fun to make some of your own vanilla-infused vodka by adding a fresh, sliced vanilla pod to a bottle and shaking it periodically for a week.Getting your hands on a passion fruit to garnish your Pornstar Martini may be a bit of a challenge—our best suggestion is to check the Asian grocery stores.

ingredients.name: Half A Passion Fruit For Garnish

instructions.description: Add vodka, passion fruit purée, vanilla syrup, and lime juice to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Float half a passion fruit in the drink for garnish.
Fill a shot glass with sparkling wine and serve on the side.

name: Love on the Rocks
description: The delightfully-named Love on the Rocks comes from Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar and Grill, that fine eating spot at Miami Beach hotel, the Plymouth. It's a riff on the modern-classic Paper Plane, which combines bourbon, Aperol, lemon, and Amaro Nonino. Here, you've got those first three ingredients, but sub out the Nonino and sub in some creme de cassis. Plus orange bitters. And Cava.The end result is a bubbly and easygoing cocktail that's perfect for drinking any time of year. But given the name, Valentine's Day seems like a good time to start.

instructions.description: Combine all ingredients over ice and shake.
Strain over fresh ice into a rocks glass, and top with Cava.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

name: Ghost Margarita
description: The Ghost Margarita is a simple riff on the classic Margarita. Here, you're starting with a base of Ghost Tequila, which is made with 100% agave tequila and a dash of hot pepper extract. Throw in some lemon and orange in place of the typical lime juice, and you've got a tart, refreshing cocktail with a hint of spice.

instructions.description: Rim a rocks glass with salt.
Shake all ingredients with ice, and strain into your rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with a lime wheel.

name: White Russian
description: A White Russian is a simple vodka cocktail with a creamy, coffee flavor that makes for a great dessert drink. It is very similar to a Kahlua and Cream but stronger due to the addition of vodka.Believed to have been invented sometime in the 1950s, the White Russian cocktail has enjoyed renewed popularity thanks to the 1998 Hollywood hit The Big Lebowski in which the main character, lovingly called The Dude, no fewer than nine White Russians throughout the entire film.

ingredients.name: Coffee Liqueur (Kahlua Is A Popular Choice)

instructions.description: Fill an old-fashioned glass with ice.
Pour vodka and coffee liqueur into the glass.
Float cream on top.
Optionally, swirl to mix the cream evenly, or leave the cream floated and let the drinker decide.

name: B-52
description: The B-52 is a widely popular shooter cocktail named after the American B-52 bomber, and rumored to have been invented in the 1970s or 1980s. The B-52 shot consists of a coffee liqueur (commonly Kahlúa Coffee Liqueur), an Irish cream (commonly Baileys Irish Cream), and an orange liqueur (commonly Grand Marnier Cordon Rouge)—layered—in that order.

instructions.description: Pour the coffee liqueur into a chilled shot glass.
Layer or float the Irish cream next on top of the coffee liqueur (use an upside down spoon to help if necessary).
Layer or float the orange liqueur on top, and serve.

name: Black Cat
description: The Black Cat is a cherry-flavored vodka cocktail, typically served in a highball glass. A popular cocktail around Halloween, the Black Cat is anything but spooky, and is enjoyable throughout the year.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a Highball glass with ice, stir gently, and serve.

name: Matador Cocktail
description: The Matador is a tequila-based cocktail, and is really just a simple riff on the Margarita recipe with the addition of pineapple juice. It's not clear who invented this cocktail, but the Matador recipe combines three popular Mexican exports—tequila, pineapple, and lime—so it's plausible it was created in Mexico. We prefer the Matador served in a cocktail glass, but have seen it served in other up vessels, as well as on the rocks.

instructions.description: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake vigorously, and strain into a cocktail glass.
Garnish with the lime wheel.
Add Kahlua and tequila to your hot cup of coffee.

name: Mrs. Fitzgerald
description: The Mrs. Fitzgerald is a complex, refreshing spring cocktail devised by the team at Mother's Ruin in New York City. It combines fresh, muddled strawberries, Four Pillars Rare Dry Gin, simple syrup, a bit of absinthe, and a couple dashes of orange bitters to create a truly unique blend of aromas and flavors. The Mrs. Fitzgerald is a perfect recipe for those early spring days when you need an extra splash of color to brighten up the gray skies.

instructions.description: Muddle strawberries in a cocktail shaker.
Add all other ingredients to the shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with a strawberry and serve.

name: Irish Tea
description: Tea is great. It's like a hug in a cup. We'd never besmirch the good name of tea. But we would definitely suggest improvements. For example: whiskey. Whiskey makes tea better. And that's exactly what's going on here.The Irish Tea comes from Ian McCarthy, the man behind Sharpshooter, a mobile cocktail bar operation in San Francisco. And it's combining Irish whiskey with tea, honey, and ginger for an easy-drinking, restorative beverage that will cure what ails you. Even if all that ails you is a thirst for whiskey.

instructions.description: Bring one cup of water to a boil. Add a few small pieces of thinly sliced ginger, along with your tea (one bag, or a tbsp of loose leaf).
Steep for 5 minutes, then strain into a tea cup, and add a tablespoon of honey.
Stir to dissolve, and add your whiskey.
Garnish with a lemon wheel.

name: Water Moccasin Shot
description: The Water Moccasin shot features five ingredients: whiskey, peach schnapps, triple sec, lime juice and simple syrup. It's a popular shot at college bars and, just like the snake, it's got a bite.When making the Water Moccasin recipe, you can choose your favorite whiskey, but no need to reach for anything particularly expensive or refined. A tried and true bottle like Crown Royal does the trick, and is a common pick among bartenders.Given the Water Moccasin's mix of ingredients, it works best as a chilled shot. But if you really like the flavor, you can always pour the drink over ice and sip it as a cocktail. See below for the recipe, and enjoy.

ingredients.name: Fresh Sour Mix (1:1 Lime Juice To Simple Syrup)

instructions.description: Add the peach schnapps, whiskey, triple sec, lime juice and simple syrup to a shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into two shot glasses or serve over ice in an Old-Fashioned glass.

name: Captain and Coke
description: The Captain and Coke is a simple two-ingredient cocktail that's made with Captain Morgan Spiced Rum and Coca-Cola. A more specific version of the Rum and Coke, it's a popular call at bars and a great option for people who enjoy the spicy-sweet flavor of Captain Morgan. The rum blends seamlessly with the cola, creating a flavor combination that drinkers love.The Captain and Coke is typically served over ice, either in a short rocks glass or a taller Collins or highball glass—the latter two options are perfect for those who want a larger drink or one featuring a bit more soda.The next time you need an easy party drink or just something to enjoy at home, mix up a Captain and Coke with the below recipe.What's in a Captain and Coke?A Captain and Coke is about as straightforward as it gets. To make this cocktail, all you need is Captain Morgan Original Spiced Rum and Coke (you can aways get fancy and used Mexican Coke, which is still made with real cane sugar).The history of the Captain and CokeLike its cousin the Rum and Coke, the Captain and Coke owes its existence to an earlier drink, the Cube Libre (aka, "free Cuba", a rallying cry from the conflict). A byproduct of the Spanish-American war that saw the latter nation's most famous export combined with Cuban rum, it went from Havana to the United States in the early 1900s and found widespread popularity as a simple, thirst quenching drink.While the Rum and Coke was typically made with Cuban-style light rum, the drink was adapted to various types of rum, including Captain Morgan's spiced product. How to Make a Captain and Coke The drink is as straightforward to make as it sounds. All you need at hand is some Captain Morgan (or another spiced rum) and Coke. The ratio of this popular drink is a matter of personal preference, so how many ounces of Coke or ounces of rum it may contain is ultimately up to the drinker—though we think that two ounces of rum and four to six ounces of Coke is generally a good rule of thumb. Popular Rums for a Captain and CokeThe name itself implies Captain Morgan would be the best rum for making this drink, but there's nothing to stop you from using a third party spiced rum like The Kraken. But if you go that route, maybe don't call it a Captain and Coke, lest you confuse the bartender or your friends.

instructions.description: Build over ice in a Collins glass or an Old-Fashioned glass.
Serve.

For the tomato mixture, mash a small, pineapple sage leaf at the bottom of a mixing glass. Add 4 oz of tomato juice, 0.3 oz lemon juice, 0.5 tbsp of balsamic vinegar, pinch of salt, pinch of black pepper, dash of Tabasco sauce, and a little grated horseradish and stir very well. Put in refrigerator until chilled (about 2 hours).
Build shooter directly in a large shot glass (or small tumbler glass) by combining vodka and the tomato mixture from above.
Serve on a tray over ice with the oyster and a lemon slice.
Alternatively, drop the oyster into the glass and serve with a lemon slice.

name: Hibiscus Shot
description: Why just do a shot when you can do this and exclaim "YUM!"

instructions.description: Put it all in a shaker with ice
strain
SHOT!
smile

name: Sydney Sunrise Sunshine Cocktail
description: The Sydney Sunrise Sunshine is a nonalcoholic drink that combines fresh orange juice, fresh lime juice, honey, and a whole egg. It's a fortifying pick-me-up in the morning, and in some circles is employed as a hangover cure.The Sydney Sunrise Sunshine is made by blending the ingredients, which creates a silky texture because of the egg. Some people choose to drink the mixture at room temperature, downing it quickly. But you can also pour it over ice if you prefer colder drinks.

instructions.description: Add the orange juice, lime juice, honey, and whole egg to a blender, and blend until smooth.
Pour into a highball glass (ice  is optional).

name: Perfect Brandy Manhattan
description: The Perfect Brandy Manhattan is a variation on the classic Manhattan cocktail, made with brandy instead of whiskey, and using equal parts sweet and dry vermouth, just like the standard Perfect Manhattan. Add in a dash or two of Angostura bitters, and you've got an excellent, classic cocktail.Swapping the spirits in the Perfect Brandy Manhattan makes a fairly substantial difference in the flavor profile, especially if you're used to using a spicy rye whiskey. This is balanced out a bit by the inclusion of dry vermouth, which keeps the sweetness in check. Everyone has their favorite ratio (ours is below), so we recommend experimenting with proportions until you find the perfect balance for your tastes. But you really can't go wrong with the classic 2:1 ratio, in which you mix two parts brandy with one part vermouth, split between sweet and dry.

instructions.description: Place maraschino cherry in a chilled cocktail glass.
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
Strain into cocktail glass and serve.

name: Black Julep
description: The Black Julep is a unique, bittersweet take on the classic Mint Julep, and one that skips bourbon in favor of an Italian aperitif and a German digestif—Cynar 70 and Jägermeister, respectively. That herbal backbone gets a slug of Crème de Peche (a peach liqueur), plus some cold brew coffee to balance you out.
